reviewText:
I've now finished the game so i've updated my review.

This game is a lot of fun, not sure why the professional reviewers hate it so much. Maybe they're expecting it to be a fast-paced action game or something like that which it definitely isn't.

It's a detective game with an interesting story and characters that draws you in. It's also pretty novel in that you're playing a criminal-turned-detective's ghost who's trying to find the identity of his killer. You spend the game collecting clues to figure out your killer's identity while stopping along the way to help out other lost souls in little sidequests where you figure out how they died so they can pass on. There are also lots of collectibles, some of which provide background for the story, such as notes left by the main character's wife, or that unlock stories about unsolved crimes connected to hauntings. You end up collecting a lot of clues and you have to figure out which ones will help you solve whatever crime you're working on. They make sense and its fun. I've noticed a few negative reviews saying the clues don't make sense and you end up just clicking on everything till you get it right. I only did this once at the beginning of the game...and all I can say is, try thinking a bit and paying attention before just mashing your mouse. If you do this, you'll pretty quickly get a feel for how the clues work in the game and figure out which ones are useles. You can also posess the living, and while you can't move them, you can help them remember and eavesdrop on their conversations or thoughts. You can, however, posess cats which allow you to reach places you can't reach on your own. Everything about the game makes sense...you can't walk through the outdoor walls of buildings that have been consecrated, the demons you have to sneak past to take down from behind are souls who never passed on, etc. The mood the game sets just enhances the experience, being creepy and immersive.

Overall, this game is a lot of fun. Story is great, gameplay is fun, voice acting is well done. Having finished the game now, the story is a pretty good detective story, with everything falling satisfyingly into place at the end and a few neat twists. There are only a few drawbacks: the graphics aren't the best, but they're still decent (especially the lip synching); sometimes when you posess someone and listen to their thoughts you'll hear the same thought in different people; the parts where you have to sneak behind demons and take them out can be a bit tedious. However, all these are definitly worth overlooking.

The other drawback is that the game is a bit short. I finished it in 7 hours, and if you check out my achievements you'll see I didn't get 100% completion. I did all the side-quests and found as many collectibles as I could. You could probably stretch it out to 10 hours if you wanted 100% completion which seems totally possible in a single playthrough. Its up to you to decide whether a 7-10 hour game is worth $60 or if you want to wait for a sale.

In short, if you like story-driven games, or mystery/adventure games then you'll probably like this game. If you want this game to be a gritty shooter, then go buy Max Payne instead, because you won't get that with this game. Having finished it, I would now give it between a 7 and an 8 out of 10.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure detective game, which was released in mid-2014 on PC, PS3, PS4, 360 and Xbox One. The game was developed by Airtight Games; which hadn't released anything worthwhile for a while before this game.

You play the role of detective Ronan O'Connor, based in a town called Salem in USA. The story is based around hunting down a serial killer by the name of The Bell Killer". Ronan is killed by the serial killer at the beginning of the game and you are revived as a ghost and must find the killer before he can move on to the afterlife.

The game is played in a third person view as you wander around the town of Salem

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is supernatural detective adventure thriller game where you are playing as detective Ronan. He got murdered by a Bell Killer a primary antagonist and now he need to solve his case as a ghost.

Pros:+ Great main character
+ Voice acting is really good
+ Enjoyable graphics
+ Good story and atmoshpere
+ Lots of collectibles
+ As a ghost you can walk through walls, read people's minds etc.

Cons:- Short ( main story for around 6 hours )
- Combat is poor ( you basically sneak behind the enemy and do fast QTE)
- Only one type of enemy
- Most of NPC's are just clones/duplicates
- Only 4 optional quests ( to finish them you need like 5-10 mins each)

reviewText:
An uncommon title, yet it suffers some shortcomings // Recommended for those who seek a story-rich experience*
*You'd likely prefer it at sale price

+ Voice-acting is excellent
+ Facial movements and lip synchronization are above average
+ Character makes a ghostly 'impression' on walls and objects as they are passed through; this makes it easy to keep track of areas previously visited
+ Mechanics in place to facilitate ones investigation are inventive and refreshing
+ Ephemeral bits of Salem's past look fantastic, and work with the mortal world to create a uniquely hybrid environment
+ Disposing of demons is a somewhat satisfying experience, and is the only time in the game that really requires situational awareness and a tactical approach
+ 'Unfinished business' side-quests are interesting and well-scripted
+ While Ronan isn't exactly a unique, well-written character (he isn't), he and Joy are, at least, well fleshed-out and see a satisfying level of development throughout the story
+ Successfully creates a dark and unsettled atmosphere; gameplay is very immersive

- Choices are meaningless, and funnel into a solitary conclusion
- Puzzles/Crime scene investigations require almost no thinking, and the solutions are always quite obvious
- NPC models are shamefully copy/pasted
- Due to linear story and few 'off the beaten path' collectibles and additions, there is little replay value to speak of
- While unique and interesting, the historical remnants of the environment serve only to limit exploration in practice

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
From the first article I read about this game I was hooked. Investigating your own murder and other crime scenes as a ghost? Yes please! The idea seemed so original and any screen shots I had seen looked awesome.

So I get the game and the first half hour is awesome. You'll have fun getting used to the controls and your own abilities as a ghost, but it didn't take me long to lose interest in walking through walls and making printers/TV's malfunction because at the end of the day, you rarely stumble across anything interesting or you get little to no reaction from the living people in the area. I mean come on! if I'm a ghost I want to be able to scare the living. Not just distract them from guarding that door for 20 seconds.

So let's get down to the things that really got on my nerves.

(1) Gameplay - It gets repetitive. Honestly, you'll find yourself running across the city/buildings where  your obstacles will be either one of  two things.

- Oh there's a demon there? better sneak up on them and extract their soul.

Or

- Oh would you look at that, a fiery pit straight to hell is blocking my path. Luckily for me there's  this person here I can possess, who's sole propose seems to be walking down this hall for the rest of their lives.

Oh which leads me to another thing, if you give us the ability to read minds, actually have the characters think interesting stuff that's personal to them, instead of the same thing like, Oh its cold outside" or "I hope they find that killer" Seriously

Gumshoe detective seeks soulmate for end of the world
MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT begins its tale with your murder. A serial killer known as The Bell Killer is terrorizing Salem, stalking and butchering young woman in a gruesome fashion reminiscent of its famous past. Taking on the role of Detective Ronan O'Connor, a former juvenile delinquent and all round bad boy turned good, your fate appears to be initially quite simple: Wrong place, wrong time - or is it?

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=330033152
MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT, the new supernatural thriller from Airtight games who brought us the wonderful Quantum Conundrum and the not so wonderful reboot of Dark Void, is a pleasantly passable affair for any armchair detective out there. It has an interesting story filled with twists and turns and red-herrings galore (not all of them making much sense in the cold light of day unfortunately) and it evokes a fantastically eerie atmosphere (think the movie The Skeleton Key) thanks to some really creepy and creative environments and a back-story that involves the Salem Witch Hunt trials from the late seventeenth century. Impeccably voiced by a cast of seasoned voice professionals and featuring sound and audio design only the best publisher money can buy, MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT plays out like any modern day thriller you would catch on a Friday night at the movies to ebb away the toils of a hard week at school, university or work.

While the central mystery to MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT is indeed a thrilling journey, its rather heavy-handed approach to giving its main protagonist some definition is often so blunt it may as well be walking around town dropping anvils on peoples heads. It borders on being almost too puritanical especially for a game with such a modern day setting. Rather than subtly hint at Ronan's past as a boy with a murky past the gamer is constantly hit on the head with a jack-hammer as it drives its points home. I am not entirely sure in what world an obscenely tattooed man (given that in today's climate, tattooing oneself excessively can be a rather expensive en devour) is grounds for defining a poor and violent upbringing but MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT appears to be madly in love with its clichés.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=327624985
Most of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT requires the player to move from A to B and solve puzzles in the process and this where the game commits murder most foul. I am not sure if it's because the game was designed particularly for consoles (and the limitations that brings) but the game mechanics I found were too simplistic and held no challenge whatsoever. Not once did I feel like I was doing any worthy detective work to unmasked this unhinged killer but simply pressing buttons. When I look back at games like Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father or Gabriel Knight: The Beast Within (two very similar themed games that married murder, the supernatural and mystery together perfectly) - both made the player work to unravel the mystery and there was a sense of accomplishment the player felt when finally cracking a particularity difficult section that required all the players wits. None of that is present in MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT. In fact a monkey can solve this riddle which I found rather disappointing.

While graphically the game looks great, thanks to some excellent level design, exploring the town of Salem does start to loose its appeal quite early in. Many environments and character models are re-used add infinium and for such a small game (there isn't a whole lot to explore here) seeing townsfolk that look identical to the previous townsfolk starts to break the immersion the game is so desperately trying to create. The game also features the ability to possess passers by, witnesses and police guards but it's never brought to its full potential with the gamer mostly only being given the opportunity to listen to their thoughts which to be honest are all duller than the dirtiest of dish water. These inner monologues also start to repeat fairly quickly which results in a Salem that feels more like Stepford. The game also tries to introduce stealth sections into the gameplay but these felt totally out of place and every time the game forced me into this mode I stopped caring for it until they had passed. They are not particularly enjoyable and once again they play out more like stealth-lite for 5 year olds.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=328177727
MURDERD: SOUL SUSPECT could have been the next Gabriel Knight supernatural mystery for a new generation of gamers but unfortunately it falls a bit short. While it has an engrossing story that should please most fans who care for anything supernatural or anything that involves hunting for serial killers; it unfortunately performs quite a few mystery adventure cardinal sins that ultimately ends up placing it squarely in camp mediocre. One for a sale definitely.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-

reviewText:
Ah, Soul Suspect. The trailer alone had me clapping my hands from excitement. However, there's a lot to say about the game itself.

The concept seems unique at first; a murdered cop who is forced to solve his own murder before he can pass on to the other side, where he can be reunited with his dead wife. It's not an angle you see often. That being said, the game feels empty when it comes to gameplay and the semi-original plot can't make up for it. It feels like all your abilities seem to have huge potential and you have fun playing with them for an hour or so, excited about what more you can do along the way. Then you realise that you're limited to distracting people with flashing lights and walking through a wall (but not all walls, only some walls, obviously) every now and again.

You also have the ability to possess people, which seems wicked awesome at first. You can possess pretty much anyone you meet and you have the options of mind reading or influencing them. However, the reality of possession is that you possess a person, read their mind and they're like Oh man
date: it's sort of chilly today" or "I hate my job" and you lose interest pretty fast when that's all you hear.\n\nIn the end

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is detective-ghost story told through the interactive-medium of gaming. Murdered is kind of like a combination between a TellTale game, LA Noire, and Alan Wake... But honestly the game is more often than not more like an interactive movie, and I think it's with these expectations that you best experience Murdered.

Murdered: Soul Suspect tells the tale of a man named Ronan, who at the game's start experiences his own death. He is pushed out of the window by a notorious murderer, who is known as the Bell Killer, who then commences to shoot him seven times in the chest. Ronan grew-up as a criminal in Salem, but changed his ways late in life to become a detective, partially for the woman he loved, Julia. However, he was torn apart a few months earlier, when Julia's life was taken at the hands of a street mugger. At death's door, Ronan discovers he is a spirit to this world, trapped here until he can move on from something that's keeping him bounded here. He finds out that he can be with Julia again in the world beyond our own if he can resolve whatever is keeping him here, so he goes out to try and solve the case of his own murder.

Gameplay is rather simplistic in Murdered. You will spend most of your time exploring around, using your ghost powers, and looking for items and clues in the environment. As a ghost, you can freely pass through human-world objects, which essentially makes clipping a gameplay mechanic, but you might be surprised how natural it ends up feeling and due to some good visual cues and sounds it ends up not looking or feeling weird, and makes sense with everything else built up with the game. The only objects you can't pass through are ghost-world objects (relics from the past which are present in the ghost world, and tell-able they're ghost world as they glow with a blue aura), and into or out of buildings freely (ghosts can only enter or exit buildings through open doors or windows). Other powers at your disposal include the ability to possess people, to either read their minds or influence their thoughts, to poltergeist and make objects (mostly machinery) act up, to teleport around by choice, and a few other underutilized but still interesting powers.

The game splits-up between 'stages' (bigger interior areas usually), and a Salem hub-world. The stages I thought generally got better as the game went on, and Salem was a joy to explore... At first. The problem is that not much really happens in Salem, it stays the same mostly for the whole game so you can literally almost do everything in it the first time you enter the hub-area (with only a few things you can only do once you gain the teleportation power).

As you explore, there's a variety of content to immerse yourself in the world. There's a lot of side areas and areas off the beaten path. You can approach living people to listen in to conversations they're having with each other, made more amusing you can then possess them and see what they're REALLY thinking. You can approach ghosts, and either talk to them briefly, question them about something they're up too, and very occasionally help them via a side-quest to move onto from this world to the next. However, there are literally only about 3-4 side-quest in the game, and there is obvious content and characters that were left around for more side-quests, but were left-out as cut content. Things like items you can observe for no real reason, characters it looks like you would be able to help but then they cut you short from actually helping them.

And then there's the collectibles. This game kind of goes overboard with it's collectibles, but they're pretty enjoyable and expand a lot on the plot, the lore, Salem's history, character background's, additional cinematics, and my personal favorite, ghost stories. Extended from this, the investigation scenes usually have you looking for and going about collecting clues, and then putting together the clues that matter to a particular solution or outcome. These typically were rather simple, and sometimes felt more like sort of mindless collecting to get to the point. However, other times they actually felt kind of rewarding. None were really 'puzzles' I would say, but were a mixed bag.

The only other real gameplay mechanic is demons, which are rather underutilized. I didn't find them offensive, and I'll admit there was a few times when their screeches or them detecting me legitimately startled and scared me. However, there's only one type of demon in the game, you only face a few of them in the game, and their encounters are often brief and they're easy enough to deal with (you sneak up behind them to execute them, otherwise they spot you and chase you down, where you hide in things until they lose interest).

But then this is a game I'd argue isn't really about winning or losing, it's an interactive film essentially, and on that account it pulls some things off really well.

Firstly, the audio design is fantastic in this game. The voice acting for the main characters are all well-done and performed, and even most minor characters are rather well-voiced (though you'll find a few reoccurring VAs). The ghost stories you can get via collectibles deserve particular praise, as the acting done here really adds a lot to the story, and honestly are really well-done.

But it's not just the voice acting. The music is very good too, with some good creepy vibes, emotional melodies, and songs to go well to the mystery. The ambiance of sounds in the environment also add a lot, with a lot of attention to detail to help bring the locations alive. And even the game sounds, for solving cases, getting clues, etc., are all satisfying and fitting.

The story is quite good, especially if you like detective-ghost stories, ala' The Frighteners, Sixth Sense, or the like. While the writing can be a bit hammy at times, they do have some believable dialogue between characters, the story has interesting developments as it goes on, and there are some rather well-done plot twists throughout.

Cinematics deserve special mention. The cinematography is really well-done, with fantastic angles, focus, artistic direction, and were a joy to watch.

And the characters are well-realized, trope-ish, but manage to be developed and become more than their tropes and have rather realistic relationships with each other. They have fights and don't agree, but come together (sometimes reluctantly), and there are a few heart-warming moments and real development with each other as it goes on.

Graphically it looks good for the sort of niche budget title it is. Some nice attention to detail in environments, some good art direction, and some of the models are rather well poly'd. There's some visual quality dips in certain areas, textures... But not a bad looking game at all.

Generally, I would label this as a game for gamers who like story, exploring, and world-building above all else. Gameplay really takes a step-down to the game's other elements, and it will definitely strike with its niche. But its lack of action, focus on making what is usually the 'extra' parts of games the main part, and just the general styling and minimal gameplay make it lack that mainstream appeal. I'd also say it isn't worth its $50 pricetag, but felt it was worth it for the $15-25 range.

I'd say if the game interests you, it is worth experiencing... Just maybe not at full price. It is different than your typical budgeted game in this day and age, and is sure to find a cult audience. In some aspects, it's a bit disappointing or under-cooked, but as a whole, this may be one of the best realized classic-styled ghost stories to appear in the gaming medium for years. Like the Fedora or not, Ronan is the perfect tour guide into a very different look at ghosts, Salem, and games with a budget.

reviewText: This is a game that needs to be approached with the right mindset in order to be fully and properly understood. Murdered is an interactive movie with a story straight out of the best 90's B-reel supernatural horror flicks that dominated the video store of an era long bygone. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game that will engage you and take you back to a simpler time of gaming.

reviewText:
Ever thought about being a ghost?  Pass through walls, posses people, teleporting,  making the T.V. go wild, things like this make it fun to be one. Of course, being a ghost has to be somewhat dark and taken seriously. After all, being a ghost means you’re dead.
Murdered Soul Suspect is a game where Ronan, a detective that follows a lead, dies but stays in this world as a ghost and the only thing that keeps him from finding peace is solving the case. The story is very noir like, despite the presence of modern objects, since the dark atmosphere and the mystery  are the things that are unavoidable in this game.  The plot is as it should be,  clear, logic and ended with enough closure to make you realize what a good story it is. In a world where ghosts have many questions, where are mediums that can see that and a killer that hunts those people down, you are the one that provides the answers.  There are ghosts that you can help find peace. There are collectibles that give you a lot of backstory on various topics and characters. There is one murderer that can’t be stopped still loose in this town. All of this is obvious throughout the game and that’s what will keep you hooked.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=412829954
Gameplay wise, the game is easy. To put it simply, you’ll  take walks,  find clues, conclude investigations with the correct solution, execute demons by taking them from behind and collecting stuff if you feel like it. To put it as it is, things are more complex than that, but not much more.  In order to gain clues, you’ll need to look for them at the crime scene , you’ll need to interact with someone or something to find more, which sometimes mean possessing a person, influencing them to think about the topic you need or looking through their eyes.  The things that present a challenge in this game are the demons, that are very much alike with the dementors. They’ll consume your soul if you are exposed to them for long enough.  You can pass by them, or you can execute them by going behind them and using one of your ghostly abilities. Ronan can hide from them by possessing people or hiding in different entities. At the player disposal is also the ability to see the demon from afar, even through walls.Facing the demons are the stealthy section of the game, but they’re not frustrating enough to make the game challenging at all. For completitionists, there are a lot of collectibles to be found, which contain backstories of characters and places, or a separate story.  They aren’t hard to be found and there are more than one good guides, so you could say it’s easy to get all the achievements. The town of Salem is beautiful, varied but after you explore it all, it feels like a small place.  There is free roam until the last mission, but that is useful for those who want to get back to specific locations to get the rest of the collectibles.  Also, if you see an NPC that looks interesting to you, you can posses him and hear what he thinks.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=412831624
Is the game a great one? No, it’s simply good. It lasts for about 10 hours, it has great concepts and executes them simply, which may be a fault for it, since many said about the game that it had great potential. Still, there’s no other game that can make you have fun for being a ghost like this one.  Passing through walls, possessing people, talking with other ghosts, potterghasting different object to perturb the living ones, it’s all very enjoyable. The theme is dark, some details are gritty, it’s a game where you solve a mystery which has a solution that isn’t obvious at all(the plot-twists turned out to be mind-blowing).
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=412830626
All in all, Murdered Soul Suspect is a good game that delivers on what it describes itself to be and doesn’t take risks in being something more.

reviewText:
7.5/10 Very Good game , but id recommend buying it on sale.

A mix of Alan Wake meets LA Noire and has a baby delivered by Bigby Wolf with the whole thing being recorded by Nicholas Cage on a 8mm film, and Jennifer Love Hewitt standing by to help all the ghosts watching cross over.

PROS:
- Good mystery story and atmosphere
- Lots of collecting
- Very interesting system and dynamic of game while playing as ghost
- Dark undertone of story
- Enjoyable graphics and pretty smooth gameplay imo ( had only 1 minor bug fixed by reloading )

CONS:
- very little and very simplistic combat (might as well remove it completely and add a few more sidequests or even some puzzles)
- if you strictly rush main story without exploring or doing sidequests might be a bit short. I did 2 playthroughs first one i collected all except 5 items and it took me 12 hours, second one i rushed to get those few items and it took me 5h to get almost to last part of game ( Judgement house). So rushed probably 6h playthrough.
- wish world was more open to explore and more interractive and immersive (ghosts you meet are pretty forgetable after you do quest)
- this would work great as a mystery adventure with some rpg progression
- not really scary , very little horror.  More of a murder mystery thriller if you ask me.

CONCLUSION:
Worth playing. Hope there is a sequel and i will buy it when it comes out.

reviewText:
I am here against all odds to recommend this game to everyone. You will like this game if you are like me and loved reading those detective novels.

The Good Very Cinematic Approach, with a 1st person narration and 3rd person navigation.
Quite an intriguing story.
Even though the theme is supernatural it doesnt talk about religiousness or any other stupid stuff instead focuses on the characters that are in the game instead.
The background score is great along with good voice actors.
Very simple controls nothing too fancy considering the fact that this is a ported game from a console version.The BadThe Story is so condensed that the entire game takes place within a single night. In a sense it is a fast paced game but it doesnt feel like a fast paced game at all. The only other comparable game would be Fahrenheit aka The Indigo Prophecy.
You are a ghost, there are a ton of fun stuff you could probably do as a ghost but this game doesnt allow you to fulfill your Hollowman dreams.
The Story is very linear, there are no alternate endings, hence its very predictable considering it is a AAA priced game there should have been alternate endings.
Limited exploration of the surroundings, you dont get to go everywhere you want. The only reason you get to explore is because you have to collect certain artifacts and items -again- the reward for which is negligible and has no direct relation to the game's storyline.
In a way the game does try to teach 'children' about a moral about fulfilling your debts and being honest & things like that, but the developers forgotm kids dont get to spend 50 bucks. Teenagers and Grown up gamers do.
You do get to snoop around a little to help a few other souls to 'move on' but it is nearly not enough.
I am a DOG person why are there so many cats here and no DOGS in Salem ??
The UglyThere is no denying the fact that the game has a very sloppy game engine. The quadruped animation quality of the cats are less than okay.
I was stuck in a limbo / mid air within the first 5 minutes of the game.
The lack of action. Despite what the trailer had me believing there is absolutely NO action game play here. The Cut Scene sequences are fun to watch but thats it.
There was a million different ways how this game could have been made way better than what it is, the story, the interactivity, the side missions everything felt too little and too less.My rating 3.8/5

reviewText:
Mudered: Soul Suspect left me wanting in almost every aspect of the game. I expected an engaging story focused 3rd person game with puzzles and minimal to no combat and in a way thats what you get here, just not well executed.

Graphical Fidelty is mediocre as you would expect from a Console Port and i wouldnt mind if the mechanics and story were up to compensate for that. The Main mechanic of conducting an investigation is for them to designate an area where you look for a set number of clues to tell you what happened. This almost plays like a hidden object game and its really not interesting. At the end you are supposed to select some of the clues to conclude your investigatoin into a story and a little cutscene tells you what you gathered from that.

Sometimes you can possess a witness where you can peek through his eyes to find a clue on a screen or notepad, influence his memory by selecting a clue you found so that he reveals more information about that or you can eavesdrop on a conversation. The Problem with all this is that you do it maybe 5 times in the game with some effect while the rest of the time, it doesnt do anything at all. Mindreading in Salem is really boring and i hope the real inhabitants have more going though their head than these NPCs.

The Game has two types of collectibles which reveal some lore about your former life or a criminal story. The lore bits about your former life or you girlfriend reveal information one at a time which you can access by going into a horrible menu where you have to click on each piece individually to see what it says. And the Navigatoin of the Menu is horrible, the most basic pc-conversion where using your mouse is a pain, they put no effort into adjusting a system for pc which is badly designed from the start. Why dont you let me just click on this! You just dont want to navigate through this to get 2 sentences about the meaning of your tattoos, or how you met your deceased wife.

The second tye which reveals a little story is even worse, because these are collectibles in a major areas which only reveal their story after you collected all of them. This means you can run around the levels for ages looking for that last piece which extends the game time in a very boring and artificial way. Only some true OCD guys will suffer through that.

And they even have more ideas how to prolong their game time. Sometimes there are areas with demons which can end your undead life unless you sneak up behind them and press a button+mouse combination to ban them. So you jump from hiding point to hiding point to get behind them and banish all of them. This is neither challenging nor interesting, its only annoying because you want to get through this part which adds nothing to the game.

All in all i am very disappointed and if i had payed full price for this i would be furious. The game doesnt know how to tell its story through its mechanics. the mechanics are uninspired and boring and there is a lot of filler to prolong a game wich doesnt have much to offer. I took 7h for the main story line and there was an infuriating bit at the end, where i had a lot of respawns right on top of these black spot which draw you into the abyss. So i got to spawn found myself  dying and reloading several times in a row before i could continue to the end.

I am Sorry but A resounding: Dont Buy! from me

reviewText:
I was fairly dissapointed with how this game turned out. The concept was interesting, and I love the genre; however, the excution of the game play mechanics was lacking in any real dept. All of the crime scenes were a fixed camera angle away from being a point and click adventure, and putting the clues together could be done by random guessing without penalty. The characters felt forced, and fell deeply into non-relatable stereotypes that were hard to really care about. I really wanted to like the story, but I kept finding myself just grinding through everything to see it end.

I couldn't see me much functionally wrong with the game, and didn't encounter many bugs; however it just got down right boring. The stealth/combat whatever they were going for with the demons, ended up becoming an annoyance, and half the time I could just run by them without worry. The voice acting, music, and ambient atmosphere were excuted well, and they created the emotions the story was trying to encourage. Unfortunatly the writting its self was too forced, and anti-climatic at best.

I completed the game in about 7 hours without collecting everything, but I did all the side cases I could find. It wasn't a completely regrettable expierence, but for the price you're better off waiting for a good sale as this is a play once and uninstall title. I hope this helps someone from being stuck with a $50 dissapointment like I am.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third-person adventure game, in which you play the role of a ghost, who needs to find out about his mysterious murder.

You're playing Ronan O'Connor, a detective, who gets murdered right at the beginning of the game. The Murderer itself gets away unidentified and you're staying in this world as a ghost, to find out what happend, why and who did it.

The game itself is very story-driven. You're walking (or running) around the different hubs, interacting with items or persons, trying to find clues (and combining them) about your murder or the victims of the serial killer, which you were after at the beginning.
There are also various collectibles to be found, which will keep you occupied (if you like things like this).

Graphics are pretty neat and i liked the atmosphere of the game, though, even as you visit different scenes and buildings, the overall look doesn't change drastically. A bit more variety could have been better.

The story kept me entertained quite well and had also some nice twists throughout the game.

There is one part, which could be frustrating: from time to time demons appear on your path, which you'll either need to evade or destroy. THis only happens at certain points in the game (not often) and if you kill them, they'll be gone forever and won'T reappear.
It's not *that* hard, but if you don't like things like this in an adventure game, then you might have a little hassle here.

Apart from that, i can recommend this to all players, which like fairly easy, story-driven adventure games.

reviewText:
If you like games such as L.A Noire and Sherlock Holmes this should be right up your alley. It is different from those games though, because this is you solving your own crime. That means your a ghost, wandering around the town looking for clues. I would say this is a very unique game, and that's rare these days.

Gameplay wise it's simple, look around for clues, draw a conclusion and go to the next place. it's very interesting because you are a ghost and you can simply walk through walls. However you cant go through solid buildings, unless someone opens the door for you. You can also use abillities like poltergeist, mind control and even take over a cat.

This game is extremely story heavy, and the story is really intresting. It kept me coming back until I was done. Even the simple sidequests really intrigued me and made me want to collect every little collectible I could find.

About 1,5 hour of the game is cutscenes and the others are gameplay. It's not that long of a game, but I would actually say this was the perfect lenght. It didn't overstay its welcome and drag out for to long. The story was exciting all the way through, and you could never figure out who it was until the end.

A lot of plot twists in this game, which reminded me of Heavy Rain. The story is great thanks to impressive cutscenes and good voice acting. Any downsides with this game? Only that the demons and the elements were quite repetitive, but that isn't that big of a complaint since the game didn't go on for that long, and I can clearly see that they put the work on cutscenes and story instead.

I really enjoyed my time in this dark and gritty town. This is a game that everyone should play at some point in my honest opinion, it's that damn good. I really hope they will make a sequel or something along those lines.

reviewText:
This a fairly classic noir story -- with a supernatural twist. I've seen the reviews that put the game at around a 5-6 (mediocre) and on one hand I can see that. The graphics aren't anything amazing and for fifty bucks I'd like to have spent longer than 8 hours to finish the main story. On the other hand, what a fun (if somewhat predictable) story. I especially enjoyed the investigation elements; they're reminiscent of games like L.A. Noire or Condemned: Criminal Origins. Even more, the game is focused exclusively on the storytelling and there's really no combat or action -- it's all about the mystery and puzzles. What little combat there is in the game is mostly based on sneaking around and running away from enemies (you can only attack them from behind).

Where the game really shines is in characterization and story development. The two main characters, Ronan and Joy, have a great odd couple vibe that had me laughing in spots. Most of the character development for everyone else (and even backstory for Joy and Ronan) happen through collectibles but provide really deep storytelling that is (occasionally) historically accurate and interesting.

I'd recommend this to mystery or noir fans but suggest you wait for the price to come down since the game is so short. I finished all the main story, the interactive" sidequests AND managed to collect about 75 percent of all the collectibles in my 8 hour play through."

reviewText:
I am judging this review based on its full price and therefore cannot recommend it. I would only recommend getting this game when there is a deep sale.

The pro/con section will be at the bottom of this review .

Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective adventure game where you play as Ronan, an ex-con badass who became a cop to atone for his wrong doings. You get killed by a man in a hoodie and become a ghost. You learn that you need to find clues to figure out who killed you in order to complete your unfinished business" and be at peace. This game had so much potential to be something great but fell short and left me with an unsatisfactory experience.

Gameplay
This is a detective game where you play as a ghost in the mortal world. Think about all the things you can do as a ghost
date: it's going to be awesome!.. Or at least that's what you are led to believe. You start off the game learning that can you can walk through walls
recommended: only to realise that there are "ghost walls" all over the town Salem that you can't walk through. These walls are just there to hinder you from exploring the town of Salem and become extremely annoying after a while. Next you learn that you could possess random people and read their minds
hoursPlayed: only for it to get boring and repetitive after 20 minutes. The people around the town were bland and shamelessly copy pasted and the only thing you get from reading their minds were always something along the lines of "Oh dear a murder
voteText: that’s terrible" or "I wish it wasn't so cold". It's the same thing over and over again and eventually you just won't bother with the possessions. Their scripted dialogue with each other is pretty interesting to listen to though.\n\nThe core gameplay has you travel from place to place in order to investigate scenes and solve puzzles. You have to find a couple of clues and then come to a conclusion about what the killer was doing or where he was going to next
helpfulPercent: much like the crime scene investigations in L.A Noire . However the puzzles are so painfully simple and boring that it doesn't take you long to come to a conclusion. In the end it just becomes a sort of glorified find the object game with an extremely obvious "which one of these objects are related to the crime?" conclusion (seriously
votesHelpful: a spoon
votesTotal: a fork
votesFunny: or a key that belonged to the killer? I wonder which of these are relevant).\n\nThe combat system is an extremely basic stealth system where you have to hide from patrolling demons and then execute them when they weren't looking at you. However
commentsCount: like most of the game
column16: demons pose little to no challenge and are just there to hinder you and fill time. The combat didn't evolve over the course of the game and after the 4th or 5th time I heard the demons arrive I just thought to myself "ugh not again".\n\nYou also have several dialogue options to choose from during the story
column17: but these have no effect on the story at all. There are also side quests where you go about helping other ghosts to finish their business and these quests are rather interesting.\n\nThere are collectibles hidden all around the map for you to collect
column18: these will allow you to learn about the town of Salem
column19: Ronan's background as well as give some insight on the killer. Unfortunately there is no map function and also no way for you to check which collectible you already have and which ones you still need to find.  I enjoyed listening and reading the stories about the artifacts I collected and make exploring the town enjoyable
column20:
I just wished the damned ghost walls weren't so restrictive and annoying.

Graphics
The game is quite good looking and the town of Salem looks great. The ghost structures and mortal buildings complemented each other well to give this dark and gloomy feeling.
The main characters looked unique and well designed. There is a 30fps when you have v-sync on
column21:
but you can turn off v-sync in game and use v-sync from an external program such as Nvidia's control panel and the game will run at 60fps.

Sound
The music in this game was pretty good. It set the mood really well and occasionally the music would go eerily quiet to build tension. The combat music also tries its best to build excitement and tension but was unfortunately unable to complement or help the poor combat system.
The voice acting in this game was superb and was one of the only reasons why I could finish this game. I enjoyed listening to the conversations between the main characters and especially liked listening to many of Ronan's monologues.

Pros
+ Town looks great when the "ghostly" and "mortal" buildings are mixed together to form a unique hybrid look
+ Voice acting is superb
+ Interesting lore and backstory about the town as well as the protagonist
+ Good chemistry between the main characters
+ Interesting storyline
+ Side quests are a nice change of pace

Cons
- Basic and boring combat system
- Core puzzle solving is too simple and repetitive
- Extremely linear game
- Ghost walls are a hindrance
- Somewhat clunky controls
- Choices make no difference to the story's conclusion
- No replay value

In conclusion this game is an overly simplified detective game with a boring stealth combat system slapped on it. It fails to impress

reviewText:
This is a fine example of style over substance. The voice acting is solid, the writing is generally okay (it's cliched at times, but has some decent moments) and it looks good.

Unfortunately, it is hampered by gameplay which ranges from mediocre to bad.

On the mediocre side, you are given a mere handful of skills, which are used remarkably infrequently and only in very obvious situations. The detective aspect has some good aspects, but while it mostly avoids LA Noire's tendency towards arbitrary and frustrating sleuthing, it does so by making things terribly obvious and having no consequences for failure. My favourite was a scene where you have to find a key. Not only does the game tell you how to go about getting to the key, it then presents you with a puzzle to pick it up, where you have to choose between the key, a fork and a spoon. Spoiler: the correct answer is the key.

As for the bad, the combat is hideous. Awkward controls, very limited options and overwhelming noise make for a frustrating experience.

There's plenty of collectables in the game, some of which are at least a mild challenge to get, but unless you're really into that aspect of it, you're better off just watching the story on YouTube.

reviewText:
Well, I did not know who Airtight Games was up until now but doing 2 consecutive walkthroughs of Soul Suspect will certainly make me remember them for a while! This is a third-person view adventure game that employs some stealth elements and lots of crime scene investigation gameplay mechanics.

The story follows Ronan, a con-turned-detective who has just been murdered and whose soul - for some reason - cannot leave this world and proceed to Heaven where his wife awaits. We soon learn his killer is the one he was originally after - a couple of cutscenes later his memory is refreshed and he is certain he needs to solve the mystery of the Bell Killer who has been haunting his residential town for a while so that by solving the murder case he can peacefully enter Paradise.

Now, when playing this game I was constantly thinking of the adventure games released by Telltale Games. Why? Because the puzzles are easy and there is a great emphasis on the story immersion. Unlike those Telltale adventures Murdered allows you to control the protagonist and freely walk around in Salem.

Still, I wouldn't really call this an open-world journey as many places are only accessible if the story demands it - the hub area" is mainly for collectibles and a couple of side missions where you help other ghosts finish their business and ascend once and for all.

Then come the demons. Certain sections require you to hide from the beasts and approach them while they turn away - execution is not mandatory but collecting evidence and other "artifacts" in the areas require you to rid Salem of them for good.

While the game is not difficult
recommended: and lacks any real combat it does have a great story. I almost completed it in one sitting as I really wanted to see the antagonist dealt with. Murdered has a great atmosphere which is accompanied by a great score and very well done voice acting.\n\nTo summarise: if you are in for a great story and for something new and you do not mind that one playthrough gives you all the experience (a 2nd should only be done for the collectibles) then Soul Suspect is an easy grab - especially with a discount!"

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective puzzle(?) game, with some action(?) elements.

You play as Ronan O’Connor, a cop whose wife died. That's all the back story the game has to offer. Though there was a bunch of collectables, each one had around 2-3 sentences of boring info. So I never bothered to read them, as it wasn't engaging or well wrote at all (much like this review).

Ronan is murdered at the start of the game by the Bell-Tower Killer, who Ronan was hunting down. He soon discovers he is a ghost, and he must solve his death to move on to the afterlife.

The game is open world, in the sense it has a hub of sorts between missions. It's literally just filler to add time to the game as you walk a short distance to the next area. The hub is littered with collectables to find, but they glow up so it's easy to get them all quickly.

Investigations are poorly done. The only game I could compare this to is L.A Noire. But this feels like the poor man's L.A Noire. It's a total cheap knock-off. Asians are not only making fake American clothing, but games now too.

You are thrown into an area and must walk about looking for clues. There is no indication of what might be a clue, so sometimes you could be spending upwards 10 minutes looking for the final one. Only to stumble upon by sheer luck, Whereas in L.A Noire, the controller would vibrate, or a jingle would play.

The clues are also really badly thought out. Most of them are just one word, or a little phrase. Instead of finding proper evidence, you'll get one word like damage"
date: or "scratch". It's as if no thought was poured into the game.\n\nThe only action in the game consists of you running up behind demons and holding a key

reviewText:
„All those street brawls. It’s amazing I lived as long as I did.” ~Ronan

MURDERED: Soul Suspect is a new game made by Airtight Games, known from their other, warmly acclaimed production: Quantum Conundrum. This time, instead of a puzzle-adventure game devs made sure to provide us with a polished action-adventure suspense story backed with a supernatural mystery. Although professional reviewers are mostly critical about this game, I’ll try to convince You that it’s actually worth both its price and Your attention.

The Game starts on a high note, with our protagonist – reformed cop Ronan - falling to his death after brutal fight with a mysterious murderer haunting the streets of modern day Salem. Soon he comes to his senses, only to discover that death itself was just a beginning. We end up being trapped on earth, but in a new ghostly form, with our mind set on a one simple goal: to complete our unfinished business, and finally move on to the other side.

Unfortunately for Ronan, this unfinished business involves solving this one last case, which ultimately led him to his own demise by the hand of a dreadful Bell Killer. Luckily our hero is a fast learner, and easily adapts to the new state he’s woken up to. On our quest to hunt down the killer we’ll be using Ronans wits and experience gained as a police detective to find new leads, connect evidences and even access past memories imprinted into the ghost-realms fabric.

The game consists of two different gameplay modes – first being a free roam explorations, during which we use our ability to pass through objects, summon or cast away solid fragments of the past Salem, and later even teleport to pass beautifully designed locations while finding as much collectibles as we can, and second being much slower ‘investigation mode.’

The investigations are the most iconic moments of the game, and thanks to their presence many players felt obliged to describe Soul Suspect as “L.A. Noirish”. I’d argue with this opinion, because although in both games we progress through solving some cases the feeling of those is definitely different. In Soul Suspect we conduct our investigations with appropriate supernatural twist by correctly influencing possessed people, linking uncovered evidences or even accessing past memories lingering in the ghostly Salem. In turn Soul Suspects system feels much more simple, and dynamic in comparison to L.A. Noires ‘adjust and question’ model.

Leaving gameplay behind, the strongest point of the game is definitely its scenario. With perfectly written characters and interesting plot twists, Ronans crusade against Bell Killer will be a memorable experience appealing to every gamer. The locations inspired by some of the Salems most iconic buildings are recreated in a great detail, and greatly contributes to the games spooky atmosphere. The whole experience is polished by believable voice overs and sounds, with only minor flaw being games music which felt somehow nonexistent.

The only serious drawback of the game, is the large amount of collectibles, that makes even ‘Alan Wake’ blush in shame. It’s actually hard to move more than 5 ft without stumbling upon some new note, item or a graffiti flooding us with new information either related to our investigation or the Ronans past. All those stories are pretty well written, but the sheer number of those papers seriously affects immersion preventing us from fully diving into the games world.

Murdered: Soul Suspect is definitely worth getting and trying especially for its captivating story. The game is definitely a must have for every supernatural events enthusiast, shining brightly in comparison with other productions picking up this subject. And if after reading the above review You're still unconvinced, I'd like to tell You that in this game You can possess a cat, and fool around in its body!

Pros:
- Agitating suspense story with supernatural twist.
- Smooth controls with both mouse/keyboard and x-box controler.
- Lots of witty puzzles and logic investigations.
- Interesting ghost-powers affecting gameplay.
- Clever world design with parts of the past Salem overlying its modern streets.
- Really spooky side stories to unlock.
- Can possess a cat!

Cons:
- Game’s a bit short, with full play through taking about 8-9 hours.
- A high number of collectibles seriously affects immersion.
- Due to its nature game is linear.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Murdered: Soul Suspect
Original Release: 2014
Genre Tags: Adventure; Mystery; Third-Person; Detective
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-12 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers
REVIEWMurdered: Soul Suspect is a story-driven adventure game with a strong focus on collectibles and “detective” work, and very little action/combat.

You play in 3rd-person adventure style, progressing the story and moving throughout the game world from one spot to the next.  You collect clues and make deductions in the case you are working on in the primary story arc.  The game is pretty linear, which is to be expected for something so focused on story telling; but there is some freedom of exploration.  Much of the backstory and lore can be learned about through the extensive amount of collectibles scattered throughout the levels.

The graphics are pretty nice at max settings and the atmosphere of the game is fitting and done well.  The voice acting is among the best you will find in the realm of video games, which is important since the whole appeal of the game is the story.  It’s a pretty short game, perhaps medium-sized if you decide to get all the collectibles— but it is paced very well, and wraps up right around the time it starts to get stale.

There is really only one mechanic to the game, which is to move around and pick up clues or artifacts... and maybe use a few bland abilities here and there.  The combat is rare and one-dimensional and never evolves into anything more.  So it feels a lot like a show/movie where you control the main character.  To keep you busy, you can explore the levels to search for collectibles as you play through the campaign.

So in conclusion I would posit that I enjoyed my playthrough of this game.  It is pretty minimal in terms of gameplay mechanics; but if you are one who enjoys good story-driven games with atmosphere, and who enjoys collectibles in a 3rd-person adventure setting: then you will probably enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
This game starts untraditionaly, with your own death, but what's wierd you just get up as a ghost, told that you need to finish your things on earth to actually move on. You figure out that your purpose why you are still in the ghost world is finding out the killers identity. Last thing you remember is that you were called somewhere to the city centre where was spotted The Bell Killer, a serious killer who terrifies Salem in last weeks. Through the story you are finding out more about The Bell Killer murders with newly obtained abilities, like posses, read mind or influence someone. You are also finding out more about your main character detective Ronan with very difficult to understand past full of criminal records, and also about his dead wife Julia. Identity of your killer is unknown until the last minutes of the game, unfortunately its not that simple and just finding out the who actualy kills is not enought...During the gameplay you have also option to help some of the other ghosts to find peace using your detective skills which is a nice variegation of the game.

I really enjoyed this game, for me it is a game full of interesting stories and some detective elements. In some moments it reminded me of Batman Arkham series, where I was always checking every corner for collectibles and seeking everywhere to reveal and solve another mystery. You can find out some information about history of city of Salem which is known for the witch trials and few ghost stories and of course some of main character's past and thoughts of his wife.

I must admit the ending of the game really surprised me, you really need to play this game until the end to be satisfied. Nevertheless the last part of the game seems tacky, it hurt the game and I would appreciate longer and better ending cutscene.

7/10

reviewText:
I gotta admit, I did not expect this. This is a unique game to be honest, because it surprised me, a whole lot.
Imma do it like they all do, cus it's easier to understand reviews, so here:

PROS:
-An unique experience (for now)
There aren't many games with it's concept being you die and become a ghost solving your murder (not really a spoiler, because the title spoils it all then), and this one is from my perspective done exceptionally well.
-Voice Quality
I can't say this is the best voice quality I heard, but the voice is mixed and put together, doing its job of keeping you on your toes, really well.
-Graphics
For the graphics maniacs and the graphicsrexics this is a meet down the middle. For its scenery and location, the graphics fit really good, since it gives this dark, mysterious vibe with a dash of detectiveness.
-Story
Oh. I absolutely loved the story (I haven't finished it yet (at about 7,5 hrs right now) but I know I'll be too lazy to edit this review, but I know I'll love it, so y'know), and some moments in it are a really well done,unique, some other important adjective of a moment. It's what it is - great.
-Demons
Well, I wasn't really expecting them and I was scared sh*tless at first (still am at times ;D), but you get used to them. They offer a new type of enemy, but in an interesting form, making it something you probably won't see soon.
-Clues
These little sons'a'b*tches are tricky but fo' real entertaining and I think that with time I started enjoying myself, when I got the answers to various questions about, ''why this happened'', ''why that happened'' and them putting them together, reminds me of Sherlock Holmes in a way, yet unclear to me. Checking IGN guides on where stuff is also happens quite often (often being almost everytime).
-Collectibles
A lot of em. A lot. Which is good (?), but what's even better is, that at any time when you're in the town, you can go to various interiors (since collectibles are more or less spread out across interiors), and collect the ones you might've missed.

CONS:
-There aren't any cons

I enjoyed it, and the achievements make for some work, but you get the hang of it.
Also, when this first came out, I was oh-so-not interested in it, but after time (time being about a year later), it was on sale and I said ''why not''.
P.S I don't think I regret it.  (1murderedcop/10)

reviewText:
You play as Ronan, a freshly deceased cop who's trying to figure out his own murder. Because of this unfinished business, he gets stuck between hell and heaven, wandering in the world of living, invisible to the naked eye, only able to interact with human mediums. As you learn the ropes of this supernatural world, you start collecting clues and putting all the stuff together. The ending blew my mind, really. Some people may say it's too short for a fully priced title but I think the time was appropriate for the told story and filler missions would only ruin the ambience of certain urgency in the air. Perhaps this should have been something episodic, one murder story - one episode. But we all know that is not happening anytime soon.

Murdered: Soul Suspect has an awesome story and I enjoyed uncovering the case in L.A. Noire-ish style. Playing as a ghost? Very nice, not a common thing in games. Possesing people, reading minds, communicating with mediums? Sounds awesome, seems like these devs are taking the ghost business seriously. Being a murdered detective investigating his own murder? I'm sold.

These ideas are great but something went wrong and they were kind of poorly executed. My guess is the developers either got lazy and told the janitor to put together some pieces of the game because they were busy actually working on the main storyline and side quests that really got some love. Or they were rushed by the greedy publisher, what do I know. But some details are just like whatever. Details so strong in numbers that I couldn't just ignore them after a while. For example: Reading minds of the entire city - extremely few lines that keep repeating even between different people. Musicless, slow, unskippable credits. Overdesigned main protagonists while other models are just copy pasted - even in the story, totally destroys the overall pleasant graphics. Some controls are weird, whole main menu and press start" while using k+m. And a few more.

Even though I needed to vent my frustration with this game in here
date: it was mostly because of the lost game of the year potential. (For me) I still enjoyed it. There is nothing like it on the gaming market and I very much like originality. Mixed with amazing story makes a great
recommended: underdeveloped game. I feel bad to rate it 6
hoursPlayed: 9/10. I'd smack the people responsible for the lazy/rushed details."

reviewText:
8,5/10

+ nice presentation, although graphics are not next gen, the locations and character models are well done and the atmosphere is creepy as it should
+ runs great on highest settings
+ nice sound, excellent voice acting
+ dark, original story about you trying (as a ghost detective !) to catch a serial killer
+ gameplay wise it's more of an adventure game, with lots of exploration, tons of stuff to collect and notes to read, main progress is done by investigating scenes, that is finding clues and piece them together
+ fighting demons on your way by using stealth and then using qtes to kill them are the only action sequences that can be considered in the game (that's fine for me)
+ nice diary that tracks everything

- gameplay feels monotonous through the end, they could add some more gameplay mechanics to keep interest higher, but still you will want to finish it for the very good story
- technically it could use more polish

again the reviews for this game are very unfair, maybe it shouldn't be rated as high as i have done, but it's a genre i love (creepy adventure in heart games)

reviewText: I can't believe how much I liked this game, considering all the negative reviews it got. It's like some bizarre mix of Condemned, LA Noire, and Ghost Trick. The only combat you're exposed to are simple exorcisms, and the rest is investigation, story, and mystery. The only down side is that it doesn't run so well at times. Entering new areas make you lag & stutter on any setting I tried (and I spent about two hours combining different settings). If you can have a little patience while it chugs a bit in new areas, then you're in for a treat. I would have paid for this (won it in a contest), but I wouldn't have paid full price. Worth a grab if you see it discounted on g / 2 / a or greenman gaming, or even on steam if they get it £15 or lower. This is a really, really good game.

reviewText:
Murdered :Soul Suspect is a refreshing new concept for a game and it sure does deserve a metascore of more than 60 % .

Gameplay  7/10

Yes there is no real combat system , no hordes of various enemies , no grenade launcher  , none of that .
But it was never meant to be a Resident Evil clone , it's more like a playable thriller /detective movie . You play a ghost ( Ronan O' Connor ) who must  who must solve the mystery of his own death and you have ghost like abilities , like mind reading , warping and you can possess humans and animals . Also you can collect various artifacts to uncover the city of Salem's dark secrets or uncover the backstory of the main character e.g.
Finished the game in around 12 hours, so it's best to say it's kinda short .

Story 8/10
Very unique and with a little twist in the end , like a good thriller .I won't go into detail , because this would surely spoil the story .

Music  7/10
Okay , nothing spectacular . Just good background music and noise .
Voice acting is okay too.

Graphics 7 /10

The graphics are kinda outdated . They look more like  PS 4 /Sbox 360 . Character models are not very varied . You got like 4 different ones , only the main protagonist and important side characters are unique.

Definetely a must buy if it's on sale .

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed  Murdered: Soul Suspect. Let me start by saying if you are looking for action, adventure, and shooting in a run and gun style look elsewhere (You don't shoot a gun at all, not even once). If you are looking for a solid game with a great storyline, reading, thinking, and a great mystery plot that keeps you guessing look here.

Is the game scary? No I would not say it is scary, maybe creepy or atmospheric. The Dev does a good job of making you feel and realize that you are not among the living. There is the occassional disappearing ghosts and scary music but nothing like silent hill, dead space, or amnesia. The point of the game is not to scare or freak you out. It's to tell a great story and for you to solve a mystery.

On top of figuring out your own mystery there are about 6-10 little side quests if you will. None are very long, but they are each enjoyable and have a little story of their own. There are also hundreds of little collectables to find and to keep you busy. I am not usually a fan of finding and hunting for hidden objects; but for some reason in this game it does not seem to tedious or difficult. The style of game just seems to lend itself towards finding lost or hidden items.

All that being said I would recommend this game overall score 8/10. I picked it up at 75% off and am not disapointed. I think for me even %50 off would justify the purchase. If it's on sale and you are a story driven gamer I would strongly urge you to pick this one up at some point.

Oh and if that's not convincing enough did I mention you have the ability to posses cats, and you have a never ending cigarette?! Yup see I knew that would help you make the right decision!

reviewText:
Inspired by 1996 classic The Frighteners, Murdered fails to provide Michael J. Fox's film main value - FUN.
Technically and visually the game is smooth and pleasant and if you're not planning on getting every collectable, you probably won't notice it's flaws. The gameplay is ridiculously easy and sometimes even silly. The puzzles where patronising and never prompted me to think.
The mediocre story of the game is very well presented and can even surprise with the ending some unspoiled player. But everything in it, especially characters, is so cliche, that I wouldn't recommend the game to people familiar with the Peter Jackson's gem.
Despite everything, I tremendously enjoyed possessing cats.

reviewText:
Ronan is a criminal-turned-cop who is killed by the mysterious Bell Killer. Playing as Ronan's ghost, investigate a series of crime scenes (sometimes with the help of teenage medium Joy), searching for identity of the killer. Many supernatural elements come into play – ghosts, witches, demons – and some flashbacks of the witch trials are pretty gruesome (drowning, burning, hanging).

As the investigation progresses, you'll explore a graveyard, an apartment house, an old mansion, a police station and of course the obligatory asylum level. While the game world is small, it is open, with the ability to just wander around the town of Salem. It's a gloomy place – the game occurs entirely at night – but is well-dotted with NPCs and collectibles. Obtaining collectibles can unlock other stories (usually brief, narrated cut-scenes), and some NPCs will provide side-missions. There's a decent amount of stuff to do, but most collectibles were easily found as I explored the town or a level.

Investigations require exploring a a crime scene, finding evidence (“Press E to analyze”) and sorting through the collected evidence (“Press Q to conclude the investigation”). Walking (or later, teleporting) around as a ghost feels fun; Ronan can walk through walls, possess people (mind-reading), and turn on random stuff to mess with the townsfolk (poltergeisting). Especially cool were the impenetrable “ghost walls” from past times that can block Ronan from exploring – or even provide new hazards (watch out for the ghost train!). Oh, and you can possess cats, too. This is actually crucial to progress through several stages of the game.

The demon sections, though, dragged the experience down a bit. Demons will sometimes spawn after completing an investigation. Their existence does have a crucial part to play, and they're easy enough to defeat with a little patience. Given that this is a supernatural tale, it would be rather weird if demons of some kind weren't in the game, and having some stealth sections added some variety to the gameplay. But after a while the demons became annoying distractions from the story.

And the narrative is where Murdered: Soul Suspect stands strongest. There is a lot of backstory to be found about Ronan and his wife (via collectibles). Sometimes collectibles are merely annoying, but they are worth pursuing here. Jason Brooks (as Ronan) and Cassidy Lehrman (as the medium, Joy) provide stand-out vocal performances. The graphics (Unreal 3) are great – murky and dark. Jason Graves' score provides a classic horror-story undertone. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a well-crafted detective game with a few quirks that holds its story aloft as its best attribute. If that sounds good to you, then go ahead and get this one.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-hZlWbvWC2M

Remember those God awful Nancy Drew Detective games that were sold in the bargain bins at Best Buy and Walmart?...Well swap out adorable Nancy with a buff, gritty, tattoo covered, cop and you have Murdered: Soul Suspect.

The game puts you in the shoes of a recently deceased detective who becomes trapped on earth as a ghost until he can track down his murderer and solve his own case. While the general idea of the game sounds very interesting, the gameplay doesn’t hold up strongly enough to back this promising premise.

The game offers fairly solid visuals; they aren’t anything that will knock your socks off but they get the job done and provide an immersive, bone chilling, spooky experience. The game is fittingly set in Salem Massachusetts, but you won’t be exploring much of the town, as the game is designed to give you the false sense of free roam when it is in fact painfully linear. The game has a fairly expanse world, however due to the ghostly limitations the game places on you, you are unable to enter any buildings unless the door or window is already opened for you. This leads to the game being extremely linear, with what appears to be a vast explorable world turns out to be an empty ghost town in and of itself.
The core gameplay mechanics consists of incredibly disappointing “Detective Work”. Detective work is conducted by entering the crime scene (which usually consist of about 3 fairly small rooms) and meandering about the room pressing the interact key on all the shiny clues that are sprinkled throughout the crime scenes. The game requires that you find a painstaking amount of these clues for each question and at some points you may find yourself spamming the interact key repeatedly hoping you will blindly click on the last elusive clue that you need to proceed, imagine it as the Easter egg hunt from hell. The game does introduce some fairly interesting puzzle mechanics on certain clues, such as word association deciphers where you are presented with an image and around 15 words and have to pick the 3 or 4 words that are most related to the image to crack the clue, however these interesting tidbits are never truly fleshed out to their true potential.

Don’t go into this game expecting any form of combat whatsoever, the combat is almost nonexistent and consists of walking behind the demonic enemies and performing a series of simple quick time events to eliminate them. The demons themselves look genuinely terrifying and if you do happen to mess up the quick time event then you will be chased by the demon and have to escape by quickly transporting through preplaced ghostly rifts that allow you to hide until the demon gives up on searching for you.

The only thing this game really has going for it that makes it worth playing is the intriguing, twist filled story. The stories pacing is done very well and at times you almost wish Murdered: Soul Suspect was a movie rather than a game. The voice acting is pretty solid and one of the best aspects of the game; being such a story driven game it benefits greatly from making sure that it has some good quality voice acting. While there are many cut scenes, they are enjoyable and emotion filled. It’s just a shame that the rest of the game feels like such a grinding chore just to get to the next cut scene to watch the story unfold.

Overall Murdered: Soul Suspect seems like it has so much potential but never truly takes advantage of anything that it has going for it. The game holds your hand through a painfully linear environment and offers absolutely no challenge or difficulty. The only thing that makes Murdered: Soul Suspect even remotely worth playing is the fairly enjoyable story delivered through the cut scenes. The game plays out like a very good movie with obnoxious, tedious, burdensome, gameplay in between. What seemed like a very promising premise wasn’t strongly supported enough by the overall weak puzzles and lack of difficulty.

I would only recommend this game if you get it at a ridiculous sale price

http://noobsthatplaygames.com/

reviewText: A good game that falls short of being great because of a linear story line and lack of content. Starting off interesting enough, Ronan goes through the process of dying, which is a surreal experience but the game quickly becomes stale after the basics are covered and it actually stays boring until around mid to late game. The story seems to slowly string you along and the reason you continue is because you're interested in finding the culprit. Various unrelated background stories are discovered through collectibles scattered around Salem and are worth checking into if you enjoy a little treat to break you off from the main story for a bit. Sure, it does get frustrating at times because dealing with the demons becomes tedious after the first few tries but you'll come to a point where you'll realize it's worth the patience so you can finally get to the end and solve this giant mystery. Murdered may not live up to its hype but that doesn't prevent it from being an enjoyable game.
