reviewText:
Well, nearly made myself to finish it. This one started as a promising story-driven atmospheric paranormal detective about ghosts and investigation of death of your own character while actually being a ghost: walking through walls, spy on citizens, possess them and read their minds, do stuff in yout favor, collect evidence and make conclusions... Yeah, very promising. And this all also wrapped with pretty good graphics with good visual art and detail, good score and voice acting. As a fan of atmospheric story-driven games I was really looking forward to Murdered: Soul Suspect. And at the beginning it was good. But it failed for me eventually.

The catch? - Dull story and mainly boring and repetitive gameplay.

The story had a good potential but authors were unable to pull it off. Eventually it slipped to so trivial and dull finale, that I began to regret for my wasted time. Authors tried to fill it with the notes of Salem's history, Ronan's personal story and love tragedy, but it didn't worked, something was missing and the main story felt... shallow. The ending of the game is plain ridiculous both gameplay- and storywise.

Throughout the game there is almost no progression in gameplay: after you learned how to discover things, collect evidence, solve the case, possess people, counteract the opponents - you'll do it till the end with almost no diversity or new meaningful mechanics. The investigation part is very dull and making conclusions is not particularly interesting - especially when doing it dozen of times.

I know this might look silly to blame a story-driven game for lack of gameplay (it's not Dear Esther though), but we're talking about the game with also sort of 'open' locations for your discovery, where you can freely go and explore it, solve some side-quests (they are also trivial and repetitive). On the contrary, I never got bored in story-driven Spec Ops: The Line, even though it's mere third-person shooter, because of its constant progression in fascinating story, locations design, changing circumstances, obstacles and gameplay.

In Murdered, besides that you can wonder around the locations doing side-quests, looking for collectibles (fun at first, become boring and useless later) or navigating your way from point A to B there are a lot of times during the second half of the game when you forced to revisit old locations and more often than not run through it from one end to another.

The locations themselves are not very distinctive and did I mention you can't run through every wall? At first that part with looking your way through the labyrinth of real and paranormal walls was OK, but quickly faded since they all looks the same, same blurred bluish corridors all the time. This is an unnecessary protraction of the game - you simply getting bored and 'felling off' the game's reality and story.

The enemies? Man, I wished that part of the game's 'features' never ended up in final version. It's just wrong, unnecessary, badly designed gameplaywise, and... oh, that console port QTEs... Quickly press W+RMB / D+LMB... etc.

No, I don't recommend this game, because I don't want more games of such quality of game design.

reviewText:
I don't know how this game has so many people liking it.

It's nothing like LA Noire, everything in this game is a forced QTE, the stealth parts where you take out the demons are awful and feel out of place, and the game is just all around boring.

In LA Noire, I felt like I was actually solving crimes and interacting with the evidence and finding out who had done the deed. In this game, it's all done for you. All you have to do is press E and it will go to some cinematic crap and just put it down in your ghost journal which will fill up with crap you will never care about and utterly just be a cluttered mess of writings about stuff not pertaining to the fedora man at all.

The console port is just awful, it's so hard to control the UI and the camera when hiding from the demons will ♥♥♥♥ you up and utterly get you killed, and oh god, the demon fighting is just horrible, absolutely horrible.

1/10 for fedoras

Please, do yourself a favor and save your fifty dollars.

reviewText:
7/10.   If you enjoy story driven games, this game is a good fit.  A well fleshed out storyline with excellent voice acting, cinematics, and live action gameplay.  I didn't find any silly time wasting quests or non-sensical gameplay at all.
I had no idea what the gameplay would involve, and it's an interesting mix.  You are a detective who becomes a ghost and needs to find out who killed you and why. So, lots of investigations.  To me, the investigative parts of the game are most like a hidden object game.  You walk around a small area and find the clues to solve the inquiry.  Very straightforward.  There is a bit of action involved with demons to dispose of. You play stealthy while sneaking up on them.  Later in the game, it gets more intense with up to 4 demons simultaneously and can be a little challenging to sneak up on.
There are clues, letters, special bad guy info bits, historical parts, human mind reading, and some side quests too.  I didn't enjoy these as much.  They just aren't interesting and add little to the game story.  Mostly, the human mind reading gets boring to the point where I stopped bothering to read minds one third of the way through the game.  There are also ghost stories to unlock.  Some are good, some are so-so.  I liked the asylum one best.  Those are optional and require going through the rooms quite a bit more to search out hidden unlockables.  If anything was time wasting, that was it.  But, it's not mandatory.
To me, the story dragged up until about halfway.  After the cemetery I was hooked and kept on playing without any lack of interest. Before then, I was getting a bit bored, so slow gameplay and story up until midway.
Two things that stood out to me that may interest others:
1) It's not an adventure game.  Don't go in expecting an adventure game of any kind.  This wasn't clear to me from the onset until I had been playing a bit.
2) If you like action or fast paced horror games, this may not be for you.  This game is laid back, not terribly scary, and takes it's time.  More for the detective story fans IMO and fans of hidden secrets.
The ending is good and don't watch a vid of it please or it really ruins the experience.  If the initial half of the game wasn't so slow and a bit scarier, I would probably rate it higher. Still a good game, lots of love went into it, and it's optimized very well too.

reviewText:
I will try to make this review as short as possible, and list a few pros and cons.

You play as Ronan O'Connor, an ex-convict that found love and got married to a police officers sister, Julia. Which got his reputation cleared  criminal records hidden  and allowed him to be accepted into law enforcement. Shortly after Ronan marries Julia, she attempts to stop an argument between two men that didn't end too well, she got stabbed by one and dies in Ronan's arms. Shortly after Ronan loses his cool and basically turns into Batman.  He goes in alone and tries to stop the Bell Killer, but is quickly over powered, thrown out of a window, then shot seven times.  now you are now stuck in limbo and have to find out whom killed you before you can go into the vast world beyond. This is where your story begins.

Pros. Great voice acting, almost no loading screens (I only got 3 during my whole play through.), a great cinematic story (7 hours of gameplay for most users), a very pretty game. Graphics don't always matter, but I still have to throw this in.

Cons. Almost no real fighting in this game.  The Demons are too easy. , very linear story, little to no replay value, cliffhanger ending. I never liked them.

TLDR. It's a great game, if you like playing a cinematic story. The $20 price tag may actually be worth it, but I always go for game when they are on sale or in a bundle. Got this little gem in Humble Bundle myself.

reviewText:
Firstly, I have to say that this game has a great story and is the most unique one I’ve played in a long time.I never played a game where you play a ghost and the protagonist is dead from the begginging. The primary goal of him is to find his murderer and be released from his ghostly form.

Secondly, the setting is pretty believable and rich in detail. There are so much innovative things I only can scratch the survface of it in my review:

The trains of thought to find out the truth are pretty great depicted: There are a bunch of clues which you have to find and then you have to find the link between them by clicking the most important one or figure out the right order of events. Only game of this type I played was The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.
You can posses people and read or influence their minds to get clues.
You can posses cats (This is pretty cool) and climb/jump around in trees.
The atmosphere is pretty dense and unique.
Outstanding voice acting!!!!
Great story telling (This is no action game!).
The only action element of this game is that you get hunted by demons. This is sometime kind of intense but nothing extreme scaring
The only thing which spoils this game a bit are the darn bad technics of this game. You notice every second of playing that it’s a console porting. You can’t change the assignment of keys. For that’s unacceptable: sprinting on shift..WTF?! Another thing which bothered me is hat you can‘t disable 30 FPS lock with V-Sync enabled. So it’s either tearing" or no FPS over 30! reviewText:
Despite an interesting premise and a promising start, Soul Suspect suffers from some significant problems.

The game is good at setting an atmosphere and the lead characters background is interesting - if a little hard to belive.

It struggles, however, when trying to be a computer game.  The puzzles are interesting, but their internal logic is inconsistant - you end up having to think like the designer.  Unfortunately, it's obvious that each of the puzzles had a different writer each time, meaning that every time you approach a problem it's sometimes hard to know what it is that is being asked of you.  This is a problem as the game has a rating system that punishes you if any mistakes are made.  The punishment is only the loss of a points on a system that doesnt seem to have any real bearing upon the game at large, but it is irritating to feel that failure is more due to an inconsistant mechanic than a mistake.

The worst aspect of the game is undoubtably the action sequences involving the hunting or avoiding of deadly shades, trapped between the our world and the next.  Sound intersting? In practice, it's not.
Unfortunately, these sections feel rushed; a knee-jerk attempt at introducing some action into the otherwise slow pace of the game.
Not a bad idea in principle, but the problem is that these fights vary little from the start of the game to the end.
The shades don't do anything other than follow very short, pre-set paths which occasionaly pass something that may be used to distract them.  The challenge" comes from the fact that as the game progresses increasing numbers are put in your path - not exactly imaginative. Mistakes result in dashing about trying to hide from the shades that hunt you more aggressively
date: which would make these sequences more exiting
recommended: execpt that some areas seem to lack an appropriate number of places to hide.  This leads to you dashing between the few available
hoursPlayed: never quite caught but still unable to shake the shades off.  In the end it becomes nessecery to let the shades catch you

I am recommending this game as I personally like it. I will give my reader a huge WARNING before purchasing : the game play isn't super immerse, it's more the genre of the game. The controls/abilities are a bit limited. The game itself, however is comparable to a beautiful painting.

Murdered : Soul Suspect follows a detective who was pushed out of a window and then shot repeatedly as he was trying to get up. The (bell tower) killer is an unknown assailant who has been attacking random individuals. After being shot, the detective is now a ghost and has to figure out why he's still roaming the Earth and hasn't passed on.

You are in third person view of Ronan (the detective) and have identical controls/movements (not actions though) to Hitman Absolution. What is probably the most outstanding feature in the game is the fact you can walk through walls. Of course, you cannot walk through any wall you wish. This will be made obvious with a solid white fill on a few walls or other ghostly" objects will appear that will not let you pass. None the less
date: something completely different I have never been able to do in any game I've played yet. The combat is quite minimal. I should add if you are looking for a cop fighting action game

reviewText:
Oh dear, I'm dead - pretty much the main mechanic of the game.  MURDERED: Soul Suspect starts out with the death of the main character who goes by the name of Ronan, a local Detective investigating a murder. It's not the most unique premise out there, but it handles it in such a way that makes it intriguing, but can ultimately fall a little short thanks to the way the game itself is structured.

A Clean Cut Ghost
While Ronan and the other main characters look pretty good and the environments themselves look pretty top notch, I can't really say the same for the NPCs. I noticed they re used qutite a LOT of NPCs without as much as trying to hide it somehow, which can definately break the immersion this game tries to set in with it's dark and drab setting. The lighting is top notch also, and really helps give the game the sense that you're in some ghostly world in an already dark setting.

The environments, as stated above, look very nice and I really like how they themselves tell their own stories because of the way the game places just random objects in an area. You can have, for example, a train inside a museum to let the player know that in the past, where the museum stands now used to be a regularly used train track and the game's chock full of little things like that, as well as it uses flat and ghostly images that sorta just fade out as you get closer to them to help accentuate that you are indeed in a ghost world. It's really good.

Even greatly influencing the atmosphere the game has, is it's sound design. You can occasionally hear ghostly wails in the backgrounds, and the game is very light on music, only really playing it during tense moments like when there are Demons around, it knows when and when not to play music and it handles it pretty well. Voice acting is pretty par for the course, Ronan and the main characters sound decent, but some of the VA's for the NPCs can be pretty hit or miss.

Solving the Case
Murdered: Soul Suspect  is pretty much a glorified adventure game. The very linear structure the game has is done to help accentuate the story, making it feel actually more like a 3D Visual Novel than an Adventure game. The game is pretty much divided up by stage" sections and an overworld (The Town). Each "Stage" has it's own set of collectibles that
recommended: gives you insight into a usually very dark and grim backstory into those items you collect as well as having it's own story section and more in general collectibles.\n\nWhat can feel detrimental to the game's pacing
hoursPlayed: is the way each stage is handled. It always ends up being a straight up Move from Point A to Point B sort of ordeal while exploring through every nook and cranny to find collectibles.\n\nAs far as mechanics go

reviewText: Classic case of good idea, bad implementation. I found several glitches on my first playthrough, most were graphical, but one where it was a bit stupid. There were several instances of objects(both real, physical objects) were clipping together. At one point part of the storyline is hindered by a locked door, however you can simply pass through the wall and open it while the NPC still believes the door to be locked with their hands inside the door's model trying to get it open. Many issues also exist with the port to PC. I'll be honest, I am a PC gamer and haven't played this game on console, however I expect game ports to be decent. On numerous occations I found myself in one of the game's many menus and interfaces with my mouse unable to correctly interact with said menus, I then had to go keyboard-only with the arrow keys to navigate and exit the menus. Character animation is also a bit sub-par, especially when characters are talking. Unfortunately all of the bugs and glitches I've noticed could have been fixed with patches yet have not been.\n\nIf you insist on playing this game I highly recommend a gamepad.

reviewText:
Ronan is a criminal-turned-cop who is killed by the mysterious Bell Killer. Playing as Ronan's ghost, investigate a series of crime scenes (sometimes with the help of teenage medium Joy), searching for identity of the killer. Many supernatural elements come into play – ghosts, witches, demons – and some  flashbacks of the witch trials are pretty gruesome (drowning, burning, hanging).

As the investigation progresses, you'll explore a graveyard, an apartment house, an old mansion, a police station and of course the obligatory asylum level. While the game world is small, it is open, with the ability to just wander around the town of Salem. It's a gloomy place – the game occurs entirely at night – but is well-dotted with NPCs and collectibles. Obtaining collectibles can unlock other stories (usually brief, narrated cut-scenes), and some NPCs will provide side-missions. There's a decent amount of stuff to do, but most collectibles were easily found as I explored the town or a level.

Investigations require exploring a a crime scene, finding evidence (“Press E to analyze”) and sorting through the collected evidence (“Press Q to conclude the investigation”). Walking (or later, teleporting) around as a ghost feels fun;  Ronan can walk through walls, possess people (mind-reading), and turn on random stuff to mess with the townsfolk (poltergeisting). Especially cool were the impenetrable “ghost walls” from past times that can block Ronan from exploring – or even provide new hazards (watch out for the ghost train!). Oh, and you can possess cats, too. This is actually crucial to progress through several stages of the game.

The demon sections, though, dragged the experience down a bit. Demons will sometimes spawn after completing an investigation. Their existence does have a crucial part to play, and they're easy enough to defeat with a little patience. Given that this is a supernatural tale, it would be rather weird if demons of some kind weren't in the game, and having some stealth sections added some variety to the gameplay.  But after a while the demons became annoying distractions from the story.

And the narrative is where Murdered: Soul Suspect stands strongest. There is a lot of backstory to be found about Ronan and his wife (via collectibles). Sometimes collectibles are merely annoying, but they are worth pursuing here. Jason Brooks (as Ronan) and Cassidy Lehrman (as the medium, Joy) provide stand-out vocal performances. The graphics (Unreal 3) are great – murky and dark. Jason Graves' score provides a classic horror-story undertone. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a well-crafted detective game with a few quirks that holds its story aloft as its best attribute. If that sounds good to you, then go ahead and get this one.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
7.5/10
Overview: Adventure

Watch the movie Ghost, replace Patrick Swayze with an ex criminal cop and replace Whoopi Goldberg with a teenager, throw in some supernatural elements and you have the basic foundation for Murdered Soul Suspect.

The gameplay is a mixture between investigating areas for evidence and stealth sections. Investigating areas is basic, you walk around until you get to item/object you can interact with. A few times you are given a list of clues and must select the right clues in order to advance, as far as I can tell there is no way you can fail any of these. No matter how many times you get it wrong the game will always let you keep choosing until you get it right. As a dead man you have a few tricks which you can use, such as possessing people to influence them or causing disturbances in the environment to distract people.

The second portion of gameplay involves stealth which can be a bit frustrating at times but it does help break up the gameplay a bit. Every once in a while you will have to hide from demons, luckily, if they see you, you can easily run and hide in hiding spots until they decide to stop searching for you. Sneaking up from behind and pressing the appropriate buttons will kill them.

The game is also littered with collectables that give back-story to characters or provide history of the surrounding locations.

There are a few side quests but they are very basic and amount to nothing more than investigating an area until you found everything.

This is not an action game. If you enjoy point and click adventure games you will find this somewhat enjoyable. The problem is this game offers very little puzzle solving and the entire game can be completed in 4-6 hours. I do however commend Square Enix for publishing a game like this.

reviewText:
The game is good, worth a shot, but still hardly worth the full price considering that the main story can be completed in about 7 hours. Yeah, there are side quests, but there's little motivation for anyone to waste time trying to complete them, except maybe for achievement hunters, since they're not connected to the main story too closely. Since the combat, the action part of the gameplay is very simplistic (just attack the enemy from behind and press some key combinations), the exploration part could've saved the day if it weren't just as simplistic as well.

Anyway, if you're like me and care more for a good story than sophisticated gameplay, Murdered: Soul Suspect will be a nice experience.

Pros:
- the story is complex and captivating, the ending is pretty unexpected
- the visuals are nice
- good voice acting
- interesting characters
- nice noir/dark atmosphere
- interesting basic concept (some kind of walking dead" but not the "usual" kind of "walking deads" :)  you die right in the start and then just play as a ghost  )

Cons:
- kinda short
- the gameplay is quite simplistic
date: in terms of both fighting and exploring\n- there's only one type of enemy to fight\n- horror is hardly a good keyword to describe it
recommended: there's pretty much nothing scary about it\n- the full price doesn't seem very reasonable considering the gameplay's length"

reviewText:
Despite having its flaws, Murdered: Soul Suspect is quite possibly one of the most enjoyable single-player games I've played this year.

The Pros:
· A unique story that feels like a combination of Silent Hill and L.A. Noire, and the beginning does a great job of introducing you to its atmosphere.
· You start at the point where Ronan O'Connor (the game's protagonist, of course) starts the hunt on his murderer, the Bell Killer. This makes you feel like you know as much about the afterlife as Ronan himself does and creates a sort of connection, right from the get-go.
· The town of Salem is pretty small, but its yours to explore... and it's worth exploring. Tons of side missions and collectibles can be found in Salem, and the eerie mood that constantly lingers around really immerses you into Ronan's role.
· The atmosphere is incredibly unique and satisfying. The ghostly white glow around certain object make the bridge-world connect with the world of the living. Seeing the flickering souls of dead children sitting next to a swing or a dead corpse dangling from a tree by its neck is oddly disturbing and makes you feel uncomfortable, which a bridge-world should.
· Pretty cool characters. Ronan is your typical rebel-turned-cop tough guy, but his tattoo's reflect his life and the sins in it, and the detail to him is quite impressive. Even though he's partially see-through (because you know, he's a ghost and stuff), the orange bullet holes give Ronan a distinctive look from the other ghosts in Salem.

The Cons:
· The mechanics feel a bit underused at times. As a ghost you could be able to do so much more, like possessing and controlling others for example. Sure, you can influence people and read their minds and control a cat (10/10), but it limits the player.
· For a detective game, it doesn't really require too much thinking. You have to find clues and connect the dots (sometimes those dots connect in an unlogical way), and that's basically it.
· The NPCs are mostly the same. Salem doesn't have many people walking its streets, but two of the same people might be sitting a few feet from each other. Plus, they have the same thoughts, which is weird. Like freaky weird.
· The combat is there, but its simplistic and repetetive. You hide in lost souls, sneak up to a demon and quickly rip him apart. It's satisfying and it even feels as if you're helping those tormented souls, but it's just too much of the same.

The Visuals:
· Most of its atmosphere comes from the visuals. Ghostly white silhouettes and detailed environments may not look next-gen, but they're stunning none the less.

Final Verdict:
· Murdered: Soul Suspect sure has its flaws, but it's a unique and highly enjoyable experience and easily one of my favorites of the year. 8/10

reviewText:
I will premise this by saying that I have beaten the game and have all of the achievements completed.

The metascore has you doubting, doesn't it? Well, don't let it. This game has some good and some bad, but the good wins in the end.

First thing's first. Play this with a controller. I started this game with my keyboard/mouse and I immediately hated this game. The controls are a joke. The FOV is WAY too sensitive (even after changing settings). I was almost ready to give up on this game when I decided to try my Xbox controller. This choice saved the game for me.

The Bad
- Crappy save system. You can browse the discussion boards and find people have issues with the autosave. You can't make your own save and have to rely on it... trouble is, it's not that reliable. (you can however copy the save file from your steam folder. You have to look up how though. I think it's titled 233290. So it's a random number, not a name)

- Limited action. This game is a walk around and talk to people and find clues game. There is only one type of monster (demon) and you have to sneak up behind him to banish him. So it's all about timing. I think there are probably less than 20 of them in this entire game.

- Collectables. There are a lot of clues to find. Some are necessary, some aren't. The necessary ones will be located in a limited area, so you can eventually find them. The other collectables are scattered around and you have to find them. This is going to either be great because you love these kinds of things or frustrating because some of them are hard to find. Each one tells a little bit more about the story and it's characters.

The Good
- Cutscenes. There are a lot of them, and I found them to be good. I know some folks hate games with lots of cutscenes. If that's you, look elsewhere.

- Story. I really enjoyed the story. It's a dark mystery that you just can't help but want to solve. I felt the characters were engaging. They felt real and their struggles were believable.

- Easy achievements. You will get most of the achievements without trying. There are some for collections too. Those ones I used a video walkthrough to help me find them all.

- Simple investigations. So your job is to get clues and solve a mystery. This isn't the kind of game where the answer makes little sense. You collect as many clues as you can find and pick the answers based on them. You can solve a mystery without finding all the clues, but I recommend you find them all.

- Time. This game didn't take long to complete and to get all of the achievements.

Overall, I would recommend adding this to your wishlist. It's a really good game as long as you know what you are getting into. If you want an action packed game, this isn't for you. If you want to sit back, relax, and listen to a really cool story -- this game will be perfect.

reviewText:
Just finished the game.  My thoughts are as follows:

GOOD:

Unique concept with some cool abilities - passing through walls, posession and teleportation
TONS of collectibles reveal more of the characters' backgrounds as well as history of the city
Decent voice acting, characters with believable motivations
Interesing blend of spirit world into the material world.  Ghosts are a nice touch, add to atmosphere
Educational - I learned a lot about Salem and its history and locations - and enjoyed learning it (gasp!)

BAD:

Repetitive
Easy - no difficulty setting, no incentive to replay
Graphics are.... meh.  I know it's nighttime, but expect LOTS of grays, browns, and fog
DEMONS! Not scary, not difficult, just.... annoying.
Fairly short.  Took me longer because I was hunting down collectibles, but expect much shorter completion times
if you're just following the story

UGLY:

FOR GAWDS SAKE!  Would it have hurt to include an in-game map???

So.  I liked the game, yet I can't help but feel it doesn't really live up to its potential.  Although there are some cool/unique or original mechanics, they are rare little glimmers in an overall sea of....meh.  By a small margin, I DO recommend it, but only some time down the road when it goes on sale, or as a rental (if you own a console).

7/10

reviewText:
I don't know why the Metascore is so low, this game definitely deserves better. I have seen good metascore on games that sucked and vice versa such as in this case. And so obviously, Metascore is not a thing to be trusted.

As for the game, this was a really good and intriguing game. The things you find such as books or side stories which have lots of text to read to follow up but you can skip on it, this is one of those games that made me want to read every bit of text i found. The back stories for characters were really good, the plot is fine and unique, the animation and the artstyle is spot on. The voice acting for all the characters is damn great. This was like an adventure game following a story with no action or shooting as one might maybe expect. A game with story and interaction that not even for a moment felt boring or made me want to rush through and end this.

The gameplay in this consists of looking for clues and collectibles and evading demons at times while in the story, you're chasing your own killer trying to solve your own mystery from one place to another. This is a free roaming game and gives you the liberty to roam around the Salem city which is filled with collectibles and cats and other spirits whom you can help and set them free by solving their deaths.

As for my recommendation, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone even mildly interested in this. This game might not appeal to everyone, certainly not to ones looking for an action/shooter. 7/10.

reviewText:
Loved, loved, loved the game... You run around solving different aspects of a serial killers murders, and along the way you collect items, for little side stories, on your own account... Sometimes it is not always obvious, how to solve some of the problems, but for the most part, if you follow the story and read the clues, it's quite logical... One part, I was not too fond of, myself, was the demons you have to fight... Mostly because I panic, and press the wrong buttons, and then I have to do the whole thing all over again... And cause they freak me out!
I'm a panicky person, so the whole fighting/stressful aspect of that did not really tickle my fancy...
The map you're running around on, is not that big, to be honest, but because you can run through walls, and into every little nook and cranny, the world just seems so much bigger... And of course there are the cats, that also helps make it bigger... (When you play it, it will make sense)
Story wise, it was a good story... Sometimes a little predictable, but when it was important, it wasn't... Or maybe my story predicting skills failed me for once...
In all accounts... Great game... I loved it...

reviewText: This is a game that needs to be approached with the right mindset in order to be fully and properly understood. Murdered is an interactive movie with a story straight out of the best 90's b-reel supernatural horror flicks that dominated the video store of an era long bygone. The challenge level is extremely low but the mood and nighttime atmosphere the game evokes are hard to deny. Destined for Steam Sale must-buy status, Murdered is a game that will engage you and take you back to a simpler time, even as it celebrates its b-movie heritage and paper-thin actual gameplay.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is an Action (Hide & Seek?) Adventure RPG game set up in modern Salem.

You are Ronan O’Connor, a badass detective chasing the infamous Bell Killer, but when you find him, seems he was more than you could chew, so you end up dead, finally you can rest in peace... Or so you thought, until you realize, you're now a ghost that can't move on, because of some unfinished business, but, what could that be? You can only think on finishing your last case, so you start tracking down your killer, now that you're a ghost, how hard could that be?

Do note, real men don't need a map. But nobody is going to look down on you if you use a guide.

★★★☆☆ | It was OK

reviewText:
This was a very good game. I didn't know what to expect, but I enjoyed the story.

Graphics were good. There are some low res textures here and there, but overall I'm happy.

Voice acting was superb imo, both main characters were well done.

There were plenty of collectibles scattered, gave me stuff to do and look for. The story itself isn't that long, but the added collectibles did add to the playtime and back story.

Very simple gameplay. Killing demons was okay, seemed out of place though. Finding clues sometimes became annoying.

In regards to the final boss fight, it was more annoying than anything. I didn't expect anything grand, but meh.

Not sure if it's worth $30, I got about 10 hours of solid playtime. But a good purchase.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect developers have implemented completely new type of investigation games. 'What is it about?', you may ask, so the answer is below:

You are local of Salem, Massachusetts, the place which is mostly associated with XVII-century's history about witches, that people were hunting at and then, after catching them, they were burned at the stake. In game, there is mystical climat exposing supernatural skills of Ronan O'Connor, the main character, who had been killed at the beginning of the game and then he transformed to a ghost, who had to face demons, solve a mystery of his death and find out, who had killed him. Ronan, while getting the 'new himself', gets new skills, which allow him to move through the walls, be invisible to people, read in people's minds and even control them! During investigation he meets some demons hunting for souls, so he needs to eliminate them, or move around the place to get safer way.

The game reminds me of L.A. Noire, because you need to solve problems by getting some details and then connecting them into one, making sense trace. If you complete it successfully, you'll see what happened before.

Graphic effects are nice, the gameplay is happening during the twilight, so colours are darky, but they keep you even closer, because of usage them in thrilling details around. The Unreal Engine 3 is helping the game to get high details of buildings, models and characters, as well as good animations. The last thing I want to mention about is sound - thrilling music showing overwhelming atmosphere of Salem and live comments of O'Connor's adventures, which lead us to equating with Ronan even more.

Murdered: Soul Suspect and its story completely touched my heartstrings and that's one of the reasons, why my note is very high! Great compilation of story, graphics and sound is forcing me to put 10/10.

Hope you enjoy!

reviewText:
I got this game when it was 1st released, completed it and then didn't play it for nearly 2 years.. Until now, on my second play through I really enjoyed it.. Again.

As people have said the puzzles aren't difficult but I think that's the point, you search the crime scene for clues and then piece them together, plus there's no punishment for getting them wrong either, you can just try again, so it just makes a good casual play through.

The developers did a very good job with this game, I was hoping for a second, but I doubt that will happen now, with the company gone and all, unless another developer gets the rights to it.

I would recommend this game (perhaps when it's on sale, if your not sure) although I had no problem paying full price for this, and maybe not everyone will play it again, but after reading some positive and negative reviews I thought I would, IMO the second play through was better than the 1st!

reviewText:
I just finished the game in one and a half sittings. I'll go through some pros and cons that I came across while playing through the game quickly.

Pros:

+The concept. It is so extremely interesting and makes for some great gameplay. Ghosts are cool. :3c

+The deduction segments. You actually have to remember stuff that you uncovered way back in order to advance, which I found enjoyable and realistic. No need for a pen and paper though as the game keeps your previous discoveries and presents them when needed.

+The collectibles. These withhold some very interesting bits of history, character development and a few creepy-♥♥♥ ghost stories.

+The setting. Salem is a town with an extremely rich and interesting history, which is uncovered through the collectibles.

+Cats.

Cons.

-Character development. There isn't any really, apart from some of the collectibles.

-The story. You will either like the story or be disappointed. You are kept in the shade until the very end, despite all your detective work. The ending is also Shayamalan levels of twisty,

-The collectibles. Yes, these were both good and bad. The good thing is the info they contain, the bad thing is they are way too easy to collect. On my first playthrough, without using any walkthroughs and not stopping to explore every square inch of every area, I found around 80% of everything there is to be found. Most of them aren't even hidden in any way. Really cuts down on replay value.

-The game is very short. My very first playthrough, which I went into completely blind, only took me 6 hours from start to finish while getting 80% of all the collectibles <_>. This is also the main reason for the lack of character development. The story takes place during just one night though, so I guess the plan was to make the game short from the get-go.

-No new game plus. After finishing the game, if you continue from the last checkpoint you are placed right at the last scene, which the takes you to the credits again. The only other option is a new game.

-The enemies. Too easy to get rid of. They pose no real challenge and don't even really slow you down.

-The town. It is way too small to really bring that feel of exploration, and the various areas are split into separate zones.

Overall the concept delivered really well. The game really puts you in that fantasy of being a ghost. I would've wished for more varied gameplay and more gameplay in general. The shortness of the game really destroys it. I wanted to love this game with all my heart but I just can't. The flaws are too numerous and too big to ignore.

I feel it deserves to be played, but the price right now is way too high. Definitely grab it when it's put on sale

reviewText: I was looking forward to this game a lot, as I love anything to do with ghosts as well as crime. But I was let down by the fact that the developers have neglected to allow for keyboard customisation within the game, so that we can't change from having to use the default WASD keys. There are people that are left-handed, or have lost part of their left hand and can no longer play that way for games. It would have been nice if this was mentioned before some of us went and wasted our money.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural detective game which challenges players to solve their own murder case.

+ Town looks great with the ghostly" and "mortal" buildings mixed together.
+ Voice acting
+ Interesting lore and backstory about the town and the protagonist
+ Good chemistry between the main characters
+ Interesting storyline
+ Side quests are fun

- No replay value
- Game is too short"

reviewText:
A game in which a Yahtzee Crowshaw cosplayer gets killed by a man and then, as a ghost, follows a fairly predictable plotline to find out who the killer was.  Also the killer kills some other people and there is ghosts hanging about the place.  If you, for whatever reason, struggle to follow the story, just think of it as Ghost, the 1990 film about a ghost, but in a video game.

The game starts out in media res after showing the protagonist getting lots of tattoos.  Apparently this is important, somehow, because he was a criminal but is now a cop?  Dunno.  The game then moves on to demonstrating just how bad of a PC port it is.  When I first use my ghostly powers to possess someone, when using a keyboard, I got stuck and was unable to move.  The controls were unresponsive and I had to end the game’s process in task manager.  Definitely use a controller for this one.

Shortly after you will meet the game’s deuteragonist, Joy, who is a young girl able to see Ronan, the player, even though he is a ghost.  She isn’t too happy about that because she is always seeing them.  She tells you to ♥♥♥♥ off even after she is informed that you are able to help her find her mother who’s buggered off somewhere (it really is just “somewhere”, you never find out where).  Eventually she resigns herself to helping you if for no other reason than to get Ronan to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up.  What a great partnership.

Ronan himself is a fairly likeable character.  If you can get passed his ridiculous attire, plethora of edgy tattoos and the Phantom Cigarette which he never seems to stop smoking, he’s kind of alright.  He reminded me a little of Bigby from The Wolf Among Us; rolled up shirt sleeves, nasty smoking habit and devil-may-care attitude.  His hat is still stupid, though.  He’s basically a modern time discount Cole Phelps.

The game itself is quite short.  While I am not usually bothered by the time it takes to complete a game, I was somewhat miffed when I played for around four and a half hours, went to bed, woke up the following morning and managed to finish the game off in about half an hour.  The game’s ending itself appears rushed, scrambling to tie the plot together by showing various scenes with aspects of the story being finalised, but at least it tries.

Like many other developers, Airtight Games felt compelled to shoehorn in combat any way they could.  This means that occasionally you’ll come across Demons which you must kill by sneaking up behind them and performing a QTE.  This serves to do nothing else by distract the player and ruin the pace of an otherwise good gameplay loop.  Fortunately, there is a way to edit one of the game’s .ini files in order to stop the Demons spotting you.  They will still spawn, but ignore you completely.  Some may see this as cheating, I see this as an improvement.

SPOILERS AHEAD: The ghost girl you meet at the beginning of the game, Abigail, is the killer.  This comes as absolutely no surprise.  It is quickly established that the people stuck in what is ostensibly Purgatory may only leave if they resolve and move on from a key event in their life.  Ronan’s problem is that he never figured out who the Bell Killer was.  And what about Abigail?  Well, Ronan has a very basic possession ability, allowing him to go inside the mind of living beings (and control cats).  But Abigail’s are far more advanced than that.  Yes, she possess people and then kills other people.  Well, mediums, specifically.  Because they’re, like, witches or something.  Her motives are flimsy at best, completely balls-to-the-wall ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and ungrounded at worst.

Unlike a similar game, L.A. Noire, I found myself always one or two steps ahead of Ronan in the story.  Many times he would receive sudden clarity on something, and I would be sitting there thinking “Really?  Well, duh.  How did you not already figure that out?”.  At one point, when Ronan finally figures out the thing I’d already clocked onto hours before (the killer’s identity) he asked “But how did she do it?”.  BECAUSE SHE IS A GHOST WHO CAN POSSESS PEOPLE.  YOU CAN DO THE EXACT SAME THING.

It might seem like I completely hate the game, but I don’t really.  It’s flawed, but it’s also quite compelling.  While the story’s conclusion was foreseeable, it was still enjoyable to watch the characters make their way to it.  I still haven’t figured out why the ghosts could pass through walls, but not fall through the ground, though.  ‘Tis a mystery which plagues many stories like these.

В целом совсем не дурно.

Возможно это, правда, из-за того что я пырил в Дэвида нашего Кейджа последние две недели и после загранья что угодно покажется недурным.

В общем, начитался я ревьюшек и не ожидал совсем ничего. Лениво поставил купленный за три рубля на распродаже сабж пощупать на полчасика и ВНЕЗАПНО прошел за два присеста. Значит игра все-таки делает что-то правильно.

Например она делает правильно клевый сеттинг. Местный тихий ведьмосжигательный Салем вышел атмосферным и на удивление проработанным. И достаточно н♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥льным, для игры уж точно. Я даже во всякие разные коллектблс с интересом вчитывался, хорошая работа.

История и персонажи тут, положа руку на сердце - вообще ничего особенного, но они по крайней мере достаточно компетентны и удерживают на протяжении всей игры. И не бомбардируют фейспальмами со скоростью пулемета как в некой другой игре про призраков. Есть даже один поворот, который застал меня искренне врасплох (хотя вроде как и не должен был, все достаточно очевидно, видимо теряю хватку).

Полная фигота тут одна - местный стелс. Он адски дубовый и бесячий, хоть и не очень сложный. Но его по крайней мере очень немного, и на том спасибо.

Нормальная такая игра на позалипать 6-7 часов. Если пройдете мимо - ничего особенного не потеряете (чай не Blackwell), но покупки где-нибудь на распродаже она вполне себе заслуживает.

reviewText:
I just finished the game with 88% of achievements done. It's a good game. I love the Stories in this game. But game mechanics are to simple. There is not enough stuff you can do in a map. Once you finished the game there is low replay value. Game can be complete in 7-10 hours. I give this game a 3 out of 5
I do not recommed at current price, If price drops $ 40 or lower. I do recommend for story.

Positive stuff about game
+Fantastic stories
+Nice voice acting
+Good graphics
+Good Environment

Negative stuff about game
-Controls feel a bit lacking
-Easy to find clues and easy to solve problem
-Level maps are simple and not much to do other than collect stuff.
-Combat is awful

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is very nicely polished when it comes to graphics, sound, and interaction with the world. I hope they make a sequel of sorts. The game isn’t open for direct sequels to the story. A “Murdered” series would be really cool if they flesh out the mechanics to make them matter more.

If you’re looking for a puzzle/case solving game, this is not it. If you want to enjoy a cool story with a couple of nice twists and some very interesting game mechanics definitely check it out.

Full Review at http://germaximus.com/murdered-soul-suspect-review/ =)

reviewText: Alright, let me start this short review out by saying that this game is not worth $49.99.  If you're going to get it, wait until it is on sale, because while it is a good game, it is not nearly long enough for it to be worth that much money.  I do recommend it because it is a game that has aspects very similar to L.A. Noire, but without the open-world gameplay features.  The story was great!  I just really wish the game would have lasted longer, but I can see how Square-Enix might have felt like they would be dragging it on if they did make it even bigger.  Perhaps more episodes or dlc with another character or something?  Overall, my score is an 8 out of 10 for Murdered: Soul Suspect.

reviewText:
Murdered Soul Suspect won't blow anyone away, but it's a fun game with some good ideas that are unfortunately poorly implemented at times.

To be honest, I was a bit excited when I first heard of Murdered, but the lack of advertising and previews always make me worry about the final product. By the time it released it seems the studio was already closing down and no effort was made to promote it and that way try and earn some extra money with it. This was already obvious by the unusually high amount of discounts, months ahead of its release date. This game wasn't going to win any awards, and they knew that for quite some time then.

Graphically the game isn't the best, but it isn't the worst either. Models look nice and detailed, as well as the vilage. There are plenty of people walking around, ghosts and human, and there's a nice mix of still standing buildings and buildings that were destroyed in a fire a long time ago (and, like all the other ghosts, are being shown with a ghostly aura around them).
In the beginning it's explained why you can't just enter any building you see which sounds ridiculous when you hear it. It's obvious things were changed because of its low(er) budget. Still, it's more disappointing than it is frustrating. It would've been nice if you could go anywhere you want, but ok, that's just my opinion, of course.
A nice touch is the addition of static ghosts in the backgrounds that disappear once you get closer to them. Nothing eery or scary but cool evertheless (and maybe even underused).

The voice acting is actually very good, especially that of Ronan and Joy. I also can't complain about the music and sounds, which range from very decent to very good.

As far as the story is concerned; it's ok-ish. I was hoping for a mysterious story and while you keep guessing until the end it didn't have the payoff I was hoping to get. About three quarters in, the story becomes clearer and your expectations will probably change. Some might like it, others might like it less. I am part of the group that liked it less. The story became less personal near the end and I was disappointed by it.
Ghosts can also be found standing and hanging around certain places. They have some creepy stories to tell, and this is one of the things the game does right. But talking to some of these ghosts will give you a conversation tree to choose from. These are absolutely worthless and add nothing to the story or game. Again a case of wanting to add too much and where it's obvious they eventually had to cut it out because of time/money constraints.
The real sidequests have deeper stories than the other ghosts found in the game and solving these is fun and worth the time.

The gameplay consists of walking around and pressing context-sensitive buttons. Solving cases usually require you to search the area in search of items or people and press a specific button. Once you have enough evidence to solve a case you can do this, again, by pressing a button. You then have to click a memory (which basically is a piece of evidence you found) or click on memories in a certain order (like; how something may have happened).
Stealth is also used but it's so minimal that it's barely even worth mentioning. I think these can be counted on one hand. Still, it adds some variety to the game and it's something that makes the games a little harder. They should've used it more frequently because it works well.

There are a few groundbreaking bugs in the game. Mine started with the first investigation when things are still being explained to you. The buttons and tutorial overlays didn't work so I couldn't trigger anything. After a few minutes I reloaded the checkpoint and this time it worked just fine. This happened 3 or 4 more times during the course of the game. Annoying bugs that shouldn't be there because the other elements of the game work fine and even feel polished.

Murdered Soul Suspect isn't the game I originally wanted to have but it's still fun if you like ghost and detective stories. Don't expect a hardcore game here, but something a bit more casual; a game that anyone can play and finish.
It's not a great game, but not something mediocre either.

[Rating: 73/100]

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is the game where walking through walls and objects is no longer a bug but a feature.

First of all you should realize that this game is basically split 50-50 between gameplay and cut scenes. If feels more like watching a movie than playing a game. You get to play as detective Ronan O’Connor. Objective - solve your own murder, and save the terrorized Salem from The Bell Killer. Murdered: Soul Suspect offers a compelling story with several twists, and manages to entertain till the very end. There are also some side quests you can complete by helping several ghost you'll encounter during the game. These ones are optional, but are recommended to complete in order to get a better perspective of the game and your detective skills, especially since the main story is quite short. If you decide to buy it i would advice not to put much hope in the gameplay. It's quite repetitive - explore the location, gather clues on the case, escape the demons, watch the cut scene, and over again...

Overall, it somehow felt intriguing and mysterious, also quite different from most of the adventure games i've played. However, even after the recent price cut from $50 to $30 i still find it a bit overpriced and would recommend to get it on sale since it's too short, and has almost no replayability value, except if you're an achievement hunter and would need to play it a second time to get the ones you've missed.

reviewText: Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third person thriller detective game where you will be exploring various locations in Salem for clues on your case. This game feels almost as if it were an interactive movie, which is a great thing; in addition the graphics, sound and voice acting are all superb. The game has tons of collectibles which add a lot of background information to the stories, locations, and characters. It took me 10 hours to complete the game and collect everything.  If you are a fan of thriller or mystery games, I highly recommend this one!

reviewText: Interesting and engaging adventure game.  Gameplay is 95% walking around finding hidden clues and talking to people.  The other 5% are quicktime events to defeat demons which are quite easy (and you can avoid some of them if you want).  I enjoyed the game's premise of trying to solve your own murder as a ghost.  The story is good - not great - but good.  Your character is likable, the dialog is reasonably well written, and the locations and plot points are well realized.  I enjoy hunting down hidden items in games, and this game offers that in plenty.  Most are reasonably easy to achieve, and some are quite cleverly hidden.  One set of collectibles though, the ghost girl drawings, are very difficult because you do not see them in the environment - you have to walk close to the walls and a reveal" prompt will pop up if there is one there.\n\nIf you like adventure games and murder mysteries I think you will enjoy this game.  Best of all
date: it does not overstay its welcome.  Steam says I completed the game in 12 hours and I was quite slow and deliberate in playing (trying to find all the collectables)."

reviewText:
A good story game that has some interesting hooks in it and several stabs to your back.

Gameplay could have been more, it is on the low side of things - unless you consider collectible hunting to be a highly fun activity. It was decent at best.

Graphics, in Direct X 11, its quite pretty - even though its mainly night blue and dark grey - due to the subject matter.

Audio does a good job, nice atmosphere it provides.

The story is quite good, as you follow the trail, it gets more and more interesting. Even the ending is rather unexpected, even though it was nagging at the back of my mind - I just was't 100% positive.

My only REAL complaint is just the lack of real variety amongst the (living) NPC's.
The level of lazy we are talking about, is the LACK of many NPS's to begin with. Its roughly 6 for male and female.
Even the dialoge for either gender is repeated amonst different types of NPC's. It really annoyed me.

Is it worth the sale price of $30?
oh nooo.
Wait for a sale or to be bundled up with either games.

reviewText:
Don’t purchase this game if you expect a lot of gameplay. It’s a narrative gaming experience which involves looking around for clues and solving a few simple puzzles. Overall I had fun and when I wanted a break from action-packed games I played Murdered Soul Suspect. Let’s see the pros and cons.
Pros:
* The game engine: the game was developed using Unreal Engine 3, one of best engines there is. The game never crashed and I was able to play it with maxed settings and 60fps.
* Visual: even though the textures aren’t exactly top notch, the motion (especially the particles) and the lightening are great.
* Original concept: a detective solving his own murder, passing through walls and talking to other ghosts and mediums. That’s gotta be enticing.
Cons:
* The “mind reading” feature: I was expecting that every NPC would have unique thoughts and a lot of embarrassing things would be exposed to the players. That’s not what happens. By using the “mind read” in several different NPCs you might end up hearing the exact same thoughts. It appears they are randomly generated and distributed amongst the NPCs. That was definitely a disappointment for me. What’s the point of mind reading if they don’t appear to be real people, but rather randomly generated walking robots that spurs platitudes?
* The linearity: it is not possible to leave an area and return to the investigation later. I reckon this is a game based on narrative, but other developers managed to create narrative games without recurring to such strict storytelling (for instance, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter).
* Looks like the developers tried too hard to make the game “PG-13”. The NPCs don’t do anything interesting. You never see them doing anything out of the ordinary (unless you find a ghost. Apparently everyone who is naughty ends up dead too). It’s like the whole town of Salem is composed of boy scouts.

Other than that the game is fun. I hope to see a sequel that will address the abovementioned flaws. There’s a lot of potential for a series.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
You’ve been murdered, it’s a real bummer. But now you get the chance to find out who it was and seek justice from beyond the grave. Or you would if you played this.

Enter Ronan a bad guy turned good trying to stop a murderer on a killing spree but wouldn’t you know it you wind up just another one of their victims. But with unfinished business to attend to you hang around for a while and haunt the halls of Salem city searching for clues that could lead you to solving your own murder and ascending to heaven.

Or at least that’s the plan but as the recently departed not many people will talk to you. Enter the one witness to your death Joy who also happens to be psychic, after a lot of convincing the duo team up and take down the evil together. The story is certainly an intriguing and unique one. I have not seen a murder mystery from a dead person’s perspective before and with the amounts of twists and turns that come flying at you as you progress it will get you enthralled right to the end.

The game is stacked full of collectables, over a hundred of them to be precise, each with its own story. They all fit seamlessly into the town of Salem with its terrible past and not too stellar present. The world is more or less open world with you being able to travel from one location to another through the hub of the down town area. Each part of the world is beautifully designed and looks great mixing an old ghostly past with the present to make something new.

The game also features a huge amount of side quests and cases to solve. Speaking of which the detective mode is also something of an oddity, find a crime and solve it with clues found in the environment and placed together like pieces of a puzzle, I found a lot of pleasure recreating crimes to try and figure out what had happened and who the culprit was.

Now onto the main meat of the game combat…. There is none. Well that’s not true, there are a few enemies and by few I mean around 12 in the whole game and the only thing that happens is when they see you a QTE begins, win and you can proceed, lose and you have to start a short ways back. I would classify this more as an interactive novel than a game. Not that it’s a bad thing, but just be sure that’s what you are looking for before you delve in.

This game offers a lot and is a great distraction if you are looking for a unique experience that’s heavy on the narrative but light in most other places. At full price I can’t really recommend it but on sale you should pick this up and just enjoy your time in purgatory.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
Overall, the game is solid. The investigative parts are interesting, the story is decent, and the mechanics were fun. I kept moving right along. The characters aren't amazing, but they manage to keep the story engrossing long enough to keep you hooked.

This game isn't perfect though. For one, it's short. I mean real short. I spent my time looking around for clues and the like and it still only took me about 7 hours to finish the main story.

I would recommend this game, but I should point out that I only spent $5 on it. If you spend more than that, you might not feel like you got your money's worth.

reviewText:
I enjoyed it tremendously.  Absolutely a unique experience.

Playing as a ghost was well implemented in my opinion.  They used what I found were convincing concepts in order to limit your navigation where needed, establishing clear rules from the outset.

The mystery-solving was great.  It reminded me of L.A. Noire some (but I much preferred L.A. Noire I must say, as a game and specifically in its mystery-solving methods).  My one problem with it is that there really isn't a penalty for being a poor detective.  It's up to you to challenge yourself by not selecting all the answers until you get it right.  Of course, your 'ranking' is lowered for each incorrect guess but that's not a gameplay penalty as much as a pride penalty.

The story was compelling and the voice-acting was brilliant for anyone with a name you learn in the game.  Unfortunately, most of the NPCs with names you don't know, are comically wooden and not remotely human.  I loved Joy, notable given I thought I'd hate an angsty teen written by someone that's not an angsty teen, moreover one that's meant to be comedic and have an attitude; the media don't seem to be good at that in general, so this was a nice change.

Then there's the voice acting in the ghost stories.  That was phenomenal.  The stories were well written and well performed.  Absolutely a brilliant touch.

I really felt connected to Julia, your wife in the game.  She's hardly in the game, but you can collect her memories, and they're written.  If you read them, you begin to develop a real sense of who she is.  I have to commend that sort of characterisation.

The main character is believable.  Probably someone I'd laugh at in real life (even though I'd still like him; he's a good person and he certainly takes things in stride), but I can't say I haven't known people like him.  And the writing and acting make that believeable.

Speaking of taking things in stride, that's one flaw in the writing; too many people take too many things in stride.  But that's negligible in the face of everything else.

The combat system isn't much of a combat system, but I felt it worked well.  In fact, had they called your one move 'exorcise' or something instead of 'execute', you could have had a true example of a great game utterly devoid of combat, where overcoming your enemy isthe best thing you can do for them.  There's a nice stealth element alongside the one move you have.

The dæmons are extremely creepy in design.  I love it.

The music is great, but I wish that in a place where it becomes tense for enemies, that it would become less tense once the enemies are neutralised.  It doesn't.  A minor flaw I suppose.

The game feels like an indie game and was developed by Airtight Games, who were apparently independent according to Wikipedia.  I say this because the graphics are rather poor compared to contemporary games, and like many indie developers, the engine used was the old UE3 engine, rather than what was most current.

There's a lot of history in the game.  Old Salem bleeds into the modern Salem as the main character (and all ghosts I imagine) sees things.  You can collect snippets of history, which were probably all accurate, as the ones I was familiar with were all correct.

Bonus:
I'm a linguist, and I liked that a lot of the accents were notably correct.  The game takes placein Salem, which isn't too far from Boston.  I'm very familiar with the Boston accent as it's rather high-profile in dialects of English, and moreover as it has a significant Irish influence.  I'm not terribly familiar with Salem's accent but a lot of characters possess Boston traits so I assume they were trying to localise the accent at least as Massachusetts, which is really interesting to someone like me.  Also, a lot of Irish turns of phrase are used, which on looking them up are apparently common in that area of America, from Irish emigrants.  Nice.  Not only that, a lot of people have Irish names, which is rather realistic and once again interesting.
Oh, but the old-time Puritan accents were cat.  Absolute rubbish they were.

Speaking of cats, you can possess cats and meow and climb things and jump on things.  Another nice touch.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is actually a really good game. Okay, maybe that's an overstatement, but I really enjoyed it's approach to detective work and solving the mystery of your own murder as well as the recent string of murders in Salem in a single night.

You play Ronan O'Connor, a former petty criminal/turned detective who is hot on the trail of the Bell Killer, only the opening cutscene is your own death. The game picks up right from there as you search for clues and get used to being a ghost. The devs handled the ghost mechanics rather well as far as being unable to walk into buildings from the outside unless there's an open doorway or window. But you can move through walls, bushes, benches, etc.

The story is really intriguing and it seemed like it was going to be predictable, but I was wrong. I didn't know who the killer was from the get go. So, I tip my hat to the devs for pulling a decent M Night Shamalamadingdong. Sound design is eerie, as it should be. Unnamed NPC's that walk around Salem that you can possess, well, a lot of them looked the same and had the same responses when reading their minds, that bugged me. And for being an open world town, it seemed more restricted than anything because of the ghost walls that you can't pass through. It just made the town section of the game seem a lot more linear, but like a maze.

The graphics were decent enough, but it's clear that the game was held back due to last gen consoles. I mean, some of the modeling and textures look like games from 2010.

The mystery work was a lot of fun though, searching for clues and whatnot. Good game.

7.5/10

reviewText:
If your dream has always been playing an undead fedora-wearing douchbag neckbeard solving criminal cases like some try-hard Maltese Falcon reject who can't come to terms with the fact that he neither lives in the 1940s, nor understands the actual era (dress code included) - this might just be the game for you. Douchehat McNeckbeard might be laughably slow in how he connects clues, but he comes with a full package of mangst in the form of a fridged (of course) Manic Pixie Dreamgirl wife, and the attitude you'd expect from a 40-year-old basement dweller. If that is what you enjoy in a game, this will be a dream for you - albeit an admittedly short one, since the game is as the most 10 hours, and that's when you take your time as I did.

On a more serious note, this game did have potential, and I really wanted to like it. Tuning out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ protagonist and his ridiculous and frankly embarrassing fashion sense (which is explained away in the most ridiculous 'didn't even try' manner possible in the game), parts of the gameplay, particularly in the beginning, were fun. Sadly the really fun parts are tragically underused, and for the course of the game following the opening mission, you experience practically nothing new. The first bigger investigation was fun especially through learning all the things you could do to get clues - connect existing clues in your head for new revelations, possess people and prompt them to reveal what they knew by triggering the right clues in their heads, seeing through their eyes into computer files, etc - but there it ended. You acquire a few more fine-tuned skills later on (teleporting, most notably), but nothing that really stands out. The fun experimental trying and testing which witness might have seen what and respond to which clues turns into a tedious button-smashing 'where's the one tiny object in the room that I keep missing?' adventure. Gameplay stagnates and turns into the same thing over and over and over again, only for Mr Fedora to finally come to a conclusion that quite frankly you could have told him after or even before entering the building.

The worst part by far is the writing. Not only are the main characters (most notably the supposed 'tough cops' who only come across as petty, ♥♥♥♥♥y, and whiny) utterly unlikeable, but the main story itself lacks any originality. For the sake of avoiding spoilers if you are for whatever reason still interested in playing, I won't go into the details further, but whatever 'twists' were apparently thought up by the writers have been done before and repeated to death, were foreseeable to the point I don't even want to call it foreshadowing anymore, and - due to the absolutely flat character writing - lacked any sort of emotional impact. I never thought a game centring around a murder investigation done by a GHOST in ♥♥♥♥ing SALEM could be boring, but this is. It's plain and simply boring, with slightly awkward, incredibly repetitice gameplay, and with the added disadvantage of the most obnoxious, annoying, self-centred, whiny wannabe-tough guy fedora-wearing neckbeard Gary Stu of a protagonist I have ever seen. It's like a bad '40s film noir rip off (BUT IN SALEM, WOOO SUPERNATURAL THINGS) gone completely wrong. And not even spectacularly wrong, just underwhelming, tedious, and most of all - disappointing.

There are worse games, of course, but this game stands out mainly because it doesn't - it's all been done before, been done better, and there is literally nothing that this game has to offer. It's not the worst, not a spectacular train wreck, but it's poor, and it's sad. Good for a few minutes of fun, and if you really have to kill time and have absolutely nothing else to do.

Overall, 2/5, and that's me being nice, because I enjoyed parts of the early gameplay. Suggested time to buy: at 90% off.

reviewText:
So MURDERED: Soul Suspect was such an amazing game that I decided to write a little review... At first the story is so good because you get everything told in the first few minutes. The story is interesting and will be unexpected and different the whole game. You're shocked, thrilled, scared and even sad with the characters.

This game doesn't have an open world or big levels to explore and the gamer has to follow straight the story more or less. Very, very much things can be collected, like memories, part of ghost tales and pieces of the past of the main character. An easy gameplay leads you through MURDERED and it's easy to learn. So something about the main characters: Ronan O'Connor is great designed. A taff, sometimes joking but at the same time a heartwarming person exploring the reason of his death and the murder.

A little negative point: For the ghost tales you need to collect in one level around 8-14 things and when the story is told you just see a picture. Something like a simple and small film after 15 minutes seeking would be better. BUT it's a great, game and it was very cool to play. A BIG I LIKE :))

+ Graphics is awesome

+ Nice story
+ The side quests are nice touch
+ The plot twist

Get it when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect was a game I've been heavily anticipating ever since I saw it in action. I expected something along the lines of Ghost Trick mixed with L.A. Noire. What I got instead was essentially a much better Beyond Two Souls and that in of itself isn't a bad thing.

Taking place in Salem, Massachusetts, you play as the deceased Detective Ronan O'Connor. Murdered by a mysterious serial-killer, he finds out that the only way to pass on to the afterlife and reunite with his dead wife is to figure out the murders identity identity so he may leave this mortal plane. It's a decent Whodunit story with a lot of interesting side-stories unlocked through collectibles.

My biggest problem with this game is the gameplay or lack thereof. For what it's worth, I did enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect when you realize the game isn't trying to be Ghost Trick or LA Noire, but this is something you'll notice more and more as you'll go along. I actually think it starts out pretty well. You walk through walls, talk to fellow ghosts, discover their stories through detective work. It all seemed fine until you find out that's that where it stops. It never gets any harder, better more complex, better. The game doesn't offer much depth and at worse, becomes less interesting for the player. All you do is press X to evidence. There are no fail states in the investigation sections. There are no incentives to actually think logically and not randomly guess at what the game throws at you besides meaningless tokens and even then the game is incredibly easy. Oh

reviewText:
Good procedural detection sim. The gun in the detective's hand is not part of the game, fyi. This is about exploration and storytelling, not shooting things. Walking through walls is fun... when they let you.
The story is alright. Nothing too moving. The metaphysics are wonky - while they give the Catholic Church a good character in the priest, they clearly didn't worry about keeping the theology of life after death in the traditional understanding. Took me out of the game a bit as your character tells lost souls to forgive themselves and they whoosh off in a bright light lol.
Also, I wish the detective was more likable instead of some fedora-wearing clown.
The graphics are ok, basically what is expected nowadays. However, some of the character models are pretty bad and voices randomly match up to models to hilarious results. I didn't encounter any gameplay issues.
All around a competently made game. I had fun completing it, but would not buy except on sale at least half off.

reviewText:
If L.A. Noire was like a big budget, 3D version of Ace Attorney, then this is sort of like a big budget, 3D version of Ghost Trick (which was made by the same people as Ace Attorney). Also pardon the pun, but this does feel a bit like a 'spiritual successor' to L.A. Noire, except with the focus mostly on the investigating, and some action-ish segments. Basically, if you like any of the other three games I mentioned above, you'll probably like this.

It is a little on the short and easy side, but that just means that no frustrating gameplay gets in the way of the player ploughing through the plot. The writing is a little predictable, and I managed to call most of the major plot developments within the first hour, but I still wanted to know what happened next, and to be fair I was wrong about a few things. The investigating of crime scenes is pretty fun and easy, and there's also some stealth sections where you have to sneak about excorcising some genuinely creepy demons.

There's also collectable story bits, like the thoughts of Ronan's wife or newspaper articles about the killer. In addition, each level and the over world has a unique set of collectable items (or rather, the same item you have to scavenge for 8-19 times) that, when all collected, get you a little narraration of a ghost story. Fair Warning: some of those are an absolute ♥♥♥♥♥ to find if you want to 100% them.

5/10
