reviewText:
Absolutely no spoilers in this review.

*Edited review now that I have finished the game. It took me about 7.5 hours(played it offline and steam doesn't track offline play) to complete this game and that is including time spent searching for collectibles and finding probably about 85-90% of them. So the complaints that the game is short are pretty valid. Had I skipped the collectibles I probably would have completed it in around 6 hours. That said, I loved every second of this game. The game probably doesn't have a lot of replay value either unless you want to go back through to finish the collectible stories or help any ghosts you passed up on your original playthough (there are only 3-4 of them though I think unfortunately.)

So I played this game until 3 am and could barely drag myself away from the keyboard to go to sleep. I am absolutely enthralled by this game and I love it. If the rest of the game is as good as the first 4 hours I've played of it then it will easily be contender for my GOTY.

The voice acting is awesome. A lot of the random civilians share the same voice actors but thats a minor thing. I recognize most of the random civilian voice actors from other big budget games. They are all great voice actors. So it seems the devs went with quality over quantity.

The visuals are great. I feel like most unreal engine games have models that look like they are made of clay, but this game does not. The ghostly effects are really cool. The way the demons move is absolutely terrifying. Animations are great all around with the possible exception of some lip syncing here and there on the minor characters.

The gameplay is fantastic. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off the demons and being forced to run and hide until they lose your scent is pretty terrifying. Finding collectibles is awesome because once you find all of a set you unlock an audio short story with a piece of art and the stories are really REALLY good so far. Your ghost powers are pretty freaking awesome and the game rewards exploration with collectibles littered all over the levels.

Helping other ghosts solve questions regarding their deaths and helping them move on is a great feeling. These little side mission stories are very well written and acted.

Finding clues is somewhat similar to but much more enjoyable than it was in LA Noire. Once you find all the clues you do a little solving... puzzle I guess. You get three attempts to solve the puzzle. I don't know what happens if you fail all three attempts yet. But they are generally pretty self explanatory for the most part. It asks a question on the screen and you answer it by selecting the proper clue(s), sometimes in a certain order too.

The game actually makes me feel like a ghostly detective. And the story itself is amazing so far. The 63/100 metascore completely baffles me because this game is great and easily one of the best gaming experiences of the year so far.

I loved the ending. It wraps everything up in a smart way. I immensely enjoyed this game. If you have any interest in ghost stories or detective mysteries then you will love this game.

reviewText:
Not a perfect game by any means, but well worth a sale pickup for the story, atmosphere and visuals.

This wasn't a game at the top of my wishlist, but I have been eyeing it since it came out, and when I found it on sale at the HB store for $15 I jumped at the opportunity.  I wasn't disappointed - personally I really enjoyed the game.  The story is engaging, the acting is very good, the visuals and mood of the game are great.  I think a lot of people hating on it are either bandwagon-jumpers who haven't played it, or were just expecting a different kind of game.  A lot of complaints seem to revolve around a lack of action - you just sort of walk around and click where it tells you to.  And in reality there's not too much more to the gameplay, so if you want more then you probably won't like it.  I went in treating it as more of an interactive story - a glossed-up point-and-click adventure, if you will, and I wasn't let down.  The game does have legitimate problems, but for me none of them were deal-breakers, and were outweighed by the pros:

Cons:
- suffered from performance issues and fairly frequent frame rate drops, which got worse as the game went on
- no ability to remap keys
- the mouse didn't work for all the menu items
- no chance to go back and finish collecting items once you've entered the final level, meaning you'd have to play through the game again in order to try and get everything.  As much as I like the game, I'm not interested in playing it all again just to finish up a few achievements
- the demons were really more of an annoyance than anything - they should have played more of a roll or just been pulled altogether
- a lot of the investigations were far too simple to solve, while a small few were unreasonably obscure

Pros:
- Great voice acting
- Great camera work
- Great atmosphere
- Great story
- NOT too short - I put 12-13 hours into the game by taking my time, doing the side missions, collecting artifacts, and generally immersing myself into the really good story.  I'd rather play a really enjoyable 8-12 hour game than spend 2 or 3 times that on something I end up barely able to finish because I've gotten so sick of it (L.A. Noire springs to mind).  Besides, at 12 hours I spent barely over a buck per hour on it - that's pretty good value in my book.

So overall it's probably not worth full price, but easily worth $15-$25, as long as you enjoy story-driven adventure games.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I really wanted to like Murdered: Soul Suspect.  The pun in the name alone gives it a couple of points straight off and I found the story enjoyable, with a well constructed supernatural mystery.  While the plot doesn’t break any new ground, it does make good use of its setting and archetypical characters.  But the game side of things really holds the experience back.  The puzzles are rather boring and quite easy, with most of the challenge being little more than a pixel hunt.  But what really ruined the experience for me were the tedious stealth sections that become longer and more frequent as the game goes on, without any variation to how they play out; they really interrupted an otherwise enjoyable story.\n\nHonestly, I wish this was a TV show or movie as it unfortunately doesn’t make for a terribly good video game.

reviewText: Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story-driven third-person investigative adventure game with some stealth elements. You take the role of Ronan O'Connor, a former bad boy turned good guy. Everything begins seconds after you've just been thrown from a fourth story window by the game's primary antagonist. The fall almost kills you and the subsequent bullets to the chest finish the job, meaning you play through the entire game as a ghost. Murdered: Soul Suspect plays out like a puzzle game along the lines of L.A. Noire. As a detective Ronan must uncover clues and evidence to track down the Bell Killer. As a ghost in limbo, Ronan has a number of abilities at his disposal. Although he cannot walk through external doors unless they are opened by someone else, once inside a building Ronan can walk through walls and other obstacles. He can fall great distances and not get hurt and he is able to possess people to read their thoughts, influence their actions and peek at their notes or at their computer screens. He can even possess other creatures such as cats to get to hard to reach areas. In addition to the primary plotline being very interesting, the game generally has a very well-designed backdrop, numerous side quests, and superfluous opportunities to discover more about the characters and places featured in the game.Another part of Murdered that works pretty well is the look of the game. When Ronan walks through the streets of Salem, he sees a mixture of how it is now interspersed with what it looked like during the witch trials of the 17th century. The modern Salem is in full color, but the old Salem is in blue and white, and the contrast is striking. The character models and cut scenes are also rendered well. Really, the production values for Murdered are about as good as you’re going to see in a game. The audio multiplies the eerie feeling as well, with some haunting background music. The music, combined with the sound effects works marvellously.I really liked the look, the atmosphere, and the story behind Murdered: Soul Suspect.Although at times the pace of the game can seem a little slow, I have found that Murdered: Soul Suspect to be an enjoyable detective experience – even if it is somewhat simplified detective work.If you’re a fan of mysteries, Murdered: Soul Suspect would be a worthy purchase. Overall 8/10.

reviewText: The best way to describe this game would be to say it's a mix of Ghost Trick and Silent Hill with a little Ace Attorney in there.  I enjoyed my time with the game, mostly to see how the story unfolds. The gameplay is nothing too special and mostly linear unless you are going for collectables (there are a lot). The writing is good for the most part but the delivery can be a bit strange sometimes. It took me just under six and a half hours to beat the game and I would recommend if you enjoy the games mentioned earlier. I also recommend going in without knowing too much about the game, which is why I don't want to write too much here.

reviewText:
4/10  Murdered: Soul of Garbage Collector

I rated the gameplay with 5 and the story with 5. This game got 1/5 for gameplay 3/5 for story.

-The game basically holds your hand through the whole game. There is no punishment for getting anything wrong, and some clues are really stupid. I figured out the run button long ago and the game tried to teach me that after a while.

-Gameplay sucks, basically you run around and collect garbage. That is what you do, the only thing that made it even get that score was the story which isn't that great.

-Characters are all have the same faces with the same thoughts. Salem had too many people with the same faces that if the killer was one of them, we wouldn't find him.

-Demons are just in the way, they didn't make the gameplay any better. It made it worse since the design for the Ghost things to hid in was far away from you, or covered by a wall, or all of them in the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ room which the demons don't even go in. Ravens that supposed to help you are either far away or the range of their screams doesn't reach the demon that you wana kill. And quick time event is not my idea of a fun game. Wish they didn't created the so called demons because they always delayed me from continuing the storyline. Boring @ss obstacles on the ground, forcing you to go around them because they are demon pits or something.

-All the cats have the same color which is black in Salem.

-Some places you think it should be possible to teleport to but you can't even though you did it during a story mode.

-Some escorting missions are stupid and *Spoiler* HOW the hell would July sneak into the church without the police even noticing her?

-*Spoiler* there is a Ghost train, so how the hell does an object have a ghost? Why doesn't animals get ghost too, since objects with no soul can have ghosts.  Throw the logic on the ground when you play the game.

- You can't recollect the other stuff once you reach a check point in the game. I tried to see the story about the (Need Gas) but with the game desgin you MUST replay the whole thing once you enter the Judgment house. Another example of  terrible game design (wish they had the chapter saving to return to the point you need to finish any achievement you missed during your first play through) instead you have autosave.

+ The only thing I liked about this game was the graveyard thief story and nothing else.

I pre-ordered this game and just got to play it. Wait for a sale to buy it, and don't waste more than 10$ on it.

reviewText:
As a HUGE adventure fan that almost always prefers a classic 2D click'n'point adventure, Murdered: Soul suspect is a breath of fresh air to everything the adventure genre has to offer. The graphics are just amazing, and thanks to the Unreal engine, the game runs smooth as butther with everything maxed out.

V-sync limits the game to 30FPS, but you can switch that off and just enable V-sync in your GPU options (Catalyst Control or Nvidia center) which gives you all the smooth awesomeness of 60FPS.

The story of this game is brilliant, and the spooky atmosphere just adds to the overall setting of the game. The way you interact with your surrounding and figure out the clues is great, but I was hoping getting stuff wrong would give you a penalty of some kind... Then again, it is an adventure game and most of them are very linear.

There is no combat apart from banishing demons witch can be really difficult at some parts but nothing an average gamer can't figure out.

I was afraid that the ending will be a dissapointment compared to the massive build up of the story (and the bodies murdered) but the game really delivered. After YEARS of trying to find something different and new in the adventure game genre, Murdered: Soul suspect finally brings tons of new mechanics, great voice acting, an amazing story and a beautiful engine to finally burst life into a slumbered genre.

Hats off to the devs and the writters.

I highly recommend this game if you're looking for something new in your roguelike/dungeon-crawling experiences... it was *the* most polished Early Access Alpha I had ever played, and is even better now that it is released.


Graphics

Gameplay

reviewText:
A solid crime and investagative experience
This game is not for everyone, but delivers a fascinating investigative thriller

The story and approach is very unique and anyone who has an interest in the Salem witch trials and history will like this game.  I found it interesting as I have read the Crucible and enjoyed wandering through Salem.

It's not very scary but does have an eerie atmosphere at times.

The graphics are good and does help the player to feel immersed in the game and story.

Investigating can feel repetitive at times but does continue the story and create more questions for the player. The game length fits in well with the story and it doesn't get dragged out.

[/b] A good game for the point and click" crime franchise 7/10 [/b]"

reviewText:
This game is an excellent concept, as you are a detective who is killed at the very start of the game and in the remainder of the game you play as his ghost, and you must solve your own murder to get out of this limbo-esque state and into a place where your already dead wife is which seems to be kinda like heaven.
The story is really good. I really enjoyed the gameplay however there is very little combat so if you don't like games without combat you're probably not going to enjoy this. So if you're not interested in the story then I'm almost certain you wont enjoy the game.
The only bit of combat in the game is very boring and frustrating, as you will be investigating when suddenly a demon will appear and chase you and you will have to keep hiding in these little spectral gas bubbles. This is very tedious and in my opinion something that the game would be better without.
The ending of the game is one of the best endings I've played in a while, it is a bit annoying that you are not able to return to the town of Salem after completion of the game but this is not disastrous as this will only bother serious completionists who want every collectible.
The game took me about 12 hours with exploring pretty much everything I saw so I guess it would take 8 hours or so without that. I wouldn't say its worth £25 considering how short it is so wait for a sale.
I really enjoyed the game though, certainly worth playing if it goes on sale.

Just finished the game and I really enjoyed it. While it doesn't take long to play it through (I needed 8 hours and I took my time) it was fun while it lasted. I am not sure about the replay value, though. The game heavily relies on its thick atmosphere and the story twists to drive you along and I imagine it will be less fun the second time around.

If you don't care for pages after pages of story or lots of cut scenes or do expect a certain amount of fighting in your games you should skip this one, though. There are a few fight" scenes but you have to solve them through misdirection and stealth. No open combat.

Still
date: if you do enoy a good story and an atmospheric game you should give this one a try. I recommend playing it at night or in a darkened room - both for the atmosphere and to see all the details on the screen. You should also take the time and gather as many clues as possible
recommended: especially for the small side quests. The stories are delightfully spooky."

reviewText:
If you like the Blackwell series (and I would heartily reccomend the Blackwell games, I bought them on GOG not Steam), you will likely enjoy this odd beast. I got it in the half price sale and consider it worth the 12 some quid, but I wouldn't reccomend buying it at full price since it's a fairly short game and like most adventure games, low on replayability.

This is a good game with some terrible game mechanic design decisions.

Pros:
Decent story
Enjoyable characters
Interesting ideas explored throughout - enough to overshadow the cons, for my money.

Cons:
Clatty interface, probably made worse by poor porting to keyboard and mouse. If you use a pad on your PC, you may have no issues.
Some really annoying QTE's bracketed with unskippable cutscenes - especially the finale which should have been exciting and ended up being an exercise in impotent rage management.
Unskippable end credits that run for 15 mins  - laughably bad decision.

reviewText:
For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.
Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.
Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.
However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together.
The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well
date: making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics.\nVery little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons
hoursPlayed: or paranoia plaguing the area
voteText: thus leaving much more to be desired in character development.\n"Extra" characters aren't even kept within the game for very long
helpfulPercent: making it feel as though there are only four real characters

reviewText:
A very unusual detective story where you try to solve your own murder. The gameplay isn't very strong (they could've done so much with what they had with some effort) but the story itself is quite. Not wasting time trying to get 100% completion, I didn't feel any part of the game overstayed its welcome or that I was grinding. Some of the investigations seemed to require answers that were contradictory to what was asked though, which was the biggest gripe I had besides the final confrontation which was very much a trial-and-error thing compared to the rest of the game.

Can't really say I recommend this at full price as it's a bit fiddly around the edges that likely won't be fixed post-release with patches, but if you can get it for 20€ or less, I can recommend it for anyone who wants more a story than a game (it's not completely devoid of being a game like Dear Esther tho).

So there. Thumbs waving up here. Liked it. Probably around 4-6 hours long for those who get things right fast and just ignore the side stuff completely, 10+ hours for those who try to get 100% without guides maybe.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story driven game in it's entirety.  The initial events and investigations that followed kept me interested enough to keep playing to the end.  In that regard, Murdered succeeds and is why I'm giving it a thumbs up recommendation.  However, if I was able to vote with both thumbs, it would be one up and one down... I was on the fence about this one.   Why?

On the positive side, the story of a modern murder mystery slowly unraveling as the victim himself uncovers the truth is satisfying.  It starts very strong and doesn't end the way you might expect, so that was refreshing.  But there comes a point when as a player you piece together the basic gist of what is happening but Ronan takes a while longer to 'get it'.  This is about mid-point in the game and it was quite frustrating because Ronan is supposed to be an investigator but due to his inability to make the connections before the player does, the game seems to drag until Ronan catches up.  The ending does leave a lot of 'huh?' questions in your mind and does feel a little anti-climactic.  I think this is mostly due to discovering several things all at once in once scene, then end credits.  There is no pacing to the final shocking revelations, and therefore no real chance to feel closure, empathy, relief, satisfaction... none of it.  It's there but it happens too fast.  So fast that Ronan doesn't even react to a world-shattering personal discovery.

The characters are memorable.  Pairing the main character Ronan with a mostly reticent, feisty, but intelligent teen Joy adds a lot of chemistry.  Joy is well written and performed.  For me she was the star.  Ronan was a rough and tumble kind of guy before meeting his soulmate, and the mellow, tolerant side of him is done well but that's the only side we get to see.  I was severely disappointed by the lack of strong emotion or raw aggression that could have bled through on many occassions but doesn't.  Sadly Ronan comes off as deadpan.
The environment is very well done, with a quiet moody setting where the grim nature of it's history can be seen through your dead eyes.

On the negative side, this is a game.  Or more precisely, it tries to be a game.  Almost every single game aspect  just gets in the way, slows things down, and makes you wish the substance it hides was more fleshed out.  The presence of demons and the need to evade and/or exorcise them is haphazardly thrown into the mix.  They look cool and scare the crap out of you when they start chasing you, but these notably gameplay moments seem so disjointed from the story.  It's like the developers said 'OK let's just throw some game in right here'.
There is a heavy collecting element to this game if you want your story fleshed out.  From Ronan's background, to his relationship with his lost wife, to history of the setpieces... it's all locked away in the text granted to you when you find something which is not always related.  I'd say maybe half of these were worth reading for good background info.  The rest were all useless to the story and the game.  Of special note are the area specific ghost stories you can unlock.  Most of them are interesting and I really wish they had been incorporated into the story somehow.
The investigation and possession elements were great concepts that were presented so incredibly poorly.  When you attempt to solve an investigation the premise is that you take clues and piece them together to come to a conclusion.  Among those pieces are clues that don't help.  If you get one clue wrong, it exits the minigame and you start again.  So all you have to do is keep trying each one until you get it right, and there aren't that many to choose from anyways.  It feels really pointless.  You can inhabit the body of people and read or influence their thoughts, but the thoughts are so plain and boring and the chances to influence people are few and far between.  More wasted potential.

My recommendation is to enjoy the game for the story and just follow the carrot.  The gameplay is easy enough to just get through so you can keep the main story moving along.  Collecting and killing demons and exploration are entirely not necessary (unless you want achievements in which case you will be forced to grind through everything).  The game length felt good for a story driven game; not so short that I felt ripped off but not too long that I felt it was watered down or needless.
I'd also recommend getting this at $15 or less, which I feel is a fair price point.

reviewText:
If you like the Blackwell series (and I would heartily reccomend the Blackwell games, I bought them on GOG not Steam), you will likely enjoy this odd beast. I got it in the half price sale and consider it worth the 12 some quid, but I wouldn't reccomend buying it at full price since it's a fairly short game and like most adventure games, low on replayability.

This is a good game with some terrible game mechanic design decisions.

Pros:
Decent story
Enjoyable characters
Interesting ideas explored throughout - enough to overshadow the cons, for my money.

Cons:
Clatty interface, probably made worse by poor porting to keyboard and mouse. If you use a pad on your PC, you may have no issues.
Some really annoying QTE's bracketed with unskippable cutscenes - especially the finale which should have been exciting and ended up being an exercise in impotent rage management.
Unskippable end credits that run for 15 mins  - laughably bad decision.

reviewText:
For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.
Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.
Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.
However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together.
The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well

reviewText:
Rating: 7.5/10

Short thoughts:Overall, I very much enjoyed playing Murdered: Soul Suspect and would definitely recommend it for those who are looking for a cool story about a ghost detective in the town of Salem looking to crack the case of his own murder.

Longer thoughts:The story is based around a murdered detective named Ronan who is a pretty cool and has the outfit to match (and never ending cigarette). Ronan travels around the town of Salem investigating his own murder case as well as those of other townsfolk. Main story was enjoyable, as well as the side mini-stories fueled by the collection of 'evidence' around the town. The ghost aspect was neat, as you could walk through walls, possess people and animals, influence their thoughts and more of that nature. Could have used some variety in the options of interacting with NPCs, but I didn't mind it much. The game has a simple combat system which I found to work out great in the end as it allowed you to continue focusing on the story rather than get distracted and spending hours sneaking by monsters as some other games have you do. In the end, I am very satisfied with how this game played out and do not regret purchasing it one bit. However, I would not recommend purchasing this at full price (~$30), but if it can be found on sale below that, I would definitely suggest picking it up.

reviewText:
Spent 14 hours to finish this game and get almost all of the collectibles, except the Ghost Girl Messages because they were hard to find and I was too lazy to backtrack and find them all. So here's my take on the game.

Gameplay:Many people compare this with L.A. Noire but I think the two games are vastly different. This game leans more towards an adventure game, if I have to find another game to compare it with, this game is pretty close in concept to the Blackwell Series (which is awesome, go grab it) in that the game asks you to solve a murder mistery and also help other spirits move on by helping them to know why they died and resolve their situation. In a way, it's almost a 3D version of the Blackwell series, with the emphasis on adventure, finding clues and solving puzzles.

Some people complained that the stealth action parts of this game (exorcising demons) are too difficult and annoying. I think it's not that difficult, but if you DO find it hard and it breaks the game for you, there's a simple cheat/patch out there that you can use to completely nullify the stealth action parts and turn it entirely into an adventure game, which might help make this game infinitely better for you.

Story:Personally, I think the story is the main strong point of this game. As a lover of classic supernatural adventure games, such as the Gabriel Knight series, this IS the game for me. I also love games that are based on history or cult stories (such as the Assassin's Creed series), and knowing that this game mixed some real history (the Salem witch trials) to the plot just makes it more immersive for me. There is even one character from the Salem witch trials history that appears here, which might surprise some that are in the know of this story.

But as with any story out there, like when watching a movie or reading a book, this section is entirely subjective and either you like it or you don't. If you find out that you don't like the premise, then you have no reason to play this game at all, as there is nothing else to find here if you dislike the story. It will quickly get boring for you.

Graphics:Played this game on my ASUS laptop with GeForce GT650M 2GB DDR3 graphics and the game runs fine on mostly high settings (see the screenshot I posted of this game for more details) with no stuttering framerates or slowdowns. The graphic quality is awesome and totally realistic, from the facial expressions of the characters to the textures and clothings. Ronan, especially, is rendered with truly amazing detail, I was a bit speechless when I saw his semi-transparent ultra-detailed character model during the opening moments. If you have a decent graphics card, this game can render truly amazing details for your enjoyment.

Sound:Voice acting is very good, especially for the lead character Ronan. The music and ambient sounds successfully brings out the haunting and crreepy atmosphere of the story. The sound effect is carefully designed to great effect, especially the shrieks of those demons which can literally get you jumping out of your seat if you're playing with headphones on during the middle of the night.

Weakness:There is no in-game map. But the town of Salem is not that large and pretty soon you will be able to get your bearings around town by memory alone. The only difficult route to remember was probably the one that leads to the church, because you need to take a specific route to get there. If you're worried about getting all the collectibles, there are a lot of guides and videos out there that can help you, so you don't have to worry about that at all.

Verdict:7.0 - A must buy for mystery/murder/detective adventure game lovers out there, especially those who loved the Gabriel Knight or the Blackwell series.

TIP: Don't buy it with the full price. This game often goes on sale, so better wait for it to go on sale and grab it. I got it for just $3.99 during the most recent Square Enix sale.

TIP #2: Play with a game controller, not with a keyboard and mouse. It will make a whole lot of difference and can make or break the game for some people.

reviewText:
This is actually quite a fresh and intersting idea for a game. You play a cop who gets killed by the serial killer he is investigating only for him to become a ghost. Even worse for him he can't move on until he finds out who the serial killer is and then stop him. Playing a ghost is actually quite fun as you can walk through walls and objects as well as possess living characters and listen to their thoughts and influence them. The gameplay is a bit lacking though as most of the game involves investigating by searching for clues and then concluding the investigation by picking the most important clues thus moving the story along. The only enemies you encounter are demons which are easily dispatched by sneaking up behind them and killing them and the encounters with them are too few and far between to be a problem. The biggest dissappointment with this game is that they could have done so much more with the ghost stuff to make the gameplay better.

The Good:
-Interesting idea for a game and it works quite well.
-Decent story which is the games main strength. Also the setting of Salem is brilliant and the atmosphere is great.
-Playing as a ghost is quite fun even if they could have done so much more with it.

The Bad:
-Game is really easy and doesn't provide much in the way of a challenge.
- Pretty short and padded out with having loads of collectibles.

Overall this is a decent game if not perfect.Worth picking up on sale.

reviewText:
First thing: If you Consider buying this game buy it when it goes on sale.

Pros:
You get to Play as a Spoopy Ghost.
Good Story.
Very atmospheric.
Intriguing Side Story's felt like something you would read out of a Horror Story collection book.
Most Collectibles are given along the area questline. (only a few you have to go searching for.
For a game based upon Salem it gave a very dark feeling as you explored an area for the first time.

Cons:
Would of benefited more from being a point and click adventure. (In my Opinion)
Very Linear.
Combat feels tact on to give more play time.(How have companies not learned people hate QTE'S?)
Short Story (from start to finish if you rush and don't do any side parts maybe 4-6 hours)
No replayablity unless you want to 100% the game.


For what it's worth the game wasn't bad it was game that had a few things going for it and a few things that could of have been improved on.

If I had to rate it out of 10 it would be
7/10 Not a bad game but not a great game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Short version:+ Amazing detective story
+ Background stories of characters to uncover
+ Possess cats and never ending cigarette
+ No need to use doors, just walk through walls
- Obviously made for consoles
-- Boring and linear gameplay
-- No action, apart from demons

= 6.5/10

Long version:First of all, this game has a Metascore of 59/100 and I can kind of understand why. This is not about the story or the characters, but mainly because of the gameplay.

WARNING: minor spoilers (not really spoilers, but just in case, you know). Marked them.

Story: The story is simply ah-ma-zing. In my opinion, it’s a great murder mystery in which you have to solve your own death (and prevent others from dying too). The whole ghost-idea is greatly elaborated in the story and makes the whole thing quite original: you’re not the usual cop who has to solve the usual murder mystery. The game has some great (and by that I mean unexpected and mind-blowing) plot twists. And, honestly, I didn’t expect the actual murderer to be the murderer, if you know what I mean.

Characters: I LOVE how the characters’ stories become clear throughout the game. Most of the characters’ stories are quite vague when you start the game, but as you progress and collect artifacts, you learn more about each one of them. It made me want to keep playing, not only to know who my killer was, but also to know more about other people’s lives and deaths (and Ronan’s tattoos, for example). The side quests are nice additions to the story; they aren’t very long, but quite interesting, too. The main characters aren't really stereotypes, in my opinion. For example, the fact that Ronan was a gangster himself while he was young, doesn’t make him the stereotype cop (not really sure if spoiler, but marked just in case). It makes the game much more interesting than your usual detective story. The side characters, on the other hand, are much more flat and typical.

Gameplay: Not great. Even boring, after a while. You walk around in Salem, investigate surroundings to find clues, possess people (and cats!), hide from and defeat demons, poltergeist stuff, and, well, that’s about it. It’s the same thing over and over again, for the maximum of 15 hours of gameplay the game has to offer (one playthrough). No real puzzles, just looking around and finding things. No real action, I believe there’s a maximum of 20 demons to defeat throughout the game. The combat is boring: you have to sneak up to them and kill them with nothing but your bare hands. You have no defense apart from some hiding spots. The demons are in my opinion unnecessary and only a burden to the game. The game’s pretty linear, too. You have no choice but to follow the storyline. Between cutscenes, you can walk around freely in Salem and the areas you’ve already visited throughout the story.

Also, it’s obvious this is a game made for consoles, not for pc. I mean, “Press START”? You’re joking, right? You’re unable to change the controls, so if you’re playing with an AZERTY-keyboard, you’ll have to change the language settings of your pc. I really recommend playing this with a controller, if you have one: it suits the overall gameplay much better.

Other: Great graphics. The creepy music fits the atmosphere and story perfectly. Good voice acting. Achievements are relatively easy to obtain, apart from some artifacts. Also, DO NOT ENTER THE MUSEUM IN THE END OF THE GAME before you’ve collected all artifacts! You won’t be able to return, or play the whole game from the start to collect the missing ones.

Conclusion: I was doubting whether I would go for recommended or not, since the gameplay is such a disappointment. I did go for recommended, because I haven’t seen such a great and original detective story in all my life.

I wouldn’t recommend buying this game if it’s not on sale: €30 ($37.5?) is way too pricey in my opinion.
Like detectives, murder mysteries and story-driven games? I guess you can give this a shot.
Want action, adventure and shooting? Not the right game for you.

reviewText:
Spent 14 hours to finish this game and get almost all of the collectibles, except the Ghost Girl Messages because they were hard to find and I was too lazy to backtrack and find them all. So here's my take on the game.

Gameplay:Many people compare this with L.A. Noire but I think the two games are vastly different. This game leans more towards an adventure game, if I have to find another game to compare it with, this game is pretty close in concept to the Blackwell Series (which is awesome, go grab it) in that the game asks you to solve a murder mistery and also help other spirits move on by helping them to know why they died and resolve their situation. In a way, it's almost a 3D version of the Blackwell series, with the emphasis on adventure, finding clues and solving puzzles.

Some people complained that the stealth action parts of this game (exorcising demons) are too difficult and annoying. I think it's not that difficult, but if you DO find it hard and it breaks the game for you, there's a simple cheat/patch out there that you can use to completely nullify the stealth action parts and turn it entirely into an adventure game, which might help make this game infinitely better for you.

Story:Personally, I think the story is the main strong point of this game. As a lover of classic supernatural adventure games, such as the Gabriel Knight series, this IS the game for me. I also love games that are based on history or cult stories (such as the Assassin's Creed series), and knowing that this game mixed some real history (the Salem witch trials) to the plot just makes it more immersive for me. There is even one character from the Salem witch trials history that appears here, which might surprise some that are in the know of this story.

But as with any story out there, like when watching a movie or reading a book, this section is entirely subjective and either you like it or you don't. If you find out that you don't like the premise, then you have no reason to play this game at all, as there is nothing else to find here if you dislike the story. It will quickly get boring for you.

Graphics:Played this game on my ASUS laptop with GeForce GT650M 2GB DDR3 graphics and the game runs fine on mostly high settings (see the screenshot I posted of this game for more details) with no stuttering framerates or slowdowns. The graphic quality is awesome and totally realistic, from the facial expressions of the characters to the textures and clothings. Ronan, especially, is rendered with truly amazing detail, I was a bit speechless when I saw his semi-transparent ultra-detailed character model during the opening moments. If you have a decent graphics card, this game can render truly amazing details for your enjoyment.

Sound:Voice acting is very good, especially for the lead character Ronan. The music and ambient sounds successfully brings out the haunting and crreepy atmosphere of the story. The sound effect is carefully designed to great effect, especially the shrieks of those demons which can literally get you jumping out of your seat if you're playing with headphones on during the middle of the night.

Weakness:There is no in-game map. But the town of Salem is not that large and pretty soon you will be able to get your bearings around town by memory alone. The only difficult route to remember was probably the one that leads to the church, because you need to take a specific route to get there. If you're worried about getting all the collectibles, there are a lot of guides and videos out there that can help you, so you don't have to worry about that at all.

Verdict:7.0 - A must buy for mystery/murder/detective adventure game lovers out there, especially those who loved the Gabriel Knight or the Blackwell series.

TIP: Don't buy it with the full price. This game often goes on sale, so better wait for it to go on sale and grab it. I got it for just $3.99 during the most recent Square Enix sale.

TIP #2: Play with a game controller, not with a keyboard and mouse. It will make a whole lot of difference and can make or break the game for some people.

reviewText: Set in the notorious New England town of Salem, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a ghost story themed murder mystery investigation game. I recommend this game to all who value story, atmosphere and interesting characters and setting, as well as collectibles over fast-paced fighting or trial and error gameplay. The best part of the game is slowly unlocking the riddle surrounding your own murder and many others, as well as piecing together the stories of lost souls you encounter along the way. Generally speaking, the puzzles are very easy (by comparison with something like Monkey Island) and the QTE combat is so trivial it might as well not exist. If you can get it on sale it is a nice experience with loads of good cutscenes, some nice dialogue and a well written story.

In fact, the 'avoid / destroy the demons' parts almost came close to that and were more irritating than adding anything to the gameplay IMO.

If a sequel came out I'd probably be willing to pay £15 for it.

reviewText:
TL;DR; 7/10

This game is done very well. The features they implemented in it (like going through stuff, blocking off places thus hiding object from you, etc.) are good.
However the controls are a little bit wonky. Sometimes you need to perfectly aim your sight to get what you want. One of the main features of the game is introduced late and not used as often as they could have.
The story is is entertaining, but not the best. Eventually everything's coming together and there's a big surprise at the end. However if the bad guy had more role throughout the game, it could had a better score.
I really can't tell anything on the graphics, my computer can't handle it on full details. But it didn't look bad. :)

If it is on sale, get it. ;)

reviewText:
To be honest, I feel that this game got a lot more flack than was deserved. Is it perfect? No, but I think the criticisms were a bit extreme. Mind you, most of the criticisms I read were during the time that it was initially released and some of it had to do with bugs.
I'm guessing that by the time I bought the game (4 months after release) all those bugs were fixed because I didn't really have any of the issues that they were talking about. There were times, however, I noticed that the narration would cut out. This happened in maybe 3-5 different cutscenes were there was just no sound at all - the only way I knew what was supposed to have been said during the scene was because I always have subtitles on.

I think what hurt the game more than anything else was the story. It was okay, but I feel that it could have been better - more developed maybe. Also I feel like the characters were poorly written.
I say this because I felt no emotion towards any of them whatsover. The wife was annoying, and there were too many random collectibles of her memories with him - I'm guessing like finding pages of her diary or something scattered around. I felt myself annoyed with all of these and couldn't care less about her or their relationship.

The friendship or, partnership I guess, between Ronan and Joy felt really shallow. Since Joy is the character Ronan interacts with the most throughout the game, I was hoping for more development in their friendship.  Also the way Joy treated Ronan after he saves her from The Bell Killer is ridiculous. I'm not expecting her to want to help him right away but it was a bit much imho

I couldn't even find myself caring about Ronan himself. None of the characters in the game were developed enough for me to root for them or care about them in anyway.

Also I felt it was strange that all the events in the entire game takes place in one night. Why on earth was that one couple getting married in the middle of the night / wee hours of the morning?

The demons in the game were laughable. It felt like it was just thrown in at the last minute to give the game some kind of combat in it. They should have either given the combat more diversity or taken the demons out completely, in my opinion. I didn't play the game with combat in mind so I wouldn't have cared if there was no combat in this game. There are perfectly good Adventure Mystery games with absolutely no combat in it (the majority of Sherlock Holmes titles for example).

With all that negative out of the way now for the positives: I appreciate the game trying to do something different. I'm a big fan of Adventure Mystery type games and one that approaches it from the perspective of a ghost is innovative and interesting. I enjoyed walking through walls and possessing adorable felines, as well as the people around town.
It would have been great if they expanded a bit more on this - more animals to possess, control over individuals in town like how Abigail was able to control humans to do her killings  , as well as being able to poltergeist more items.

To sum up my review, I would recommend people to give the game a go. It's enjoyable and fun and I definitely don't think it deserved 59 on metacritic. I would rate it more of a 6/10. It's worth a play through to get to play and experience something different. The mystery is also relatively engaging.
I just wouldn't get this game at full price - wait for a sale. I was able to scoop it up during one for 4.99.

reviewText: Once you get past the fact that this is a port and has no configurable controls (stuck to wasd), its a very enjoyable game. I played it with the xbox controller in the end. I enjoyed every minute of it and will undoubtedly play again.

reviewText:
I was put off this game initially due to negative reports about its length, and so the base price of £20 was enough to give me pause. However, when it appeared on sale for £5 I decided to give it a chance and I am very glad I did.

The star of this game is its story, where you play as the ghost of Ronan O'Connor, a detective in modern day Salem. For a large part it feels like a point and click adventure game where the emphasis is on finding the pieces and putting them together rather than on any sort of direct action. Gameplay revolves around investigations that are heavily reminiscent of L.A. Noire (another game I really enjoyed) except you can walk through walls and interrogating people is mostly replaced with possessing them to influence their mind. Perhaps owing to the length of the story (it only took me around 8hrs to complete the main quest, all side quests and most collectibles) both the story and gameplay never outstayed their welcome and remained entertaining to the very end.

The main negative in this game is the repetitive forced stealth segments where you are forced to sneak up on demonic spirits before a simple quick time event is entered in place of combat. I felt even after the first of these that it was an unnecessary mechanic designed as a buffer between me and the enjoyable parts of the game. I would commonly find myself sweeping an area of these enemies" before returning to start the section proper. Thankfully
date: they don't take too long and aren't difficult
recommended: but this just emphasises how needless they are.\n\nI would definitely recommend this as a sale pickup if you are even remotely curious."

reviewText:
As a HUGE adventure fan that almost always prefers a classic 2D click'n'point adventure, Murdered: Soul suspect is a breath of fresh air to everything the adventure genre has to offer. The graphics are just amazing, and thanks to the Unreal engine, the game runs smooth as butther with everything maxed out.

V-sync limits the game to 30FPS, but you can switch that off and just enable V-sync in your GPU options (Catalyst Control or Nvidia center) which gives you all the smooth awesomeness of 60FPS.

The story of this game is brilliant, and the spooky atmosphere just adds to the overall setting of the game. The way you interact with your surrounding and figure out the clues is great, but I was hoping getting stuff wrong would give you a penalty of some kind... Then again, it is an adventure game and most of them are very linear.

There is no combat apart from banishing demons witch can be really difficult at some parts but nothing an average gamer can't figure out.

I was afraid that the ending will be a dissapointment compared to the massive build up of the story (and the bodies murdered) but the game really delivered. After YEARS of trying to find something different and new in the adventure game genre, Murdered: Soul suspect finally brings tons of new mechanics, great voice acting, an amazing story and a beautiful engine to finally burst life into a slumbered genre.

Hats off to the devs and the writters.

reviewText: Murdered: Soul Suspect is engaging and enjoyable.  The atmosphere and graphics are great.  You explore Salem and 'ghost Salem' as a ghost and as a detective, solving your case and many side cases along the way.  Ghost Salem physically exists for ghosts, as a barrier which prevents you from accessing areas of Salem too easily and as a mode of access to collectables in areas you wouldn't have access to in normal Salem e.g. ghost stairs.\nThere is a lot to engage with: collectables (too many, in my opinion), stories to unlock, ghosts hanging around (they say the best things in the graveyard).  It does get repetative and there isn't a challange.  The game is easy to beat but there's still a small amount of action such as dealing with demons.  I find the game satisfactory for entertaining, easy gameplay but I wouldn't pay $30 for it.  Maybe if it was more challanging, everything down to the puzzles are simple.

reviewText: This game has one of the strongest openings I've seen in quite some time.  The ghost mechanics work well and feel good. reviewText:
To be honest, I feel that this game got a lot more flack than was deserved. Is it perfect? No, but I think the criticisms were a bit extreme. Mind you, most of the criticisms I read were during the time that it was initially released and some of it had to do with bugs.
I'm guessing that by the time I bought the game (4 months after release) all those bugs were fixed because I didn't really have any of the issues that they were talking about. There were times, however, I noticed that the narration would cut out. This happened in maybe 3-5 different cutscenes were there was just no sound at all - the only way I knew what was supposed to have been said during the scene was because I always have subtitles on.

I think what hurt the game more than anything else was the story. It was okay, but I feel that it could have been better - more developed maybe. Also I feel like the characters were poorly written.
I say this because I felt no emotion towards any of them whatsover. The wife was annoying, and there were too many random collectibles of her memories with him - I'm guessing like finding pages of her diary or something scattered around. I felt myself annoyed with all of these and couldn't care less about her or their relationship.

The friendship or, partnership I guess, between Ronan and Joy felt really shallow. Since Joy is the character Ronan interacts with the most throughout the game, I was hoping for more development in their friendship.  Also the way Joy treated Ronan after he saves her from The Bell Killer is ridiculous. I'm not expecting her to want to help him right away but it was a bit much imho

I couldn't even find myself caring about Ronan himself. None of the characters in the game were developed enough for me to root for them or care about them in anyway.

Also I felt it was strange that all the events in the entire game takes place in one night. Why on earth was that one couple getting married in the middle of the night / wee hours of the morning?

The demons in the game were laughable. It felt like it was just thrown in at the last minute to give the game some kind of combat in it. They should have either given the combat more diversity or taken the demons out completely, in my opinion. I didn't play the game with combat in mind so I wouldn't have cared if there was no combat in this game. There are perfectly good Adventure Mystery games with absolutely no combat in it (the majority of Sherlock Holmes titles for example).

With all that negative out of the way now for the positives: I appreciate the game trying to do something different. I'm a big fan of Adventure Mystery type games and one that approaches it from the perspective of a ghost is innovative and interesting. I enjoyed walking through walls and possessing adorable felines, as well as the people around town.
It would have been great if they expanded a bit more on this - more animals to possess, control over individuals in town like how Abigail was able to control humans to do her killings  , as well as being able to poltergeist more items.

To sum up my review, I would recommend people to give the game a go. It's enjoyable and fun and I definitely don't think it deserved 59 on metacritic. I would rate it more of a 6/10. It's worth a play through to get to play and experience something different. The mystery is also relatively engaging.
I just wouldn't get this game at full price - wait for a sale. I was able to scoop it up during one for 4.99.

reviewText:
TL;DR; 7/10

This game is done very well. The features they implemented in it (like going through stuff, blocking off places thus hiding object from you, etc.) are good.
However the controls are a little bit wonky. Sometimes you need to perfectly aim your sight to get what you want. One of the main features of the game is introduced late and not used as often as they could have.
The story is is entertaining, but not the best. Eventually everything's coming together and there's a big surprise at the end. However if the bad guy had more role throughout the game, it could had a better score.
I really can't tell anything on the graphics, my computer can't handle it on full details. But it didn't look bad. :)

If it is on sale, get it. ;)

reviewText: Only played a couple of hours but already clear this is a pretty decent offering if you're into something a little moody and at the same time not macabre. Imagine an clue exploration game with the investigations from LA Noire with a paranormal twist. There's tons to discover, lots of parallel stories and investigations going on, and reasonably unique gameplay mechanics. These don't always work so well, for example prompts don't highlight unless you move around to a certain angle, etc. But overall very decent experience, and worth getting on sale - not full price. The graphics are a little rough, especially character animation, but they set the tone very well nonetheless. I'd say a solid 6/10, which is fine if you can get it for an affordable price.

reviewText:
WELCOME TO SALEM, THE CITY OF THE UNEXPECTED
I had high expectations for this game, and even though it disappointing me for being kind of linear to play, actually the mystery involved in the game, and the way the narrate it, its quite good and it will make you wish to finish it till the truth is discovered.

Pros:

- Amazing plot.
- Very cool narrative.
- Ghosts stories about how they died, its quite human and realistic. A pleasure to read.
- Good voice actors.
- Music its ok, but I think it should been better.
- The ending, if you are clever maybe you will figure out at some point of the game who is the culprit. But when you discovered the truth, there is some shocking stuff you will not foreseen.


Cons:

- The game its kind of linear, it gets easy sometimes.
- The game have some bugs, so far I experienced the follow bugs:
* The game froze out of the blue sometimes.
* Sometimes the bots get stuck when they are supposed to move.
* The game closes by itself, just because. - _-

Luckily, this bugs happens just rarely, but still, a game which was released a year ago, should've all of this already fixed.

8/10, I had a lot of fun with this game. but I recommend to buy it on a sale.

reviewText: During my time with Murdered: Soul Suspect, it felt like a spark of unique features in the sea of games that feel like we are recycling the same ideas and concepts over and over. It was definitely an interesting title combining LA Noire's use of interacting with objects and no hand holding while you piece the scene together and choose the correct action from a list that is revealed once you reveal parts of what happened. However I would have liked to see more of a choice in how you progress making some choices lead you down the wrong path and some that if you dig deep enough into the scene it could progress you closer to the killer. To a trained eye a lot of the story becomes easy to pick up but still has some twists like any good murder mystery would. In all I enjoyed my time with the story and ghost/investigation mechanics even if it felt a little short (I think an extra 1-2 hours would have been about perfect for time spent in the game).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a game where you are a police detective and you have to solve your own murder and can solve other cases in the meantime (while you're a ghost). The game takes place in Salem, Massachusetts and uses the Salem Witch Trials as the premis for the story. The game appears to be educational on the subject, but I can't tell you if everything they reference is fact; I did learn that Germany also had witch trials decades earlier.

I had no technical issues with the game and I completed the game over the weekend in around eight hours. I enjoyed it enough that I played through it over two days. It's not at all a difficult or challenging game, but I feel like it was different enough to make me want to play through, help people, and find out what I could regarding the story and I was pleased.

The replay value is very low to me, but it was definitely worth the one playthrough.

reviewText:
An amazing game if you know what your paying for..

It's not a 3rd person adventure game like Assassin's Creed or Sleeping Dogs

If you go into the game realizing that it's a new take on the old point and click adventure games where you solve puzzles and experience a narrative, then your much more likely to enjoy yourself.

That being said, Murdered: Soul Suspect, does a few things really well.

- Great Characters, they're very well done and you'll find yourself really caring about what happens to them.
- Voice work is top notch
- Extra items / Side Cases come with their own ghost stories that will have you scouring the area to make sure you collect all of them.
- Setting is dark and creepy yet it feels alive thanks to all the townspeople spread throughout salem

As with any game though there are negatives of course

- The demonic / exorcism dynamic of combat feels more like an afterthought meant to draw in more gamers than a mechanic that was developed to really add depth to the gameplay.
- While the voicework itself is excellent.. the characters lip syncing is not as great.  Not terrible, but it's something you'll definitely pick up on from time to time.
- Even though there are plenty of citizens walking about and interacting with the enviroment; there is a lot of dialogue that's used on multiple people.  Also once you decide to read their thoughts and the voiceover starts; you have to wait for it to finish before  you can listen to the next or disposses them.

If you see it on sale definitely pick it up.  I managed to find this on Gamer's Gate for 13.99

reviewText: Great game on sale, got it dirt cheap not expecting too much but it ended up surprising me.  Would not buy it for full price though.  The only thing that sucks about the game are the demon encounters, they just feel out of place and unnecessary.  The game has a good enough story and investigation/exploration sections that it doesn't need the demon sections at all.  It's a real shame because the idea had potential too.  I was hoping for something in the vein of demons being disguised as regular ghosts trying to trick you into making bad decisions via dialogue options to steal your soul but instead they're patrolling enemies that you have to avoid and stealth kill.  The most annoying thing is when they detect you for no reason whatsoever or when you are in exactly the correct position to execute them and get no prompt to do so.  These sections are a pretty small portion of the game though and there's only a handful of them.  Anyone whose played any stealth oriented games will have no problems with them outside of the issues mentioned above.\n\nOverall, it was a great story with a couple twists on the end that I just didn't see coming.  The game is worth a playthrough if you're looking for something different that's story driven and not action packed.  Voice acting was great too, Ronan and Joy are both likable characters with tons of personality.  Will probably play this again at some point to get all the collectables and do the side missions that I missed.

reviewText:
Pros: Interesting game, good voice acting, nice premise.  Like an interactive novel.

Cons:  Known bugs that never got fixed before release to Steam and still aren't fixed.  Game essentially becomes unplayable if a mouse is used in certain menus because you cannot escape from the menu.  Fix is: don't use a mouse in clue menus.  Or use a gamepad controller.

Seriously Sqenix, I understand you trying to cash in on your old properties that you own, but try some QA once in a while.

Verdict: Play with a gamepad, and it's a nice story.

reviewText:
Get it when it is cheap - it is short and has no replay value beyond collecting things, and you cannot revisit earlier areas after reaching the finale. Overall, it is a pretty decent unfinished business ghost story. It comes equipped with the ex-con cop, lovable scamp sidekick, some plot twists, and posessing cats and people to get to locations your short-range ghost teleport can't reach. The setting was interesting to me, and there were some small jokes in a few levels such as ghost hunters in the cemetary, and a ghost right in front of the camera smiling and waving - that nobody can see.

The levels are fairly well designed, although some clues require more accuracy in placement with how close to other clues they are. The demons were interesting at first but quickly became just an annoyance once you near the end of the game. Most areas are once and done, although you do revisit one of the opening areas as part of the plot and can return to areas up until the finale.

This is mostly an adventure game - the only notable action sequences are exorcising demons, a single section where you have to deal with a ghost train ( which was pretty neat ), and the finale, and even then they are more or less quick time events. The rest of the game is spent navigating the hub

You are unable to change the controls if you use the mouse and keyboard. The game itself doesn't have too many poor performance spots aside from some area transitions and, at least in my case, antialiasing smoke/fog during the opening sequence.

The collectables were mostly pointless - the story parts, such as the water tank, rifles, saws, gas tanks, etc. were brief ghost stories - generic, but not poorly written.

Overall, I feel the main issue is how short the game is - the entire plot encompasses a single night and will only really take three or four hours at most, and feels like a large chunk of that time was exorcising demons and getting to the next area. If you remove the travel time and scavenger hunt, it was rather short and would probably fit inside two hours.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just wow.
This game is such an amazing and unusual experience. A grim detective story with such a vivid characters, voice acting and visual style. This is a great game, which contsits a half of exploration and a half of interactive movie. Exploration, even if limited, is done in really interesting plain - you're a ghost, and thus you can walk through walls, collect and read ghostly notes and hints, learn about places and their stories. You will investigate some simple problems by collecting evidence, looking and listening. The 'movie' part is done nice. The plot is pretty interesting, although so simple. Sometimes I was wondering, when my character will figure out the killer. I mean, I partly looked through it before the game called the killer. However even by figuring out what was happening I've never seen who exactly was the one to blame. And there was yet another unexpected twist. So even if plot is slightly predictable, It's written dam-good. Definitely a movie I liked to play.
I loved cats in this game. Just like cats should be in games. Fast, black, agile, a little glitchy. What I didn't like about them was how people react them. Like zero F-s were given that night.
I loved that monitor reference in police station. You'll know when you see it. Square Enix, oh you.
Now to the downsides:
1. This is a game best played with a gamepad. I mean it. It wasn't made to be on PC, it was made to be cross-platform. So even if it supports keyboard+mouse, use a controller, if you have one.
2. There is no free roam after you've reached the last checkpoint. The main menu will offer you to continue, but this is merely a last checkpoint, no way to collect something you've left for later.
3. Not sure about the reason, but sometimes I've experienced minor graphic glitches while ui showed/hided collected piece of evidence. Might be just my laptop.
4. Repetative faces of pedestrians. There's something like two or three models for each gender. Nuff said.
5. Really strange placement of hiding spots. Some places have plenty of them, but never needed. The others feature but a few spots, but you will need more if you need them. And some are too far to jump between them.
6. Font. Handwriting fonts in games never work as easy-to-read fonts. And this game has tons of handwritten text. Although I managed to read without problems, some might have them.

But in the end, I really enjoyed this game. It's certainly a great experience.

reviewText:
This game has a great concept, a captivating artstyle, and a fairly interesting story. The voice acting is good, the characters are overall quite believeable, and you get quite invested in the game's narrative.

On the negative side, the game gives you a huge sandbox to play in with a bunch of new toys, but what few activities you are able to complete within this open world are fairly lacklustre and are basic extensions of the same game mechanics you use during the main story. It would have been a lot more engaging if you were free to roam within this world, and had interesting things to do in it.

Overall, recommended for its mechanics, artstyle and interesting story. Suitable for fans of L.A. Noire, and similar detective games.

reviewText: Enjoyable story-driven murder mystery. Not really exceptional in any way, but the story and mechanics are interesting. You play a detective who becomes a ghost and thus can walk through walls and do other ghostly stuff while investigating a series of murders. While item collection is heavily featured, it doesn't seem simply shoehorned in to increase the game's length. Each item you collect contributes in some way to the story background/context. The only part that got repetitive and predictable was the demon mechanic: I felt it only interrupted your progress while you dealt with them essentially the same way in every level.\n\nRecommended for its enjoyable story and original mechanics.

reviewText:
WELCOME TO SALEM, THE CITY OF THE UNEXPECTED
I had high expectations for this game, and even though it disappointing me for being kind of linear to play, actually the mystery involved in the game, and the way the narrate it, its quite good and it will make you wish to finish it till the truth is discovered.

Luckily, this bugs happens just rarely, but still, a game which was released a year ago, should've all of this already fixed.

8/10, I had a lot of fun with this game. but I recommend to buy it on a sale.

I was more interested in the plot and exploring the world as a ghost than anything else, so it was a bit annoying whenever they made me fight those flying demons, as it eventually gets a bit... repetitive. reviewText:
The game has a good story, nice environments and believable characters with solid voice overs. Actually, it could have been one of those interactive movies if not these two things.

First of all, it's completely linear. The main story and a few side quests. The only variable is whether you find all the collectibles (they are all related to the lore) or not. More likely, not - looking for every collectible is just too boring and doesn't provide much new information.

Secondly, for some reason the creators tried to add more depth to gameplay and introduced demons that you need to hide from or kill stealthily. And it just doesn't work. Too easy for any Thief (Splinter Cell, Hitman, etc) player and too boring on top of that. Thankfully, those moments with demons are really short and sometimes you can simply run through them and then hide.

Despide the flaws, I still recommend playing it. Basically, it's like watching a good movie. Perhaps you can even be surprised in the end!

reviewText:
I rather enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the story, and the level of player engagement seemed spot-on for this quick, story-driven game.

On the other hand; I did encounter some repetitiveness in the dialog after a bit. The puzzle solving felt a little forced, and didn't have alternative scenarios if you chased down the wrong lead.

Gameplay: I usually don't like the over-the-shoulder gameplay style. I found it gave me some issue when trying to interact with some objects, but it wasn't too obtrusive.

Combat: The enemies were laughable, all you had to do was sneak up behind them and perform an action - a random button/mouseclick which is a direct port over to the button/paddle on the console. I found these enemies to be more of an obsticle than an actual challenge. But I belive this is intended, as to keep the game story focused and not combat driven. I actually salute the developers for remaining story focused and not bogging down the player with ubsurd mechanics or prolonged battles... or health bars for that matter (You're already dead! No health for you!)

Collectables & Achievements: Many players have complained that they were unable to go back and complete the collectable achievements, as this has a very linear progression in the story. This will often require a second playthrough, stopping at each location, and clearing the zone to ensure you have collected everything. I kept catching myself thinking in normal gameplay rules, where I would walk around walls and objects. Just remember, you can walk through that. There are still barriers - ghostly walls and santified buildings - that prevent you from passing through everything.

Due to a bug in the final fight, I didn't finish the game. After many many attempts, I kept starting the scene in a void zone, where I couldn't escape, or didn't have enough time to complete my objective after I escaped. I have not read of this bug happening to other players. YMMV. I did see alot of weird, creepy stuff in this game, but this is the only only thing I would call buggy.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is a great story. It's a mediocre game but I enjoyed the story so much I have to recommend this.
It has great atmosphere, very nice graphics and a very appealing main story. It's a unique take on detective stories with a supernatural flavor. The investigations are easy but the findings are not trivial and kept adding real new information throughout the game. Only when I was very close to the end of the game was I able to figure all the pieces, meaning the game keeps the tension very well.
However, Murdered: Soul Suspect also has linear progression, too trivial investigations, many collectibles which I did not find interesting and sort of bland side investigations and strange stealth combat.

For me the game really picked up when I stopped trying to collect everything and doing every side mission. So, I recommend this game with a suggestion to stick with the main story.

reviewText:
I just finished this game an hour ago.  I'm not sure why people feels the need to write a review without finishing the game, if I had judged the game after an hour of playing it I would have turned it down too, but after an hour you're not attached to anything, if you're looking for instant gratification in a detective game, you should have never even installed it.

At first the fact that its a console port nearly turned me off to it but I trudged on and found that its not all that bad.  I would recommend the game for those who likes the detective style game.

PROS
------------------------------
* Well made storyline
* Wealth of history about Salem during the Salem Witch Trials
* Ronin and Joy are pretty memorable characters
* Pretty original gameplay elements, such as modern infrastructure infusing with past infrastructure.
* Great sudden turn of events often
* Fair amount of collectibles to learn about side missions and such
* Cinematics and voice acting are very well put together

CONS
------------------------------
* Console port, you can't rebind keys which leads to mistakes sometimes, especially during QT events
* Quick time events are annoying when you're trying to do them with a keyboard/mouse
* Some glitches, but nothing game breaking
* Not well optimized for PC, often stutters a little

reviewText:
Was a gift from a good friend of mine (Humble Bundle)
A mix of adventure, detective mystery solving game.

Seriously, just don't hover near the spoilers if you haven't played the game yet

Pros :
- Interesting storyline
- The town looks great with the mix of  a past (ghost) and present theme
- Voice Acting
- Plot twist!
- A game that  lets you play as a cat
- Being a ghost is somehow fun
- Unique playstyle

Cons :
- The story is too linear.  Putting routes on stories and additional mini quest is fine
- Demons  Stealth in a detective mystery game sounds good but really, screeching demons who chase you but they leave you once you move in a specific spot. Also, sometimes annoying...
- Save slots would be fine. You have to replay the game once you finish/restart to the last checkpoint (A bit of a hassle when it comes to achievement farming)
- Point and click. Investigations are kind of easy since they already tell you where the clues are. You can just spam E in the map and you'll probably find the clue
- NPCs - just remove some of the  mind reading  or just  keep them silent . It's confusing  when you're looking for clues
- Locked to 30 FPS....
- Cutscenes...  A skip button would be nice if you die or restart from another checkpoint
- Too short (Finished within 9.6 hours - including breaks)



Needs a lot more improvement still. Would buy a sequel if there is one
Better buy it on sale.
