reviewText:
I rather enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the story, and the level of player engagement seemed spot-on for this quick, story-driven game.

On the other hand; I did encounter some repetitiveness in the dialog after a bit. The puzzle solving felt a little forced, and didn't have alternative scenarios if you chased down the wrong lead.

Gameplay: I usually don't like the over-the-shoulder gameplay style. I found it gave me some issue when trying to interact with some objects, but it wasn't too obtrusive.

Combat: The enemies were laughable, all you had to do was sneak up behind them and perform an action - a random button/mouseclick which is a direct port over to the button/paddle on the console. I found these enemies to be more of an obsticle than an actual challenge. But I belive this is intended, as to keep the game story focused and not combat driven. I actually salute the developers for remaining story focused and not bogging down the player with ubsurd mechanics or prolonged battles... or health bars for that matter (You're already dead! No health for you!)

Collectables & Achievements: Many players have complained that they were unable to go back and complete the collectable achievements, as this has a very linear progression in the story. This will often require a second playthrough, stopping at each location, and clearing the zone to ensure you have collected everything. I kept catching myself thinking in normal gameplay rules, where I would walk around walls and objects. Just remember, you can walk through that. There are still barriers - ghostly walls and santified buildings - that prevent you from passing through everything.

Due to a bug in the final fight, I didn't finish the game. After many many attempts, I kept starting the scene in a void zone, where I couldn't escape, or didn't have enough time to complete my objective after I escaped. I have not read of this bug happening to other players. YMMV. I did see alot of weird, creepy stuff in this game, but this is the only only thing I would call buggy.

reviewText:
As the game begins we find Ronan exploding out of a shattered 4th story window after a confrontation with a shadowy figure.  He awakens to find himself temporarily disembodied but that state soon becomes permanent upon the arrival of the Bell Witch Killer.  Shot 7 times with his own gun, Ronan must now solve the mystery of his own murder and in the process uncover dark secrets that have haunted Salem for centuries.

Quite a build up eh?

It is and it's worthy of it.  The story is intriguing with twists, turns and dead ends to thrill any devotee of the mystery genre.  Add in a tastefully done horror component supported by an eerie backdrop of a dark and gloomy Salem complete with lost souls, haunted houses, and frightful demons.

The game is gorgeous even on my creaky old gaming laptop ( circa 2008 ) and the controls simple.  You're led on a path similar to the Call of Duty campaign modes on the hunt for clues to your own murder.  On the way you'll find ample opportunity to complete side quests but be warned if like me you seek to earn all of the Steam achievements you must be methodical in your approach.  For me it took 2 playthroughs as there is no quicksave nor any way to go back once you've completed the final chapter of the game.

It's a casual game but it can be maddening at times.  For one, you have no onscreen map nor any way to mark your progress toward achievements.  Meaning you'll spend a lot of time running in circles to find the way forward and backtracking for that one elusive clue.

Then there's the demons.  I understand that a game in the horror genre has to have some kind of threat but they're all over the place.  It breaks the flow of the narrative and it's jarring to go from a casual detective story to a flurry of button mashing every 10 minutes.

Still, even with the more gamey" aspects
date: it's still more ghost story than game which explains some of its mechanical shortcomings.  My first playthrough was simply for the sake of taking it all in.  The second was purely for my own desire to see everything and in the process earn every Steam achievement.\n\nAll tolled I've spent a bit over 30 hours and enjoyed every minute of it."

reviewText:
To be honest, I feel that this game got a lot more flack than was deserved. Is it perfect? No, but I think the criticisms were a bit extreme. Mind you, most of the criticisms I read were during the time that it was initially released and some of it had to do with bugs.
I'm guessing that by the time I bought the game (4 months after release) all those bugs were fixed because I didn't really have any of the issues that they were talking about. There were times, however, I noticed that the narration would cut out. This happened in maybe 3-5 different cutscenes were there was just no sound at all - the only way I knew what was supposed to have been said during the scene was because I always have subtitles on.

I think what hurt the game more than anything else was the story. It was okay, but I feel that it could have been better - more developed maybe. Also I feel like the characters were poorly written.
I say this because I felt no emotion towards any of them whatsover. The wife was annoying, and there were too many random collectibles of her memories with him - I'm guessing like finding pages of her diary or something scattered around. I felt myself annoyed with all of these and couldn't care less about her or their relationship.

The friendship or, partnership I guess, between Ronan and Joy felt really shallow. Since Joy is the character Ronan interacts with the most throughout the game, I was hoping for more development in their friendship.  Also the way Joy treated Ronan after he saves her from The Bell Killer is ridiculous. I'm not expecting her to want to help him right away but it was a bit much imho

I couldn't even find myself caring about Ronan himself. None of the characters in the game were developed enough for me to root for them or care about them in anyway.

Also I felt it was strange that all the events in the entire game takes place in one night. Why on earth was that one couple getting married in the middle of the night / wee hours of the morning?

The demons in the game were laughable. It felt like it was just thrown in at the last minute to give the game some kind of combat in it. They should have either given the combat more diversity or taken the demons out completely, in my opinion. I didn't play the game with combat in mind so I wouldn't have cared if there was no combat in this game. There are perfectly good Adventure Mystery games with absolutely no combat in it (the majority of Sherlock Holmes titles for example).

With all that negative out of the way now for the positives: I appreciate the game trying to do something different. I'm a big fan of Adventure Mystery type games and one that approaches it from the perspective of a ghost is innovative and interesting. I enjoyed walking through walls and possessing adorable felines, as well as the people around town.
It would have been great if they expanded a bit more on this - more animals to possess, control over individuals in town like how Abigail was able to control humans to do her killings  , as well as being able to poltergeist more items.

To sum up my review, I would recommend people to give the game a go. It's enjoyable and fun and I definitely don't think it deserved 59 on metacritic. I would rate it more of a 6/10. It's worth a play through to get to play and experience something different. The mystery is also relatively engaging.
I just wouldn't get this game at full price - wait for a sale. I was able to scoop it up during one for 4.99.

reviewText:
You're a cop, you just got killed and you have to investigate your own murder and the case of the serial killer 'The Bell', who's going around killing young women in barbaric ways and slaughtering anyone who gets in his way. You'd think being dead would put something of a cramp on your investigative abilities, but no, it seems all the best cops are the dead ones. Maybe it's because it's late at night, but everybody except you seems to be doing about as much police activity as can be accomplished by standing around rubbing their noses.

You run into a teenage medium called Joy who's looking for her missing mom, and she comes in really handy for opening drawers, crossing glowing holes into hell that try and suck Ronan down, and so that Ronan's musing is cut by about 20%. The rest of the time she's a regular whiny teenager you have to play daddy wolf to and pretend you give a pooper about her mom.

The game revolves around investigating crime scenes - yours and other people's - talking to the many ghosts in Salem, uncovering lost memories, being the cause of poltergeist activity and posessing people to read their minds.

Occasionally to try and make you feel like there's more to the game than prodding at a crime-scene and musing over a cigarette, Demons spawn. Since they just float around on a set path looking for something to kill, and you creep up from behind to kill them, it feels very tacked on and a really crappy attempt at adding any challenge to the game.

All in all, the game feels a lot like an interactive horror movie, but it's a GOOD movie, and it feels like worthwhile interaction. Voice acting and character animation of faces is great. Is it worth full-price? That's a personal thing, seeing as it's quite a short game. But if you can get it at a discount, it's definitely a worthwhile way to spend some game-time.

Get it if you like: Detective games, Violent murder, Interaction, Creepiness, A good movie, Collecting stuff.

Don't get it if you like: Action, Challenge, Long games.

7/10

reviewText:
just finished the game and got to admit, it got me addicted to the story like a drug. Couldn't think of anything but wonder what the next clues will add to the story. To sum it up:
Story: 9/10
Although it's a typical murder investigation, playing as a ghost trying to uncover clues makes the mystery more interesting. The side stories obtained by finding all the hidden objects on each map are very spooky and a good bed time story to wet the bed.

Gameplay: 6/10
Although it's nice to find clues and unfold the mystery, it's veeery repetitive and lacks diversity. Not much you can do but run through walls, teleport short distances and kill a few demons. other than that, you get bored fast from gameplay and you just want to finish the story faster.

Graphics: 8/10
I can't say it's bad, i can't say it's good. For a 2014 game, objects are edgy, characters lack emotions, but still, it looks ok. It's the bad textures from clues that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.

Overall, i enjoyed the game very much, considering i got it on sale. I recommend it just to unwind from stressful multiplayer games and submerge in a story filled with mysteries.

PS: could play a cat.

reviewText:
When I first heard the announcement of Murdered: Soul Suspect, I thought this looked like an amazing idea for a video game. Then, I when it was released and officially reviewed by personalities on the internet, it was met with mixed opinion, the lesser of which delayed me from giving it a chance. During the Steam sale, I picked it up for a considerable discount, and decided for the price I paid that it would be worth it. I am happy to say, that, it's good enough to play through. Though, I doubt the replay value is remotely existant, for a couple of reasons:

CONS:

1) Awkward voice acting: At times when the character is supposed to have a cigarette in his mouth, the animation doesn't, so he ends up sounding like he's chewing on his tongue. This is awkward. But somewhat hilarious.

2) Awkward animation: For the same reason as #1, as well as as that when dialogue is being conveyed through other characters (e.g.: other souls), they flail their arms in a strange manner as they talk, obviously on a loop of animation that doesn't always fit with the dialogue. As for Ronan, he himself likes to move way too much in conversation. He moves his hips, he shuffles his feet, and he keeps shaking his head. He's either disappointed and frustrated with everybody, or he just can't get past the fact that he has no perception of touch when being dead.

3) Cliche: Personally, I've seen the gruff guy working together with spunky young girl" scenario too many times. It works for the characters

reviewText: This game was one I wanted to play when it first came out. I loved the game don't get me wrong...was a great game...just not worth the full price. Its a game you will want to pick up on sale. If you love collecting everything, there is plenty of that in here. Many small items to be found all over the city, and in each of the main spots you have to travel too to progress the game itself. The story is great, even though you may see most of it coming a mile away.  My one downfall I felt on it was the demons. They weren't used often enough, with that being said it made it feel they were more to just in your way, as well were the only enemy you had in the game. When trying to kill them it puts up different button presses, so be quick, or you will need to start running then play a game of musical chairs hiding till they go away. I do wish as well that your ghostly powers were more so needed to be used, but it was a bit of a let down as well.  Other then that I do hope that there will be another game, just hopfully they will add more too it. It was a great concept, but more could have been done. Once again its one I would say buy, just wait till its on sale.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed Murdered, I felt that the story was gripping, and the characters intriguing, and get this: a likeable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a main character! In other words, he is your archetypical d-bag with a sense of justice, but he is very intriguing, you’ll find out more about that as you play the game, since I don’t want to spoil anything, even minor details….

I will say that the “combat” is the weakest part of the game, but thankfully those are generally few and far in between, all it is, is a twist on cover based stealth system that is quite frankly very annoying and frustrating to say the least.

But by far the strongest point of the game is the investigation scenes, during which, you find clues and develop several inferences, thankfully the game doesn’t really hold your hand much in the way the Sherlock Holmes game does.

To keep this short, I do recommend the game, it isn’t perfect and certainly isn’t worth the asking price of 40-50 bucks, as the length leaves something to be desired.... I do encourage you to pick the game up if you happen to see it on sale for <$20
Happy Gaming :D

reviewText:
This is a great game for those who like stories. It is very cinematic and its storytelling involves the player in Ronan's story. It's more a mystery story than a horror one (even though it has some elements). I'm going to start reviewing from the negative stuff to the positive:
- Not being able to change the controls in PC is a joke. This will prevent left-handed people from playing and makes the only difficult spot more difficult by choosing ridiculous key controls
- That said, the game is not difficult at all (it's almost an interactive movie), though in certain spots the difficulty spikes due to the controls
- There's plenty of reading if you want to know the whole stories that make the side quests, but there's a bug in the game: if you want to read the stories of the items on the menu, press Enter, not the mouse
- There's plenty of stuff to do and to collect in the city and you have almost complete freedom to move around. Still I'd have liked the option of finishing the side quests before ending the game.
- The game design works great to make you feel like a ghost. I soon realised that even though I was dead I still tended to try to walk through doors instead of walls
- The experience is great.

Oh
recommended: you can posses cats. And meow."

Walk through walls like a ghost, but cannot on consecrated grounds

reviewText:
Plot: You have been Murdered (DURH), you being the Soul Suspect (get it, cause you are dead...) have to find the Bell Killer who is responsible for your own and other peoples deaths.

Gameplay: Look cool in a fedora and badass cop clothes as noclipping allows you to go through just about everything, that is not blue.You can also posses people and lisen to their thoughts, help read their memory look through thier eyes.Also you can detect stuff with all of your neat detective skills that are now much better in death apparently.

Graphics: Puppies dont even look this good.

Optimisation: Obviously inteded for use with a controller.The actual game runs decent enough and will actually work *cough* Watch_Dogs *cough*

Pre-order bonus items: Online = A puzzle game, digital map / Retail = Boxed game, Digital map, Ronan's Diary replica.

Overall score: 9.5/10 (yes, its biased)

Final Thoughts: If you love walking through everything, a good mystery here or there, wearing fedoras in life and in death and smoking more cigarettes then Solid Snake then this game is for you.

reviewText: This game is really fun. The story hooked me in right from the start and never let go until the 'yell at your tv' ending. I find the gameplay mechanics refreshing and fun. You are a ghost so you can't directly interact with most things, but you can look and piece together clues leading you through the games story amazingly well. I don't think i ever got frustratingly stuck or bored of the gameplay. The story and gameplay flow together nicely. And the characters! I found them all to be believable, with no cliche cardboard cutouts among the main characters.\nThe collection of all the items in the game adds more reason to search through the levels and adds a nice layer onto the story with collectables about the main character, the enemy, and even the town itself. The world feels very historic. Some might argue that it is too linear, but I personally liked that places were blocked off or I would have spent hours rifling through large buildings, getting lost XD\nMaybe my only complaint about the game is that there is no map, and since you can go through walls, it can get disorienting. I get that a ghost cant really carry around a map haha, its just a little nitpick, overall I loved the game and would recommend it to anyone looking for a great story and a fun time :)

reviewText:
Two important features this doesn't have: Multiple saves and letting you complete side-missions after you finish. The issues are linked, since there's an auto-saving checkpoint maybe three minutes before the end that doesn't let you go back for no good reason (and you can't turn toggle autosave). At least there's a warning but it's still far less than ideal.

If I'm not mistaken the collectibles in the museum area also become unavailable once you enter the judgement house, this time without warning.

Otherwise it's decent, but not for 40€. 30€ maybe, since the game is just not that long. (I completed the side missions but not all collectible hunts, and I'm not going back since my save is effectively wrecked, which is definitely in part my fault but not something I expect to be an issue in a good game.)

reviewText: This is a ghost story, About a abused misunderstood criminal, who meets his soul mate and turns a new leaf on life by becoming a detective with the help of his brother-in-law, He places the story of his life in tattoos that cover his body. His wife dies and he becomes reckless, and winds up geting killed. Now hes a ghost, searching for his killer. Theres alot to do in this game, through fairly easy. you have your main story, about 7 additional ghost stories to uncover, history on salem, and many other artifacts, something like 200 Items to search for. As a ghost you get abilities as the game progresses. The game really does not punish for wrong choices except you lose your gold badge status if you mess up. Steam has achievements to earn. There are demons and demon traps so you need to be carefull where you step, or if your running from demons not to step into traps. You can kill demons by getting behind them. or you can try to avoid them. I perfer just to kill them and get them out of the way. The game is not set up so you fail, it relies on the story telling and requires you to scour areas with a fine tooth comb to unlock all the stuff thats needs to be found. Just running through the main story makes for a short game, But trying to collect everything makes a very long game. So the choice is yours. The graphics are very good, I have not found any glitches or bugs in my two play throughs, the controls are responsive. I'd recommend this game for anyone who just wants a casual interesting story to sit back and relax and play. With that in mind the critics scores on this game is unjust. It's not a 10, but more like a 7.

reviewText: This game is absolutely fantastic! I've been playing it throughout the weekend and i've just finished it. I thought it was great. I found the story to be very interesting and everytime I was left with a cliffhanger I wanted to know what happened next. The fact you play as a ghost makes the game all the more interesting to play. You cannot pick up objects and normal people cannot see or hear you. It's a very interesting way to play a game but I really like it and I think it adds a hint of uniqueness to the game.  If you've ever played L.A noire you'll probably be fairly familiar with the concept of this game (finding clues and solving cases) but gameplay wise they are completely differnet, you cannot pick up and examine clues you find for example.\n\nDon't let the negative reviews for this game turn you off from buying it. It's a fantastic game with a great story and for £24.99 (even lower on other sites) it's a bargain! I highly recommend this game to any fans of the genre.

reviewText:
I had my worries of the game especially considering how multiple gaming review sites just loved to tear it a new one. I found however a particular repeating element and pattern that struck me the wrong way in most of them. The major complaints often revolve around repetition and easy difficulty structure. The learning curve is rather flat while taking the time to solve mysteries and crimes is often called child's play at that. I hate to use this term but it just feels so rather Meta in the face of the pace the game seems to give off. Salem just looks so ghostly inviting and everywhere has the potential for you to take the time and admire the lives of the still living. At the same time it just doesn't feel like a burden to get to the next part of the story and become all the more curious of the world around you.

Even the collectables have merit in the stories they tell. It just seems that a great number of people expected a rather explosive and mind bending experience. Murdered: Soul Suspect is like a brisk walk through the undead and spiritual park. It's a pleasant walk. It has a great way of not stifling the flow it has set up and the characters you come to find along the way give a curious nuance to the atmosphere. Would I say the game is flawless or addictive? No, I do not believe it is an extreme grabber that you can't let go of. It's more like that book you've been wanting to read for awhile and you just finally got down to reading it. Take your time, appreciate the attention to details, and you'll feel all the more rewarded for the investment. If you're more set on something more fast paced and hectic then perhaps another title may be up your alley.

reviewText:
It has been awhile since I’ve played an adventure game. An honest to god adventure game, where you play the character to pass a few simple puzzles to unlock the next part of the story. And Murdered: Soul Suspect developed by Airtight Games scratches that itch. Albeit it does have its flaws.

Lets get the basics out of the way, you play a cop by the name of Ronan and in the first seconds of the game you get to see your character die. But unlike a lot of games this isn’t the end, because you become a ghost. Who in order to move on has to find out who murdered him. That’s the basic plot of the game, and the main story line. And so you will spend roughly 8-12 hours going through all of Salem’s locations hunting down the clues to discover your murder. Along the way you’ll befriend some people and learn some very unsettling secrets about the town.

While the story isn’t the most complicated or even the best it still is written and presented well enough to be enjoyable. Along with the side quest and collectibles that fill in the background details about the town and the various characters it kept me enthralled for the nine hours that I played it, but then some peoples mileage may vary.

The one complaint I will have is that the developers didn’t put more background in, or even more interesting stuff. As in very early in the game you help a young girl discover what happened to her and why she was dead, you barely ever come close to that type of detail again. And that is sad because of this the background environment in terms of engagement is inconsistent, because at one end you find a piece of the map full of history and maybe a doctor who was performing experiments on his patients then at the other end you have a boring area that you have to navigate constantly to get to other locations in the game.  Seriously it gets tedious having to run the same gauntlet over and over again, with nothing changed just the same old Salem with the same old random NPC’s.

As for the gameplay mechanics, you will have learned almost everything within the first hour of how to play this game, except for a couple of “powers” you learn later on. You’re a ghost, you can pass through physical real world barriers, except for ghost barriers and all the houses in Salem are blessed or something so you can’t get into them without there being an opening of some kind. You can manipulate real world things like tv’s, phones, and printers, but except for missions these abilities don’t rouse a response out of the people in Salem. You can possess people to hear there thoughts, which there are not many of them. You can influence them to advance the case and you can view the world through there eyes to once again advance the case. Pretty nifty thing, but only actually used in the missions and have very littler bearing on the game.

And that is pretty much the sum total of the game in mechanics other than the bad guys. Which are demons and floor demons as I will call them.

Just like most adventure games of the past the bad guys pose little to no challenge and are merely there to present a hurdle to bypass. For being called demons if its 1V1 I’m going to win all the time. You hide in shades wait for them to turn there backs and then rip them apart. Also you can use ravens to distract them, but ravens ain’t used a lot. As for floor demons just side step them.

Graphics wise, the game is pretty good, not the prettiest in terms of background environment and the character models look a bit dated, they remind me of XCOM the Bureau, or even LA Norie, but that’s not a bad thing as those games had good graphics as well. And as with anything graphics are not everything as the recent trend in PC gaming can attest to.

So you may be asking why I seemed to be praising this game in the beginning but point out a lot of flaws in it. Well because in truth there are very few actual adventure games made by triple A developers anymore so anything coming out in this genre that isn’t a bug ridden mess, it will be enjoyed by those of us who like adventure games. Where you play a guy or women trying to unfold a story, either by solving puzzles or piecing the story together . Where you don’t have to gun down an armies worth of bad guys to move from one area to the next. Where the bad guys have to be planned around as you really have no actual defense against them. Where you know you can’t lose but hate the fact that you screw up sometimes.

So for an adventure game, Murdered Soul Suspect is a fine addition, its has a fairly strong main storyline and some pretty interesting side storylines and background storylines, but as I said before could use a few more to liven the area up even more. (Maybe some DLC?)

For a game it is pretty average to mediocre though, with most gameplay mechanics discovered and mastered in the first hour it leaves little advancement in that area. The NPC’s are uninteresting, the graphics compared to top of the line are dated, gameplay is pretty linear, and replayability, well to be honest there is none. I’ve played ten hours and the game will probably sit there unless I have an itch to find those 5 pieces of background info/collectibles.

So final verdict? If you are a fan of adventure games and smooth easy gameplay, then Soul Suspect is the perfect game for you. But if you are new to adventure games, or expecting something different then I wouldn’t suggest this game. And even if you are a fan of the genre this will slot into, wait till it drops to under $20 for it to be worth the money.

Finished the game in one sitting. I found it quite short but I also didn't complete all side strories, only 4 of them.

The playstyle was a nice change of pace from other games. Playing as a ghost and learning your abilities was cool.

The storyline was ok and very LA Noire voice style. Finding clues didn't flow very well at some times since it was very obvious what happened but the detective character sounded like he didn't have a clue which was strange coming from an experienced detective. Maybe I have just watched too many detective movies.

I recommend playing it but at a discounted price like I was able to get, thankfully.

reviewText:
For those who don't want to read a wall of text; I give the game a 6.5/10

The Short review:

Pros
+Main story pans out rather well
+Collectible ghost stories are great
+Unique concept
+Intriguing secondary characters (pretty much everyone but Ronan)
+Diverse game world
+Despite the limited/focused gameplay, it did not get repetitive
+No bugs/perfect performance, especially at launch

Cons
-Very short (7hrs to 100%)
-Limited side missions
-Small game world by modern standards
-Ronan, and the investigation system, can be really..really stupid
-The facial expressions for pretty much every character in the game sucks**
-Limited number of character models, despite how few ghosts you can interact with
-Probably would have been received better if it was at a cheaper price

**My long review was actually way too long, but the rather awkward facial expressions throughout the game are the most important part of the review that I had to cut out

The (Really) Long review:

STORY 6.5/10 - Chances are, you already realize the Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure game based very heavily around a story, and that story quite often falls flat on its face in terms of portraying the sense of whodunit type mystery you would get from anything Sherlock Holmes, or from similar games such as LA Noire. The main story starts off kind of rocky, but as it pans out, and you learn to ignore the hand-holding that occurs during the investigations and some of the sillier plot points (where the game screams THIS IS IMPORTANT), it actually becomes quite intriguing. I found myself actually ruling people out as the Bell Killer, with my mind firmly set on one person from very early on in the game. To my pleasant surprise, I only partially anticipated the ending, and it wasn't something from way out in left field as you would find in an M Night Shyamalan movie. It worked (eventually).

What didn't work in this game, are many of the aforementioned investigations that hold your hand throughout, often making it obscenely clear exactly what happened without ever even looking at any of the evidence at the scene. In most cases, you needed to guide Ronan to each piece of evidence (generally around 10 items), at which point he would make a remark that is often idiotic (and very often the complete opposite of what the item clearly gave me the impression of) about how it may pertain to the case, and after you have collected sufficient evidence, you would choose the items Ronan deemed important in closing the case. Since chances are you already know what happened, you would then need to find the two or three items that Ronan needed before you could move on to the more enjoyable parts of the game. This burden is frequently increased by Ronan's tendency to ignore VERY important evidence, that could immediately close the case, to focus on items that don't really help his investigation..at all. In general, what could have perhaps been the main draw for many people in this game, ended up feeling trivial and even, at times, tacked on as an after-thought. This became especially apparent when comparing the investigative stories to what was probably my favorite part of the game.

Perhaps the most redeeming quality of the game in terms of story, is sadly the part of the game that most people are likely to overlook. Each area of the game has a set of collectibles that you can gather to get a better understanding the lore surrounding that part of Salem, as portrayed through a spooky ghost story. Between these and the investigations, it definitely appears that the ghost stories took a backseat in terms of time spent working on them in the production process, as they consist of a single voice actor describing a very short ghost story, while you look at a spooky picture related to the story. It sounds lame, sure, a cinematic would have made more sense, but at the same time I think it allows you to focus more on the story itself. The ability to successfully portray a spooky story with what seems to be as little effort as possible makes me wonder why this wasn't more of a horror-based adventure game, than a detective-y investigation-y game.

Perhaps the most depressing part of the story is the fact that it is so short, clocking in at only 7hrs from start to finish, getting 100% of the achievements at the same time. I would have liked to see more side missions (I'd say investigations, but there wasn't really any of  that going on), and a generally longer story than the game had to offer.

CHARACTERS 7.5/10 - Ronan is basically a walking cliché for a bad guy gone good guy cop who does more than just toe the line between cop and criminal when he works cases. You can pretty much ignore his character entirely for a good portion of the game as his comments tend to only point out the other flaws in the game. Joy, the teenage medium, even comes off as a rather cliché young pain in the ♥♥♥, but her character does evolve rather well. When it comes to characters, the game really shines with the secondary characters, such as Baxter, and some of the Bell Killer's victims that you meet along your journey, who have all interacted with the killer in one way or another, and you get to see how that experience has changed them - for better or worse.

The same split between really good and really boring characters can be seen in the all-to-few number of side investigations that you can find scattered across Salem, where someone may have a problem that you offer to investigate, and inevitably fix. In the cases where the characters are lame, it is often because of the same thing the investigation part of the game suffers from, the answer being too blatantly obvious to not think that character is an idiot for not seeing it. In other cases, it is clear that the character is in a literal limbo, and they need your help getting out of it.

GAMEPLAY 8/10 - First off, the game as a whole  works beautifully, both as a game being played on launch week, and a game in general, as I found no bugs of any kind while playing through the game.

Chances are, part of the reason the game runs so great is because it is just so simplistic. The combat in the game is about as basic as you can get, and would most likely have become very redundant had there been more combat sequences in the game. I had only just started to get sick of dealing with demons by the time I reach the last half hour or so of gameplay. It is very clear that the focus is on story and investigating the crimes of the Bell Killer (see the story section for why that is a letdown).

The world around Ronan becomes increasingly impressive, and creepy, as the frequency of ghosts increases, but in general I got a very Twilight-zone-empty-town feel from Salem, and the ghosts flat out reminded me of the Haunted Mansion ride at Disney World. Ultimately, the living people that populated Salem ended up feeling even more empty than their ghostly counterparts, which I think actually gave me an even creepier vibe from the game, although I don't think that was totally intentional.

While making the world feel a bit more lively is kind of optional, since a gloomier look does make sense to me as you are playing a ghost, I think Salem definitely should have been larger than it was. By the time you reach the credits, you will have only explored just over a half dozen different parts of Salem, and the streets of (a rather small) Salem itself. Sure, the areas are diverse, consisting of everything from a Church, to a Police Station, and a Mental Hospital, but none of the areas are very large, further adding to the small-world feel of the game. On the other hand, with how tedious the combat had become by the end of the game, and how pointless the investigations were (they weren't quite tedious, but certainly would have been soon enough), I think focusing more on other aspects of the game first would have been more important than expanding the world around Ronan.

reviewText:
By all accounts, this game should have never been made in 2014.  The market for AAA games demand experiences much different than this one.  This is a niche game, and throwing so many resources at it is a terrible, terrible business decision.

The game has almost no combat, and is driven by dialogue, information gathering, and narrative.

That said, I am writing this after just completing it, with a huge grin on my face.  The story in this game is STELLAR.  It evokes the slower pacing and murder mystery elements of games like the Blackwell franchise and LA Noire.  It's also compounded with supernatural elements and a heavy influence from the Salem Witch Trials.

At it's heart, it's a murder mystery (your own, in fact.)  But once it starts unfolding, there is an incredible narrative to be experienced, one I highly recommend, if you don't mind slow pacing in video games.

I can't recommend this to everyone, but if you love a good mystery, and prefer dialogue to gunplay, then I cannot recommend this game enough.  Like I said, it's a niche game, and if you fall into that niche, then please, please, play this game.

reviewText:
Plus Points:
* Great initial atmosphere with an interesting plot
* Cat possession is very fun
* Salem looks good through a ghosts eyes
* Demons look great but rarely interesting encounters
* Some inventive puzzle solving
* Decent conclusion

Minus Points:
* Sandbox world quickly feels very linier and confined
* Side missions are item hunts within a few feet
* Bonus story item hunts are boring and unrewarding
* Creepy tone lessens as things progress
* Demons are mindless padding, just to lengthen the campaign
* Mind reading and possession aren't useful or interesting
* Detective work is underwhelming
* Short 7-8 Hours with little replay value

Like a supernatural LA Noire with a shorter and more confined world. Since progressing the story is all important the game's not particularly difficult or expansive.

Recommended for: Stealth/Crime buffs with a liking for story over mechanics.

Conclusion: 7/10. Not as bad as many would have you believe and worth your time for a few quid then move on.

reviewText:
So no idea why it's online reviews were so bad. I've been looking forward to this game for a long time and I wasn't disappointed at all. Think of it as LA Noireish with ghosts. It's got the whole detective thing going for it which I like a lot and wish was found more often.

Pros:
-Compelling story, made me sit down and play though it in one sitting, amazing.
-Gameplay, if you like to walk around and discover everything then this is the game for you. It never gets dull, slow or too fast. Demons are there to change up gameplay and overall I enjoyed being a exorcist.
-Graphics, beautiful game, love the art, everything looks great.
-I found a few Just Cause 2 posters in the game.
-Even though it's supernatural it doesn't feel fake/childish.
-Writing, for the most part, was done very well.
-Made me want to help the lost souls and feel rewarded for doing so.
-Examples about people who throw their life away.
-Good ending.

Cons:
-Short, only about 5 hours if you stick to the story and probably close to 6-7 if you want to 100% the game.
-Character development, sometimes it felt like characters weren't developed enough for me but I like to know full blown backgrounds, I wouldn't say it was bad though.
-Occasional frame drops.


Overall: Solid game, would definitely recommend. Good luck in the afterlife!!

Morals:
Don't do drugs.
Don't kill yourself.
Don't hold grudges.
Do something with your life.

reviewText:
Is this a perfect game? No, not by a long shot, but then again, are there any perfect games which aspire to the complexity of narrative and gameplay as Murdered: Soul Suspect? As a narrative exercise, Murdered is very enjoyable. The stories of the various ghosts you encounter are always interesting and sometimes quite haunting. Ronan, the dead detective whom you play, may seem one dimensional at the beginning, but he is 'fleshed out', so to speak as you play, to at least TWO dimensions. But to mitigate this issue are some really interesting characters and stories, i.e. the aforementioned ghosts you meet. Some are quite affecting.

The game is, for the most part, solidly built and I experienced no bugs or glitches while playing the game. Glimpses of Airtight Game's puzzle pedigry show through in several sections, though there is never an explicit focus on that kind of gameplay. Yet nor is there a focus on action. This a much more quiet and reflective gameplay experience, which I wonder is not an explanation of the game's poor reviews thus far. Certainly, it is not a blockbuster, but it feels more like an independent, more closely focused affair which I think many will enjoy if they are open to it.

In many ways, I kept thinking about similar games I played in the 90s. Perhaps it was the interface itself or the mood or the package as a whole. The game is a throwback, so yes it does have obvious shortcomings. The living world which it hints at is very quickly revealed to be smoke and mirrors, but as already explained, I was fine with that. I liked the characters and the ideas and the game played smoothly. I do not regret slapping down the cash for this one.

reviewText: I saw this on the Halloween sale, I took the gamble and bought it, even after hearing mixed to negative reviews about this game.\n\nLet me put one thing straight, anyone who says this is a bad game have bad taste in video games. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a great 3rd person game that involves excellent crime solving elements. The game jumps straight into the action, revealling one of, if not the biggest plot twists in the entire game. After that, you must follow the notorious Bell Killer case around Salem and catch the serial killer, however, just when you thought there wouldn't be any combat in the game, you will face demons that will eat your soul when they find you. This now kinda makes this game like LA Noire + DmC + the detective bits from the Arkham games, which makes it well worth buying.

reviewText:
As many of you know this game has issues, issues square enix aren't in a hurry to fix.. mainly related to the game not launching on many PC's. Luckily there are people out there who have fixed this.. and the link at the bottom is a youtube video that also links in its description to the files needed to sort it all out. :)

Onto the review...

This game was very enjoyable from start to finish. The story is great and the whole idea of playing a dead character solving his own murder is one I haven't seen done before and it was excuted perfectly in this game so welldone to the developers for that as in the wrong hands an idea like this just wouldn't have worked as well I feel.

The games graphics and look were great. I ran it maxed out at 1080p on my Radeon 6870 with a quad core Athlon II cpu and 8gb of memory. I didn't experience any framerate issues that others have mentioned in the forums.. tho there was one part of the story that seemed to repeat itself at one point and I'm pretty sure that wasn't meant to happen as it made no sense, but the story continued fine after that little hiccup, not a major issue.

Controls on the 360 controller were great, very easy to get into and layed out well. I never tried the keyboard/mouse for this game as I felt no need to, so can't comment on some comments form others about it not suiting keyboard/mouse.. considering the price of even a 3rd party wired 360 controller these days its not a problem worth moaning about and as i said, the 360 controller is fully supported and ideal for this game.

The game is quite short compared to most large companies titles these days and can be completed in between probably 7 and 10 hours depending on whether to stick to the main story or want to collect everything and complete the side stories. I clocked a bit more than that as I was playing the game on a day I was ill to pass the time lol, so game was paused for periods of time while i was .. well... attending to being ill lol.

I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes games with a good story to unfold.. also its a bit different to the norm thats released these days. I hope Square-Enix and Airtight Games work together again on a similar title as I'd definitely buy it.. and hopefully they will learn from their game launching mistakes with this one.

As stated the game launch problems are easily fixed using the files the guy links to on youtube for anyone that needs them.. (link below, view on youtube to see description and files link)

I'll give the game 8/10 despite the shorter than usual gameplay and the fact I had to fix its launching problem. The score reflects the game itself and it was great.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YsBgPCmfbYg

reviewText:
This game, just this game.

I have so much praise for it that I don't even know where to begin, but I'll try to sound it off.

-The gameplay is a breath of fresh-air because it's this unique blend of third-person action game with occasional stealth elements and exploration based adventure game with some crime scene investigation and mild puzzle-solving thrown for good measure. I have trouble really classifying it because I've never played anything quite like it, and it really managed to form it's own gameplay identity instead of being a clone of something else or fitting neatly into a pre-defined gameplay genre.

-The graphics are also really pretty relative to how easy on the hardware it it. I was able to max it out (with AA turned off) at 1080p on a 750ti and it was rare that it dropped under FPS.

-The story is brilliant and actually managed to have a couple twists that I really didn't see coming because of the way it played with my expectations near constantly and intentionally set itself up for common tropes only to subvert or play with them.

-The art design is great and does this thing where it creates interesting eviroments by blending the real-world with ghostly left-overs of the past.

-It was interesting how it turned no-clip into a game mechanic.

-The bonus stuff like the side-missions and ghost stories were cool.

I guess there is some cons, though:

-The stealth sections can get tedious because the Demons tend to be a little to smart and aggressive, I often found myself trapped because they got stuck in the alert state and wouldn't go back to the posts no matter how well I stayed hidden.

-Some poor optimization, I know I said it runs well but it does tend to suffer from really inconsistant framerates, it can be at 55FPS one minute and 100FPS the next and the Vsync is useless because it looks it to 30FPS instead of to your screens refresh rate.

-Some of the items are to well hidden, I missed out on two of the Ghost Stories because I just could not find the last items for either, and one location even locked me out of room that the levels last item was presumably in.

-No kind of map, even though the hub" area is pretty huge and maze-like.

-Short
date: I spent just over 10 hours on it and that was a playthrough with a lot of messing about and finding A LOT of the bonus items. I imagine it would be under 5 hours if you ignored the side-missions.\n\n-Price
recommended: I think $30 is pushing it. I paid $4 during a sale and I'd say it's not worth more than $15
hoursPlayed: so wait for it to go on sale."

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect, the supernatural detective thriller from Square Enix and Airtight Games. Murdered takes place in Salem, Mass and stars the newly deceased Ronan O'Connor, who sets out to learn the identity of his killer.
It's an adventure game, basically, right down to the often frustrating hunt for clues. This makes up a good chunk of the gameplay and tasks you with finding a certain number of bits of info by exploring a tightly defined location, examining everything. Moving the story forwards requires you to find and identify the most relevant clues. It's not the most graceful representation of the detective's art, but it is a more compelling take on the genre than the rummage sale of irrelevant detritus that typified LA Noire.

So the game is absolutely amazing The visuals, the gameplay, are all spectacular and it's refreshing. they have completely redefined storytelling in gaming with this masterpiece.

reviewText:
While I have said I wouldn't recomend it I do have some positive points as well as negative ones.

I will admit the concept is quite a fun one, a dead cop investigating his own death however I feel this game suffers from Remember Me syndrome. A good, interesting concept with bags of potential that has a half arsed delivery. It also feels like a dumbed down L.A Noire, that maybe a bit harsh actualy but anyway it still holds your hand through the investigations that are implemented a lot like L.A Noire. The twist is ok and frankly I was quite a head of the investigation before that point anyway and the rest of the game was basicaly confirming my theories. The controls are also very odd. Exorcising demons, which I swear is never explained how the main character and only him can do it however I may have just missed that or didn't pay attention, involves holding the R then pressing either W,A,S,D and the left mouse button. Now I'm sorry but this is just too much, a 3 button QTE is just too much, it's a QTE not a think for a bit to make sure I have the right button because if you don't your going to have to run fast. These demons are quick and kill quick too, they also freak me out a lot but that might be just me. The mouse is also super sensitive and it took me a while to get used to it even on the lowest setting. The cat controls are ridiculous too and seems to be slightly less broken than Radscorpions, which is saying a lot as they are the most glitchy animals in a game, ever. Oh and the game is too short, and the escort parts are silly as the people your escorting won't move till a distraction happens to lead the person away....who is standing still at the time, not actively searching...so those being escorted are never in any real danger, so it's a tad pointless. On the whole, good concept, average delivery and worth £10 on sale, definatly not full price though.

Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Friday
http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

reviewText: Although I do like this game, I would not recommend anyone to pay full price for it. I purchased it from Humble Bundle when it was part of a $1 bundle and that's honestly about how much it is worth.\n\nThe gameplay is okay. While the storyline is interesting, general mechanics of moving your character around can be quite a pain. You only play in third person and the camera moves way too fast; apparently mouse sensitivity only seems to affect cursor movements on selecting clues. The demons, though 2spoopy5me at times, seem like an unnecessary add-in to the game. Also, your LMB/RMB and any keyboard function will randomly stop working. The game also only auto saves, so if you end up having any issues like that, go ahead and prepare yourself for any progress you may lose when you have to restart the game.

reviewText:
I REALLY wanted to like this.  The premise was unique (you're a detective and you need to find out who murdered you).  But this was just not enjoyable.

The game is short.  By itself, this isn't a big deal, you don't need to put 40+ hours into a game to get your money's worth.  My playtime was 9 hours.  But I'm guessing 4 of those were spent fighting with the game's poor systems:

1) No Map.  Seriously?  What is this 2004?  In a 3rd person exploration game this is unheard of & seems like it was omitted to add unnecessary time & difficulty.  Wandering about town, there is a series of intermediate waypoints that lead you to the next target, but those get broken & send you through areas that aren't available, so unless you're a navigational expert, you're stuck randomly wandering until you luck into the next target.

2) Combat.  It's basically added as an afterthought to add time in between the investigations" (which are generally well done
date: once you figure out the game's systems).  There's is one monster type & it's pattern is easily identifiable.  But the controls are difficult & even if you do everything right you still might get caught & have to redo the area.  The game is using poor controls & frustration to again add extra difficulty & time
recommended: instead of giving the enemies useful AI.\n\nThe graphics are fine
hoursPlayed: but suffer from overusing a "dark & hazy" theme.  Considering the story takes place entirely at night
voteText: this is probably expected.\n\nI was engaged enough with the setting & story enough to want to finish it
helpfulPercent: but definitely won't be replaying to get a 100% finish."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dtu37YI0oGU&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA

Murdered: Soul Suspect is a console port detective game with a horror
atmosphere that plays more like an interactive movie than a game.  Right off
the bat, I was unimpressed by the whopping 30 frames per second that this
game runs at, followed shortly by the delayed lineup of subtitles to speech.

The story was cheesy and doesn't fit with the objective of the game;
starting out by stating that your ultimate goal is to reunite with a lost love,
but then not mentioning that relationship for the bulk of the game.  As for the game
being a detective game, I would disagree with that and state that it is more
like a hidden object game that requires you search out 'clues' in a predetermined
location.  There is no deduction needed; all the clues are in one place, and
the game holds your hand by leading you to the next clue and asking
rediculously obvious questions.

The ghosts, while contributing to the atmosphere, did absolutely nothing
to add to the game.  For the most part, they were all from the same time period,
and were supposed to add a spooky element, but as you are also playing as a
ghost, and they disappear when you get close, they were more of a waste of time
than anything else.

I enjoy watching movies, but I buy games in order to, oh I don't know,
play a game!  This game played like a cinematic movie, with about 20-25%
of the game actual gameplay, and the rest being cinematic movies or dialogue.
Being made to move all across the mapp to get to the next action point does not
count as gameplay;  it is wasting time.

If you are interested in the story of this game, I would recommend going
to YouTube and watching the cinematics strung together rather than buy this game.
It treats you, the player, as if you are an idiot that can't figure out anything
for yourself.  Graphically the game gets by, as well as the level design.  The
story is acceptable, but what little gameplay there is designed for those
that can't deduce anything for themselves.  As a game, I cannot recommend this,
if it can even be called a game.

For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basic summary of
what I cover in my video.

Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.

http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText: Criminal turned detective stumbles upon a killer and end up dead. Insted of going into the light, he becomes a ghost, resolved to reveal who murdered him. It's an adventure game, most similar to LA Noire. You go around, detect and inspect clues, listen onto the conversations, talk to other ghosts, walk through the walls, think, make hypothesis, solve mysteries, and reveal the story step by step. There's no much action, but there are stealth sequences, where you have to detect demons, and destroy them before they find you. A lot of optional content (side quests, world information, character info and all that) to be found. Nice graphics and sound, a bit weird controls but one can easily get used to them. I like it.

reviewText:
To start off there is only 4 hours of gameplay here and no replay value. It is basically an interactive movie. It is a murder mystery. For me this game/movie was kind of boring... Not very fun for a video game. I feel sorry for those who paid full price. I guess I got my $12 worth out of this game since it's cheaper than going to the movies to kill 4 hours. This is a Crime, Drama, Murder, Mystery. I'd say I've been bored for 4 hours since I just wanted to finish the story. It wasn't worth it for myself. There was no challenge at all... Just go here investigate this and that help this person do this get here blah blah blah.... Just boring.

Killing demons isn't even satisfying and it's also a very small part of the game to add a challenge... It's not challenging at all. Just get behind the demon hold R then you will have to hit W, A, S, or D with left or right click, it's completely random which is cool but i'd rather actually battle the demon with something more interactive. But yeah do that and the demon is dead YAYYYY!!! Or you can just skip killing demons and go to your next location... doesn't matter.

This game is only worth $12 or less. For a single-player only game for $50 when it released and only 4 hours of gameplay if you don't care about finding every stupid hidden piece in the world. I just went where I needed to go and picked up what I could along the way.

Most single-player 3rd person / 1st person games have around 8 hours average if not a little longer and also have replay value majority of the time.

Bought it, played it, completed it, never playing it again, the end.

reviewText:
I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.

I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.

Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's optional
date: a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first completed" game
recommended: I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps
hoursPlayed: M:SS definitely appeals on that front.\n\nThe other main challenge of the game is demon encounters

votesHelpful: by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all

reviewText:
This game starts oddball, but settles in quite quickly. I suppose you could call it an adventure title – it's kind of like a modern cop detective game, without the sort of action you'd assume to be stuck in as a timesink filler padding out a story. It is *much* more like a modern third person shooter without any of the shooting, just the investigative minigames, the scavenger hunt collectibles and the plot. Does this make sense? Designwise it simply does not feel like an adventure game.

I do recommend it.

Last note on the Steam version – getting it to run on my PC was an absolute, horrific chore. For some reason, the Steam integration .dlls kept the game from starting. It kept crashing right at the start, stating that it can't contact the Steam client. Well, eventually I got it to run by some dark magic steps that I'm not going to publicly enumerate, at the cost of losing most of the benefits Steam bestows.

reviewText:
A hidden gem or a rusty stone
To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.

In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.

By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.

By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.

By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.

The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.

The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.

The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.

Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.

Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.

Is this a good game?
I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.

Final verdict
Murdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.

Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.

7/10

reviewText:
This game is another example, approving that Square Enix releases good solid games, but not AAA level. I waited for it, and although it did not meet all my expectations, it left me satisfied.
First of all it a game of a rare genre nowadays - Adventure. Get rid of the demons and demon hands - and this is a pure non-combat quest. The closest example which appeared in my mind is Indigo Prohecy. Sometimes it's really pleasant to drop off your swords, guns, explosives, tanks, etc. and just listen to a good (mystic in this case) story, or since we're talking about the game - become a part of the story.
The plot doesn't bring something new (or maybe it's me getting older), but it's interesting and keeps you involved till the end of the game, with a small twist. Thankfully, game is pretty short and does not get you bored - 16 hours in my case, BUT, this is becasue of the greatest minus of the game - it's terrible, random, sadistic check points. I had to exit the game after several hours of playing, and when came back to it about 30 minutes were gone. I had to rush into several side quests again aaand....caught a bug with Ronan falling through textures, reloaded, and repeated those 30 minutes.
As far as I understand this is first succesfull project from Airtight Games. If they had more budget, city would be bigger, there would be more side quests, more reasonablo thoughts in the citizens' minds and more interactive objects. So I wish developers all that for their next project so it can become a real AAA game.
For now, it's 7,5/10 (not enough for 8, better than just 7)

reviewText: Great story-driven game, with explorable semi-open world filled with secrets. If you like good detective story, or Japanese style of narration, or both then you are for a treat. It's must have for all fans of games like Deadly Premonition or Heavy Rain. Gameplay focuses on quite easy, but fun, puzzles and on sneaking-based combat, but those mechanics are just tools to tell the story, if you want intense, gameplay focused game then it's not for you (but you should try it, you might like it anyway because it's really good game ;).

reviewText: This game is very similar to LA Noire but instead you are a ghost detective in the present day instead of an LAPD detective in the 40s. The gameplay mainly consists of walking around and examining objects in the environment to help solve cases. If that bores you, don't get this game because there is not even much of a combat system aside from sneak attacking demons once in a while. It is kind of open world in the sense that you are free to walk around town and collect objects to solve side cases, but the lack of any sort of map or minimap makes exploration a hassle. With all that being said, I enjoyed the story and atmosphere of the game, which is surprisingly a bit lighthearted for a game about ghosts. It took me about 7 hours to complete the game and I also took my time to grab most of the collectibles as well.\n\nVerdict: Definitely get this on a sale, it is short but sweet. 6/10

reviewText:
This game starts oddball, but settles in quite quickly. I suppose you could call it an adventure title – it's kind of like a modern cop detective game, without the sort of action you'd assume to be stuck in as a timesink filler padding out a story. It is *much* more like a modern third person shooter without any of the shooting, just the investigative minigames, the scavenger hunt collectibles and the plot. Does this make sense? Designwise it simply does not feel like an adventure game.

I do recommend it.

Last note on the Steam version – getting it to run on my PC was an absolute, horrific chore. For some reason, the Steam integration .dlls kept the game from starting. It kept crashing right at the start, stating that it can't contact the Steam client. Well, eventually I got it to run by some dark magic steps that I'm not going to publicly enumerate, at the cost of losing most of the benefits Steam bestows.

reviewText:
I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.

I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.

Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's optional
date: a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first completed" game
recommended: I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps
hoursPlayed: M:SS definitely appeals on that front.\n\nThe other main challenge of the game is demon encounters
voteText: and they can be tricky to master at first
helpfulPercent: since some of the combinations are a little awkward. Still
votesHelpful: by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all
votesTotal: the demon encounters kept the game from feeling extremely linear (i.e.
votesFunny: like a visual novel).\n\nSo if you're into mysteries and crime fiction
commentsCount: love spooky stuff
column16: and enjoy a game that burns a little slowly
column17: definitely give it a try."

reviewText:
Even though I am recommending this game, it is only a recommendation *IF* you can get it very cheaply (and I am sure you will be able to)

You play the ghost of a cop who was killed and you have to solve your own murder. Good premise, and a pretty good story too, the problem is the gameplay. You are lead by the hand through the whole game, go from point A to point B and when you get there find a few things. It doesn't matter if you get anything wrong, there are NO penalties, just try again.

The game is also VERY short, so to try and pad things out, the programmers have added a couple of collect random objects" quests to make things last a little longer. You don't have to collect them and they add nothing to the story if you do (or don't) There are a couple of smaller "mysteries" to solve along the way
recommended: but overall this game is just bland. Highly polished
hoursPlayed: but bland."

reviewText:
Graphics are nice, but the control system is limited and a little forced (obviously intended for a controler). the only 'Action' is when you interact with demons and try to kill them from behind, in which case you have to quickly push a randomly chosen WASD key+mouse button combo while holding down another key to initiate. If they see you first, or you miss the key combo (EG because you're moving when you initate and the key your holding isn't the right one) then the only thing you can do is run away untill their not searching for you anymore and try again.

Other than that it's a really simple detective game where you atempt to move your character into just the right spots to be able to interact with clues to get really obvious hints. (you get flashes of information when you find the clue, then you have to watch it all over again anyway once you 'solve' the crime)

If you enjoy 'Tell me a story' mode games and can get past the controls it's alright. but get it on sale.

reviewText:
Worst game I played all year so far.

The game plays as a point and click detective game where you can guess clues to continue on.

At first I was all into the game, but you soon realize it is the same thing everywhere you go.

The side missions was more interesting than the real story and so many clone NPC's, if you really look at some of their walk cycles you think that you were not the only ghost in the game. I know I watched a woman walked through a building with me before and I was like is this multiplayer lol.

The game twist ending at the end is very lame and I was into collecting the stuff in the game and when you get close to the end you just wish the game would end please.

Ok if you want a fisher price detective game, but if you want play a Noir like game, just play LA Noir or something else.

reviewText: While there are some things that I liked about this game and are really interesting, almost none of those take place in the gameplay.  Gathering clues and evidence is neat.  The game's mechanic for putting those clues and evidence together for a solution is terrible.  When it's not the most obvious puzzle ever, it's a complete guess and luck.  The action sequences are not terrible.  They simply aren't fun.  Wait till the enemy turns his back and then walk up and do the QTE.\n\nGameplay aside though, the environment and story are interesting and the conclusion, though a bit hokey, is pretty good too.

reviewText: Terrible game. Predicted the final solution within the first five minutes of the game and spent the next four hours screaming in frustration at the stupidity of the main character. Feel like this game smacks you round the face with every answer, leaving no detective work to do and no mystery to think of. reviewText:
This game is another example, approving that Square Enix releases good solid games, but not AAA level. I waited for it, and although it did not meet all my expectations, it left me satisfied.
First of all it a game of a rare genre nowadays - Adventure. Get rid of the demons and demon hands - and this is a pure non-combat quest. The closest example which appeared in my mind is Indigo Prohecy. Sometimes it's really pleasant to drop off your swords, guns, explosives, tanks, etc. and just listen to a good (mystic in this case) story, or since we're talking about the game - become a part of the story.
The plot doesn't bring something new (or maybe it's me getting older), but it's interesting and keeps you involved till the end of the game, with a small twist. Thankfully, game is pretty short and does not get you bored - 16 hours in my case, BUT, this is becasue of the greatest minus of the game - it's terrible, random, sadistic check points. I had to exit the game after several hours of playing, and when came back to it about 30 minutes were gone. I had to rush into several side quests again aaand....caught a bug with Ronan falling through textures, reloaded, and repeated those 30 minutes.
As far as I understand this is first succesfull project from Airtight Games. If they had more budget, city would be bigger, there would be more side quests, more reasonablo thoughts in the citizens' minds and more interactive objects. So I wish developers all that for their next project so it can become a real AAA game.
For now, it's 7,5/10 (not enough for 8, better than just 7)

reviewText: I liked the game, good graphic, nice soundtrack and immersive storyline (so far). reviewText: Murdered: Soul Suspect is a typical Square Enix title story-wise, however it falls short on game length, suspense based on its genre and some pretty slow controls. What do I mean by slow controls? I mean that walking is more like shuffling and the run option is nothing more than a fast paced walk. Granted you get a power later on that helps with that problem, but only to a point.\nThe story is well presented but it still feels rushed and boring at times. The only thing that would make the gameplay any longer is by aquiring all the collectibles which I feel has had more time spent on than some more important parts of the game, both finding them and reading/watching them. This game is portrayed as a thriller and it hasn't failed on that part. However it also implies some horror elements that aren't really present, even with the spooky" spectres.\nAs my activity time shows
date: I've not spent long on this game. I'd say that the campaign is only around 3-4 hours long and all other time is spent simply getting the collectibles or completing the tiny amount of sidecrimes/cases that you can solve.\nAll in all
recommended: this is getting a thumbs down. While the story is good
hoursPlayed: I can't help but feel that this game was rushed out to help with the new gen consoles rather than be a good game. I also don't think that with the small amount of time spent on thisgame it is worth the £24.99 price tag."
