reviewText: The game is ok. Detective stuff, ghost stuff, poltergeist stuff. Fine. Among these stuff, there are collectibles stuff. 170+ collectible stuff. I collected as much stuff as I possibly could, and I figured before finishing the game I can watch a video of the missed stuff, so I can recover those stuff. Well, the last stuff I needed to collect are in the museum. The same museum that you enter at the end of the game to finish the game, WITHOUTH having the chance to collect your museum missed stuff. I can't unlock the last 2-3 achievments because of 3-4 missed collectibles stuff. I deleted the game without even seeing the end, seeing who is the murderer and seeing the bright light (I presume), because frankly...without all the stuff, I don't give a sh*t how this game will end. Don't get me wrong. I'm a story kind of guy. I like story games, but the rage I just got towards the developers of the game is so huge, that I don't care about their story. And don't judge me...I like the word stuff". I hope some day I will have the chance to permanetly remove this game from my library."

reviewText: Got this game for free when I purchased my video card. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective game set around the site of the former Salem Witch trials where you are a ghost stuck in limbo until the you can resolve everything in regards to your death (namely, identifying the killer). The story is moderately enjoyable, and the ending twist regarding your death genuinely surprised me. Didn't care for the time spent in between crime scenes, as things tended to drag, and the collectables are more of a hassle than anything. Since the story only lasts for 7-8 hours and the game doesn't have much replayability, I can not recommend buying at the $50 price. Look into playing once it hits a major sale on Steam.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect - Spoiler Free Review

First off, I'd like to point out that I like both pulp noir and ghost stories both of which are heavy influences on the general feel of this game.  If you do not like either the cinematography stylings of pulp noir (in which case, you won't like the cut-scenes and may dislike the characters on occassion) or think ghost stories are dull, then this is not the game for you.

For those of you still with me and looking at potentially buying this game a bit of background is in order.  The studio that released M:SS closed down despite really ploughing everything into this game.  Part of it is odd in places, which I'll get to, but mostly they'd been struggling for a while due to releasing a couple of games which were bombs a while back.  Any future updates to the game will have to be community driven but that at least is one piece of good news - after multiple playthroughs I only came across one minor glitch, once, and it was a graphical one that I couldn't replicate.  The game runs really well so future patching should not be necessary.

So, where to start?  How about the story.  It's pretty standard fair, almost straight out of a Randall & Hopkirk: Deceased" episode.  You're a detective in Salem when a call is put in about a strange hooded man breaking into an apartment building.  As you are an emotional loose cannon after your wifes' death (it's actually nice to play a character who's irrational behaviour gets some explanation for once) you chase after him alone only to find that he's too strong for you
date: the eventual fight resulting in your death.  Your purpose is to stop the killer from beyond the grave so that your spirit can move on and be reunited with your wife.\n\nThis opening is actually really impressive as it's almost entirely done using the in-game engine and graphically looks superb
recommended: the sweeping camera shots and the slow-motion work really well giving a strong movie quality feel but rather than just have you as a passenger watching the opening the developer makes you take part in it
hoursPlayed: trying to first catch the killer and even trying to survive the attack.  The sound is excellent too and is nicely understated
voteText: something that carries throughout the whole game.\n\nAfter this you're left
helpfulPercent: dead
votesHelpful: in Salem trying to figure out how you can stop this killer.  There's a tutorial which covers the controls and then you're given objectives to complete but you are left to wander through reasonably large parts of Salem without being stopped.  As you're dead you come across other spirits and left over memories of Salem in it's past

votesFunny: especially when it ties in with the sidequests and main stories.  The more you progress the more of Salem opens up to you

reviewText:
A hidden gem or a rusty stone
To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.

In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.

By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.

By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.

By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.

The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.

The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.

The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.

Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.

Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.

Is this a good game?
I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.

Final verdict
Murdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.

Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.

7/10

reviewText: Terrible game. Predicted the final solution within the first five minutes of the game and spent the next four hours screaming in frustration at the stupidity of the main character. Ok if you want a fisher price detective game, but if you want play a Noir like game, just play LA Noir or something else.

reviewText:
I was at first skeptical of this game, but I played it and found the storyline and characters interesting. I really found it interesting/intriguing that it focased on Salem's history and how it blended with the game's modern day storyline. Alot of references and educational material thrown in, as well as some in-game easter eggs thrown in here and there. I highly recommend this game for those interested in Salem, the withcraft trials, ghost stories and murder mysteries. The only problem I had was the uncustomizable awkward key bindings, the inability to use utilize a multibutton mouse, and the linear gameplay.


NOTE: This is my personal opinion and thoughts of the game, not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research.

reviewText:
There’s been a mukduk!

You play as Ronan and have to accuse someone of a murder. Your own!

High quality graphics give noir-detective feel to modern day Salem. Voice acting is superb and really takes the game to the next level. It is a very well written whodunit.
Do not expect action packed shootouts. The game is all about the story.

It keeps you interested until the finale and I really enjoyed discovering Salem, the clues and getting to know the characters involved.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a really enjoyable game. The gameplay is mostly just finding stuff around the environment, with a few simple stealth combat sequences and puzzles to mix it up. The story is pretty good, although far too short. Voice acting is top-notch, although the game does suffer from 'Welcome to Corneria' syndrome at times.

If you hate collectables, this is not the game for you, but unlike many other games, you actually get nice rewards for finding stuff here. The side stories are quite interesting.

All in all, this game is clearly low-budget and unpolished, but there are still many endearing and fun features. If you're a fan of immersive environments and detailed lore, don't miss out on this game.

reviewText: It is not so often, when I get lost in a game like I did with Murdered: Soul Suspect. Everything about this game roars quality and adventure & mystery. Tons of questions must be answered, and here comes you, playing as Ronan. It is not an open world game, true, but you still can play it in your way and doesn't try to constrain you. You can solve tasks without having all of the clues discovered. You are even allowed to return previous locations to finish the side quests there, if you've skipped them through the Main Storyline. A lot of collectable item awaits you in the game, that unlocks so exciting extras such as other murderous stories has happened in Salem, even it's History. You can get more informations about Ronan, Jul.\nThis game means something like Dishonored to me. Where an immersive story meets great graphics. And just not talking about Ronan. He is AWESOME.

reviewText:
I was at first skeptical of this game, but I played it and found the storyline and characters interesting. I really found it interesting/intriguing that it focased on Salem's history and how it blended with the game's modern day storyline. Alot of references and educational material thrown in, as well as some in-game easter eggs thrown in here and there. I highly recommend this game for those interested in Salem, the withcraft trials, ghost stories and murder mysteries. The only problem I had was the uncustomizable awkward key bindings, the inability to use utilize a multibutton mouse, and the linear gameplay.


NOTE: This is my personal opinion and thoughts of the game, not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research.

reviewText:
There’s been a mukduk!

You play as Ronan and have to accuse someone of a murder. Your own!

High quality graphics give noir-detective feel to modern day Salem. Voice acting is superb and really takes the game to the next level. It is a very well written whodunit.
Do not expect action packed shootouts. The game is all about the story.

It keeps you interested until the finale and I really enjoyed discovering Salem, the clues and getting to know the characters involved.

reviewText:
'Always be careful with overhyped games that even gets attention by common news media!' ... would be an advise I would give to my children.

Too bad Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the games, that I would put in that category. But why do I recommend it then? Easy answer: This game isn't a total desaster, but it is not worth its full price.

The gaming magazines criticize its length, its combat system (btw there is no combat system ... you more or less only hide from the few enemies) and absolutly no replay value. These three things I can confirm.

It is also annoying, that while the main characters are very detailed, everyone else looks way worse and there is nearly nothing to do beside the 'main' quest.

But that main quest is the thing, that keeps you nonstop playing till the end. The story with a relativly unused setting is well executed and the gameplay elements are simple enough to give you more of a interactive movie, then an (action) adventure.

So if you like (gameplay simple) mystery thriller, go grab this game, when it is on big discount.

reviewText:
I am a casual female gamer, not great with button mashing. I really love rich story lines, rpg styled play, and puzzles! This game included all of that. If you're casual like me, it's a great point and click that isn't boring. Too often I find the point and clicks are slow paced, but this isn't.

Most of the game is really innate. You know what your goals are and what you have to do. I rarely needed to look something up, so that's a plus for the casual gamer.

The storyline is reallllly cool, the characters, the voice acting, all of it.

My only negative is I didn't clue in to just how open the world was. You can explore a lot and do side quests and I missed a lot of them because I was only following the storyline. Newb mistake for sure, so be sure you do all the fun stuff on the side to get all the achievements.

Graphics and controls were great.

reviewText: This title looked fantastic when I first read about it and watched the teasers. Then I watched the first few minutes of gameplay, coupled with reviews, and (wrongly) came to the conclusion that is was a hidden object game/single-room puzzler wrapped in a 3rd person Unreal Engine. Not the case at all. While the puzzling is not brain taxing in the slightest, the story is interesting and the setting can be almost beautiful in places. There is no horror to be found, unless you found Peter Jackson's Frighteners scary. Were it designed for grown-ups instead of E for Everyone it could have been so much more.\n\nDespite it's flaws, I found it enjoyable and sometimes hard to put down.

Then it asks you some totally dumb question and you got to connect some clues which would be interesting if the game would punish you for a wrong choice... You picked the wrong clue? Nevermind.. Pick another! So you can just click around cause it doesnt matter and answering questions like "Why did she go to church?" with an answer "I think she did go to the church" summs up the dullness of the "detective mechanics".

Overall Murdered Soul Suspect looks like a game by someone who knows what makes a good game but doesnt know how to put it into his game. I can imagine somebody can get into this game and actually like it but I was so bored after 2 hours playing it."

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect was easily the biggest surprise of 2015 for me, and I think the last game that really blew away my expectations to the same extent was the psychologically assaulting trek through the sands of Spec Ops: The Line. Now of course that comparison gives Soul Suspect a lot more credit than it deserves, it’s a far from perfect game and certainly won’t be looked back on as a game design milestone. But while I expected a more or less point and click hidden object game with fancy 3D graphics and bizarrely contrived QTE’s, what I got was a decent story entwined in a fascinating and well fleshed out word with fantastic mechanics to handle action sequences.

Honestly, yes. If I had to boil this game down into a single genre I would have to go with a point and click adventure. The main backbone of the game is walking from crime scene to crime scene and pressing X when you spot a clue. There is certainly nothing revolutionary about the mechanic but the content of the clues- and to a much larger extent the collectibles- brings to light a remarkably well imagined world. Now I’m not well versed in the history of Salem and the details of the witch trials, but I think the writers put in a good amount of creative effort bringing an engaging fictional story into a very real place and time. Typically the little factoids littered around the game world only appeal to completionist minded individuals like myself, however I found myself on a multitude of occasions scouring the town for that last entry to figure out the end of a story.

The visuals of the game are adequate, nothing that I didn’t expect after looking at 2 or 3 screenshots. I was able to run the game mostly maxed out on my 680 and the framerate was stable and consistent.

Here is the thing that made the game for me: the “final boss”. Don’t worry I will not spoil a thing, and it was actually the absence of something which made it utterly refreshing and a huge relief. Aside from a handful of action-y stealth segments with demons, the game is slow and narrative driven. As I felt the story come closer and closer to a close I got this feeling of dread. You see I know how AAA games go nowadays, every fiber of my being was expecting this dreadful quick time event unfair boss fight that has no continuity with the entire rest of the game. I was even tempted to not finish the game myself and watch the ending online because I didn’t want to walk away from such a great experience with a terrible taste in my mouth. Yet the developers NAILED it. No it’s not a spectacle and no it’s not brutally difficult, but it was satisfying and conclusive to the narrative. The amount of relief I felt at the ending was overwhelming.

I’ve harped a lot on a very little point of the game, but it was a big reason this game left me with such a positive view of it. Murdered: Soul Suspect is not perfect but it’s a breath of fresh air for narrative centric games and it kept me engaged and entertained the whole way through.

reviewText: To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the ♥♥♥ to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

reviewText:
Having seen footage of the very first part of the game, I was curious about the story. The characters and detective esque gameplay seemed interesting. So, I purchased the game and have only just finished it. The game is about a detective who has to find the mystery behind his own murder. This game was played with a 360 controller.

Lots of text following, so:
tldr; amazing cat simulator, 10/10
serious tldr; Only buy if you are interested in the story only and not in it as a game. And only then when it is on sale.

numbers tldr;
Gameplay      [3/10] - not much of it
World            [2/10] - felt empty
Story             [6.7/10] - not as exciting or interesting as I hoped, but still good. Narrated short side stories were very entertaining, and eerie.
Graphics        [6/10] - adequate
Sound            [5/10] - nothing noteworthy or memorable, but adequate
Voice Acting   [6.7/10] - mixed feelings, bland NPCs are bland, main characters are quite okay.

You can move freely as a ghost, passing through real world objects such as walls. The design here is quite well done, clipping through objects felt quite natural in this game and definitely was an interesting experience. You grow quite quickly accustomed by it, and by the time you do the novelty of it does wear off as fast (atleast it did for me). Even though you can pass through some objects, ghostly objects and certain walls still limit you. More and more as you progress through the game, making it feel like any other regular game.

Gameplay wise, throughout the story you encounter different crime" scenes and are left to examine it. This involves some looking around

reviewText:
Right then, I just finished the game.

Let me start by saying that I like playing detective and love trying to solve puzzles on my own. I don't even mind if the graphics are bad, as long as the gameplay works and the plotline keeps me interested.

When the game started I thought it seemed alright. The whole ghost detective trying to solve his own murder wasn't a bad idea and had quite some potential.

Woe is me now, having paid 40 euros for something that lasted for 17 hours, and only so long because I kept on exploring the extremely limited environments that seem to be a trademark of Squaresoft's games these days. The player is guided by both arms like a blind and handicapped elderly through the mediocre and predictable story. God forbid anyone who pays good money for the game should have to think for themselves.

And it's not just that. The whole game was more like getting from one lengthy cutscene to another. The only times you can screw up or die is when battling" demons
hoursPlayed:
mean pressing two keys that show up on the screen in the correct order when close to a demon.

How exciting.

There was really only one thing I enjoyed in this game

reviewText:
This review will be in separate parts when ever I want to complain about the game. But every bit of this review is constructive criticism.

First three areas explored in:

I am already offended by this game for its lack of social construction. This game's dialogue seems to have bits and pieces of an idea together but are poorly sewn together. If you are a private investigator or an FBI profiler you will be saddened by this game. For the dialogue choices seem to route you to the same answer, but are shallow in complete thought. I get the idea behind this game being the main story line but my problem with this game so far is not your maneuverability, or lack of direction. But more or so to the approach this game takes when it comes to solving the cases. It seems like the person who created this plot forgot that detectives constantly talk to themselves while piecing together a story. Though to be fair it says in the text right there what it wants you to do. But it should be stated by the detective to help people figure out what is going on. The text floating around as you try to piece things together will throw you off guard as soon as a change of course happens within the solving of each small puzzle.

While trying to figure out one thing it suddenly switches... but our friend the detective doesn't say much and it quickly moves on to the next thing. So you miss what the text changed to, telling you what you are supposed to look for now, at that very split second given moment and you guess wrong. Worst of all is the clunky UI. You mess something up it freezes you... pauses.... backs out.... brings up several different separate tab screens for each object which suddenly takes away the purpose for searching it, (which is why I say again it would help if the detective was constantly talking to himself in thought to keep the main point in focus.) And quite frankly leaves me bewildered at what happens when you try again."

Maybe the approach to this method should have used better sorting options.... Throwing things around all the time makes me think this detective never carried around so much as a book. Possibly carried around a recording device seeing how disorderly everything being displayed becomes.

Just imagine that every time you came up with the idea behind a string of events you got angered
date: and suddenly threw up all the information you just looked at in frustration... only to come right back to it
hoursPlayed: as all the papers fall to the ground and you have this game. I think the creator... if he is or was a detective... must have had little to no patience himself in each case. Possibly due to extra ordinary means like time or money allotted to his investigations. Maybe a sergeant or person's interest was a timely manner. I am still willing to give this a second try but it is so demanding on your eyes
voteText: more or so than your brain
helpfulPercent: that it causes you to lose concentration quite easily.\n\nAnd the demons? My goodness. Talk about an annoying trap puzzle that springs up like a jack in the box that malfunctions a lot. I get the idea behind exorcising ghosts... but uh.... how does our detective friend just suddenly know how to exorcise a ghost exactly? Was our friend the detective a priest? There is no mention of him being one in his own background... But just barely minutes into the game
votesHelpful: you have the ability to exorcise a ghost without having to read any books about it. I think this game would have been a lot more interesting with the setup it seemed to hold. In which I think the Detective originally did not know how to exorcise ghosts until later in the game. But I guess the devs thought it would be too annoying to make players fear them so early. Yet it would have been a lot more fun and made more sense if the ability wasn't there until you figured it out.\n\nThis game seems to be targeted at kids more or so than adults seeing how there are some "way too soft" spots that spring up like a bad smell. You will literally yell at our detective to "JUST GRAB HER F***ING ARM!" When it comes to solving one of the cases. I want to slap the detective for being so.... retentively sympathetic
votesTotal:
yet wise cracking at certain times.

Also the girl? Best idea ever when it comes to surprising your audience when you finally meet her for the first time. But there was one inconsistency that happened at the cemetery... She complained about not being able to see him... even though she was holding a flashlight... Then a few minutes later she has no trouble seeing them. Could have been the lamp post nearby but uh.... She did shine a flashlight on him.


Last three bits:

Am I ever more disappointed in a game? This game answered that question. Incredibly short game. I am sad. I am so sad after completing this game.

The best puzzle is the ending.

I think the issue is that the development team behind this had an astonishingly awesome idea.... but I think budget cuts really let this game down. This game had some real potential but it is so short lived. The ending seems to be pasted together. But at least it did create one hell of a mind ♥♥♥♥. It is just too bad the whole time you believe one thing because of your own abilities... and then there is another. What the hell.

Too short. Way too short. My final complaint? Some of the "side missions" are broken.

This game should be twitch viewed only."

reviewText: A first impression here. It's not bad as some of the review sites out there might want you to believe. It's and adventure game, think LA Noire without the action and driving. It's a slower paced game where you'll have to look around for clues to solve puzzles to move to the next area, so if you're looking for an action FPS or something like that, it probably won't be for you. It's a good looking game with better graphics than watchdogs that I picked up last week, and has alot of graphics settings to play with, runs smooth on ultra/high on my HD 7870, although the frames per second seem to be locked to 30. I'd give it a 7 out of ten, it is kind of pricey though for what it is, but would definitely reccomend it at say $25.

reviewText:
I am a casual female gamer, not great with button mashing. I really love rich story lines, rpg styled play, and puzzles! This game included all of that. If you're casual like me, it's a great point and click that isn't boring. Too often I find the point and clicks are slow paced, but this isn't.

Most of the game is really innate. You know what your goals are and what you have to do. I rarely needed to look something up, so that's a plus for the casual gamer.

The storyline is reallllly cool, the characters, the voice acting, all of it.

My only negative is I didn't clue in to just how open the world was. You can explore a lot and do side quests and I missed a lot of them because I was only following the storyline. Newb mistake for sure, so be sure you do all the fun stuff on the side to get all the achievements.

Graphics and controls were great.

So... this game...

Well, I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, so I cannot complain about it as such - it was an interesting experience.

reviewText: Murdered is a game with an interesting idea and showed a lot of promise before it was released; a game where you play a deceased detective hunting down his murderer whilst solving crimes and using ghost powers, what's not to love? Well the problem is that the game is ultimately short and, frankly, boring - there is nothing to do outside of the main quest aside from FOUR side-quests and a bunch of collectables no one really cares about; the use of ghost walls, while a good concept, are only present to hide how small the environment is; and the biggest problem? This game is far too easy. It has a points system depending on how well you solve the crimes, but this doesn't actually have any impact whatsoever, and there is no penalty for making a wrong judgement, sure you lose a point but even after you lose them all you can keep on guessing. Oh and this game can be painfully short, if you're good at it you can complete in under 4 hours (or if you want to speedrun and miss the cutscenes - the story is the best part of the game, mind you - you can complete it in about 2). So yes, Murdered is an OK game, but it's one that will be played once and probably be forgotten about soon after playing it. However I do recommend playing it, but get when its on sale.

reviewText:
I'm going to begin by voicing my displeasure at the fact that steam has only a two means of reviewing a game. The bright blue thumbs up or red thumbs down is the first thing people see and it is criminal that I'm forced to open my opinion with either a blatant recommendation or condemnation, as it is often never that simple. Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of those games that I feel very ambivalent towards. It gets a thumbs down though for reasons I'll gladly expound upon here but I'll start by saying that If you do want to buy this game, go ahead, but do it at a discount as there isn't enough of it to warrant its full price by a long shot.

Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural intrigue game where you play as Ronan O'Connor, gangland warrior turned detective and wandering samurai warrior, who is tracking a mysterious serial killer. Ronan is about apprehend the killer in the opening cutscene when the killer decides he's had enough of the law and reenacts the opening scene from Watchmen all over Ronan's face before shooting him seven times in the chest. So Ronan is dead, but you knew that already. Ronan now has to endeavor to do in one night what the entire police force couldn't do in years worth of time and solve the case of the Bell Killer. M:SS reminds me of two very specific games I actually liked, the first of which is Alan Wake. Like Alan Wake, this game is about supernatural dealings with a distinctly traditional American feel. Also like AW, the rules for the supernatural stuff in this game are very well defined.

The supernatural lore being dealt with this time is ghosts, exploring all the traditional facets of what you might think ghosts are like, but before you go hog wild there is an exception to each of your abilities. You can pass through walls but not consecrated or ethereal walls, which mark the level boundaries. You can jumble electronics, but not to any meaningful degree. You can possess people but not control their actions. You can teleport, but not over demon holes so you still have to circumvent those on foot. Also like in Alan Wake, there isn't a whole lot to do in between plot points except hunt for collectibles. This leads me into the real issue I had with this game: its design.

Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game of extra steps. I kept a running list of things the game took more than one step to complete without needing to: Often the game will end a cutscene just to have you press the interact button to continue the same cutscene. When questioning a suspect, you have to press a button for each option you want to explore but the interrogation doesn't end until all options are explored, so it might as well be one long cutscene. You can read the minds of people you possess but each person has exactly two things to say and you have to press the button twice to hear both things when they could just say them both at once. When piecing together the clues of an investigation, if you pick a wrong option you get booted from the screen, having to reenter the screen to continue. When grabbing collectibles, you have to reveal the object first before picking it up. The collectibles are half hidden but the game tells you where they are so there's no need for hiding them. Speaking of collectibles, there are a plethora of them, all of which have very little to no bearing on the actual game. Each area has a unique object that, once all are gathered, will unlock  a spooky campfire story unrelated to what you are doing. There are a series of over arching collectibles including diary pages from Ronan's dead wife (really the only means of character development), handy info blurbs copy-pasted from the Salem tourism comity website, and newspaper clippings reminding you how creepy and invincible the serial killer is.

While Alan Wake also felt the need to boldly announce the appearance of an enemy so that there is no way for you to be caught off guard, at least it had engaging combat. Every once in a while the game breaks up the monotony by presenting you with enemies to sneak up behind and quick-time-event to death. Once or twice a level, there will be demons that half-heatedly wander around in an enclosed area. You have to hide in the hiding spot and wait for the monster to turn around so you can slowly walk up behind it and kill it. This ends up being tedious and non-threatening, unit you mess up. If you manage to not properly dispatch your spectral foe, the backlash is absurd. Demons will kill you within a 3-5 second window unless you can scurry back to a hiding spot. However, once detected, the demons can see you in hiding spots; forcing you to shift between them as fast and erratically as possible until they give up. This turns what little combat there is into a game of Red Light, Green Light. These sections make no sense to the lore of the game either as there is no reason given as to why Ronan seems to be the only ghost that can dispatch the demons. No introduction is given to the power nor is it explained that Ronan is the only one capable of it, leading me to wonder why the other ghosts all flee in terror when the demons show up.

The second game I'm reminded of is L.A. Noire, because the investigation sections are reminiscent of the ones in that game. You have to walk around the crime scene and collect the clues, using them to piece together the motive of the criminal. There are six to fourteen clues per scene but only three of them at most are ever necessary to continue. It's no secret that detective work is not as flashy or intriguing as it is portrayed in popular culture, but no where is this more obvious than video games. L.A. Noire had a good mix of action and detective work, due (I think) to it's structure. All the clues were relevant because solving the case was the goal of the mission and everything unfolded naturally. Murdered, by contrast, has you investigating glaringly obvious crime scenes which, more often than not, inform you of something you already knew. For example, one crime scene later on in the game has you investigating a room full of people the Bell Killer murdered all at once. At the point of investigation, however, you have already been made aware of what the killer did afterword, so the reason for killing the room full of people is obvious. Then, once you investigate the room, Ronan stands there and tells the the reason the killer did it, even though you already knew. Really the investigating is just being a master of the obvious. It's also impossible to fail to find all of the clues, because the game tells you how many are present in the scene.

Murdered, like many games these days, would have probably made a better book or movie. The game play really just consists of different kinds of walking around and looking at things. Despite being a game made by an established developer and publisher, this is something any indie dev could have made, if not made look quite as good. In the end, games are meant to be interactive; that is what the medium excels at. Yet more and more it seems like games are being made with interactivity at the bottom of their priority list. Once during the middle of a cutscene I caught my self replying to text messages. It was then I realized how bored I was with the game; how absolutely unengaged I felt. The story was really not all that bad but being set in Salem, you can bet with reliability that it will have to do with what Salem is famous for. I would rather them have just made a movie out of it and cut out the game play entirely. At least then it would have taken me only 120 minutes to get through.

reviewText: MURDERED isn't really a game. It's more of an interactive story/movie with movement, It has a very interesting premise, but in my opinion it failed to deliver on that punch which it desperately needed and strived for.\n\nFor the gameplay" mechanics
recommended: try to find and examine every object
hoursPlayed: then have infinite tries to choosing the correct ones that apply to move the story along. Sometimes this involves influencing people by possessing them
voteText: but that's only during scripted moments and does nothing useful when you possess the NPCs walking around the world. It's the same when you "poltergeist" an object (turn it on/mess it up for a few seconds). Lifeless NPCs will not react unless it's a scripted moment for the story.\n\nThere are enemies in the game
helpfulPercent: demons
votesHelpful: and you can walk behind them and try your hand at a randomized QTE where you'll have to press one button from WASD and use the left or right click to destroy the demon. If you fail
votesTotal: which you will due to the poor controls of this
votesFunny:
then you'll have to jump into ghost fragments around the level to avoid getting your soul sucked until the demon gives up. This is all of the "action" in the story and it's more of a waste of time than anything. There is no boss fight or no real reason for destroying demons. Their AI is on a predetermined route and they're just an inconvenience for scouring a level for the collectible items.

Each area has a different amount of collectibles. These unlock urban legend/ghost stories that are just a picture and a person monologuing. That's really it for the entire game's mechanics outside of possessing a cat and following a predetermined route with no real obstacles/puzzles. There's literally nothing interesting to do in this game beyond solving the main storyline with its pre-determined deductivity.

All in all
commentsCount: I can't recommend this as a game. If you're looking for the great supernatural mystery thriller of our time this is far from that. But if you're looking to chance it for a story that you may (or may not) enjoy and you're willing to overlook about 8 hours of lacking gameplay

reviewText:
Pros:
+Only cost me $5.
+Wasn't worse than a $5 fast food combo.

Cons:
-Not a game.
-Horribly written dialogue.
-needlessly retreads Salem witch trial tropes; completely sensationalizing the very real murders of real women for the sake of entertainment.
-Do modern game developers not understand how adventure games are supposed to work? (Go play Ace Attorney. Space Quest. Monkey Island. Grim Fandango even.)
-combat? You 'sneak' up on the reaper from the Frighteners(about a thousand times) and kill them all with the same stupid quicktime event.
-didn't feel like I got my five dollars worth, but I come from the generation who rented video games on cartridges, so oh well.

2/10

reviewText: Murdered Soul Suspect is the last game made by Airtight games, Did the go out with a bang ? In Murdered Soul Suspect you play as Ronan o connor. Salem is haunted by a serial killer named the Bell killer. One day Ronan Finds the trail of the bell killer but gets killed in the process. Ronan returns as a ghost but hes unable to move on until he finds out who killed him. In the proccess he meets Jane who the killer is trying to hunt down. So its youre job to protect her from the killer while trying to find out who killed you. So how is Murdered ? Its actually a great game. The best way i could put it would be a supernatural LA Noire. The game is essiantly you interogating ghosts and people who can see you know as mediums. The game lets you posses people and cats. Mess with electronics and stuff like that. Theres also fighting segments where you have to fight ghost while trying to aproach them from the back. But if they see you you will have to hide because you cant fight them head on. So now for the pros and cons. The game has a great story and a great twist ending. The game is fun and simple. Great puzzles to solve and tons of collectibles to collect. The cons: the game is kinda glitchy and its also really short. Overall Murdered Soul Suspect is a great game and i suggest you buy it because simply put it its a great game and Airtight Games will be missed. I give Murdered Soul Suspect a 8/10

reviewText:
Best Part: You possess a cat.
Worst Part: Combat and QTE.

I was really expecting this game to be good, and I tried to enjoy it. I recently finished it (6 hours with 77% of achievements unlocked) and I only recommend if you really want to play for the theme.

Note: UI is terrible, play with a controller if you have one. Pressing 1/3 and Q/E to change tabs is a no-no and shows that it's a port.

First off, you don't really do any detective work, I often got the answers to detective questions wrong because I was over thinking and in the end, I sometimes tried multiple times until I got it right.

The town is simply dull, some NPCs keep walking in the same path, really killing the atmosphere, they also have only two lines of dialogue, which are boring. Since there's no map/minimap, there was one time that I got lost and had to keep running all over the place trying to find my way. The barriers they added to limit the scope of the game are horrible, making the game feel more linear than it should have.

Also, the combat is simply terrible, you can see they added this part only to make the game lengthier because it's not fun at all. The QTE buttons keep changing, making you sometimes fail and get annoyed.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is my first review, so I'll try to keep it simple.

This game is aggressively mediocre. For a puzzle game, the puzzles are never very engaging, but then again, not a lot of puzzles can be done if the main character can't touch things. Every brain teaser is either 'pick the obvious clue' or 'pick the obvious series of clues'. Sometimes you have to do them in the right order, wow.

The combat/stealth is practically non-existant. Occasionally demons will jump out accompanied with the sound a piano might make if it were thrown through a window. It shocked me the first time it happened, then never again. You disable them by running up behind them and doing a simple qte. This is made incredibly easy since they cannot see through walls. You, on the other hand, can both see and walk through walls. Dissapointing.

Oh, and the many hiding spots in the overworld kept me constantly wondering if I might get jumped at one point. Never happened. Why even have them there?

The story itself is okay, but it suffers from the protagonist having never even heard of withces before, and he's lived all his damn life in Salem, of all places. Sometimes there are no excuses. And the ending, oh god, the ending was a major dissapointment. It lasted all of 5 minutes and most of that was cutscenes.

That said, I really enjoyed all the interactions between characters. All the ghosts are kind of one note characters, but the humans were kind of special to me. The way they reacted to your death and subsecuent actions made them seem more real and alive then most other characters I can recall offhand. They all mourn and act in their own way and even though this is not a big game, I can't say that there are any living characters that I disliked.

Ending... uh. Rent it, I guess? At least wait untill it goes down in price. A 10 hour game does not deserve a 40$ price tag. Definitely get it if you really, really like collecting stuff.

reviewText:
MSS is pretty much a PNC adventure game masquerading as a modern cinematic AAA game (which I don't find any better, by the way).  While the game has merit for any adventure game fan, know that the story falls apart and I doubt anyone will be satisfied with it.  So with such a major hook of pnc games not really delivering, what are you left with?

At its heart, MSS is your typical textbook modern game design, except the main character doesn't carry a gun and you don't run around shooting at pop-up targets.  Instead, you are tasked with investigating your own death, complete with spritely sidekick and canned TWEEST.  This in itself isn't bad as mysteries often need to have at least some sort of turning point and well, being dead kind of demands you have a real-world sidekick to help you out.

However, being of modern game design, MSS falls into the trap of checklist design; that is to say, it takes no risks and does pretty much everything by the book.  Exploration?  Check.  Voice actors?  Check.  Cinematics?  Check.  Hidden objects?  Check.  Progessive ability unlocking?  Check, check, check.  None of this bad, really; just saying it brings nothing new to the table.  The worst offender is the checkbox for action - because why would anyone play a game without action in it, right?  Pfft.  From time to time you will be forced to deal with a completely useless and forced section where you sneak around bad guys and try to get rid of 'em (or circumvent them entirely once you're tired of this ♥♥♥♥) because someone in development land has decided that under no circumstance should a game of this type be without an action sequence; problem is, it's stupid and provides nothing to the game other than padding and, of course, a checkbox.  Similarly, you'll be tasked several times to arbitrarily click on multiple clues to proceed through the game and it gets old fast - at least it's thematically sound what with the main character being a detective.  Whatever.

Anyways, as far as fans of PNC games goes, this one isn't that bad.  The game has a runtime of approximately 8 hours, maybe 6.5 if you don't bother looking for all the hidden stuff (which is also pointless, but allows you to do some checklisting yourself).  I wouldn't recommend getting this at full price in any shape or form, but if you get a decent deal on it, say... $10 just to cover some of the production value, then why not give it a run-through?  It's kind of like watching the latest sci-fi space opera film just because you don't often see them being made and not because it's actually really good.  MSS is just a decent effort.

tl;dr: Adventure game fans may enjoy this game on theme alone, but anyone looking for a meaty game experience will find that this offering is leaner than that girl you used to know whose bones could be counted individually when she had her shirt off.  So this remains a (meh) thumbs-up for adventure game fans, but a thumbs-down for anyone else.

reviewText:
I was actually enjoying this game until I encountered a game-breaking glitch near the end of Chapter 2. What I assume I was supposed to do was use my poltergeist ability on the vacuum to get the priest to walk over the vortex thingy on the floor so I could possess him and safely cross to the other side of the hallway.

As it turns out, the priest decided to be a bishop, in the sense that he only moved diagonally. He crossed over and clipped into the wall opposite the vacuum cleaner, and when I possessed him he moved diagonally across the vortex, clipped into another wall, and walked in a courtyard where I could not unpossess him.

I tried restarting the checkpoint. I tried letting the priest make a single trip and then using poltergeist on the vacuum a second time before possessing him. I tried starting the game over from the beginning. I tried reinstalling the game. I even tried starting the game from the beginning AFTER reinstalling, but nothing worked.

So I checked Google for answers, but couldn't find any solutions. That's when I gave up. Even if there is a solution, I refuse to sit through the same unskippable cutscenes for a fourth time in the hopes that maybe I'll be able to get past the second chapter.

If you're thinking of buying this game, don't. There's an old flash game on Newgrounds called The Dead Case"
date: which is similar yet vastly superior despite being from 2004. Not only is it free
recommended: but it actually functions like it's supposed to.\n"

reviewText:
Rented this game on console and it was alright, probably around a 6/10 for me. A friend gifted me the PC version when it was on sale, so most of my experience is with the console version and not the pc version.

Some great ideas and some nice graphics but this could have been soooo much better. If you want a style of game like this I would say go play all of the Tex Murphy detective games or even LA NOIRE.

The story is a mess, the characters are pretty meh and it is just not all that fun of a game. Far from terrible but I can't help but think this could have been so much more with another year or some different design decisions. The atmosphere is also pretty well done.

If it is $5 or $10 on sale it is worth a go, but as I said above, I would go hit up Tex Murphy series, Police Quest series or even LA NOIRE instead.

reviewText:
While I did enjoy the game a little, it is hard to recommend. Firstly, because it is very short. I wasn’t trying to find all the hidden bits, but I was fairly thorough and the game still only took me 7 hours to complete.

I’m pretty sure you could leave a chimp alone in a room with this game and if you rewarded it with a banana for solving each mystery, you’d have a chubby and happy chimp by the end of the day.

It had a lot of potential and the voice acting was quite good, but almost every element felt unfinished. If you can get it for around £4 then it might be worthwhile, but I certainly wouldn’t want to pay any more than that.

My main issue, is that it was really obvious what was happening from a very early stage (I won’t say how early because that would spoil things, but it is pretty damn early). It also doesn’t matter when you figure out the “Mystery”, you have to listen to your idiot protagonist come to obvious conclusion after obvious conclusion and follow every red herring until you reach the final revelation.

reviewText:
A boring Telltale type of game for those that enjoy watching a story instead of playing a video game. The idea is interesting enough. Be a cop, get killed by some jerk, come back and solve the mystery to your death from beyond the grave.
But what you get is just so plain and lazy. I don't play games for their 3rd rate stories, I play for the gameplay.

Not to mention that this is just a plain terrible port. 30 FPS cap randomly applies at times, mouse senstitivity has three options. Low, Medium, High. Wow, thanks guys, amazing job. The whole options menu is plain lacking, and the game eats up more performance than it should.
I also don't appreciate lazy game design. Some guy was haunting a kid after he died, and got  eaten by a demon  and disappeared. When I came back and reloaded the save, I found him in the exact same spot, except that I couldn't talk to him. The little girl's scripted MOMMY" sequence replayed again. Why does reloading a save cause everything to reset improperly? This game is not worth your time or money."

reviewText:
So far Fahrenheit/Indigo Prophecy was my favourite adventure game,Murdered comes very very close.It is definitly the best adventure game of the last 10 years or so.

In the game we play as Ronan former criminal who became a detective and died,yes died.We solve the case of our own murder,now say what you want i havent play something like that yet!Its great,original,very climitical,the atmosphere is a mix of modern times with old sql noir,which works perfectly and the action takes place in the city of Salem,how cool is that?

Its a cinematic game,like imo every adventure game should be so i love it.On the visual side Murdered is fantastic,gret graphics,pretty good map design,animations are fine theres really nothing wrong with visuals.

On the gameplay like I said as its a cinematic game,on times you gonna feel like playing a movie,similiar to Fahrenheit,again for me this is great.

So what we have here is a great,climatic,adventure game,that is original in pretty much every sens,some people say its short,idk imagine a movie 7-9h long ;)

I dont want to give you any spoilers,Im just gonna say that story got me engaged,interested and entertained from the begining to the end.

8/...sorry this game allowed me to posses a cat :3 9/10

reviewText:
In Murdered: Soul Suspect you play the role of a deceased cop whose spirit is trapped in our world and unable to pass on tot he afterlife due to the mysterious circumstances surrounding his brutal murder. It combines crime scene investigations with ghostly manipulation, set tpo the backdrop of a modern day Salem.

First and foremost, Ronan (the main character) has easily become one of my favorite protagonists in recent history; here you have a kid raised by the streets who knew nothing but a life of crime until one day he grows up and is offered the chance to turn it all around and make something of himself - thus he ends up joining the force and becoming a detective, though his past still haunts him and his newfound reputation. He's got a tattoo from every major event in his life - the good and the bad - and he totes a massive glock both gifted by and named after his mother. What's not to like?

The story is pretty straightforward - get killed by bad guy, hunt down and stop bad guy, pass on - but it's all brought together quite nicely. A strong voice cast and shiny graphics go a long way, too; Salem is looking just awesome!

Gameplay, as stated earlier, combines crime scene investigations with ghostly manipulation. That last bit probably needs some elaboration though. Basically, you're a ghost. Most buildings will be off limits, though they tie this into the story - being you're in Salem (home to ancient witch hunts), many of the houses have been consecrated long ago. However, open doors or windows are free game. You can also pass through interior walls and doors (so long as they don't lead to the outside world) and a variety of other solid objects. You can also possess people to read their minds or even influence them in certain ways, or manipulate certain objects to attract attention (TVs, radios, even vaccuum cleaners).

All in all, this title is living up to just about ervery expectation I had for it and then some.

reviewText: Murdered Soul Suspect is a game with a spiffing idea and concept but there are rather a few problems. The gameplay in general is wonderful and something I have certainly not seen before in a game. But it's about as easy as putting the kettle on, and apart from a few pesky demons who are out to spill your beloved Earl Grey, there isn't much of a threat or feeling that you will lose, but this may have been a challenge to pull off since you are dead already! The detective side of it all is similar to the wonderful game L.A. Noire but in Murdered: Soul Suspect there isn't as much of a challenge, as you will eventually solve the cases whether you muck it up or not. Having said this I believe it's rather worth a go anyway, as it is jolly good fun! The main story is very well thought out and the whole idea of it is entirely new and I tip my hat off to it for that very reason. I would also say that if the opportunity arises a sequel would be well worth a shot as they could improve on these hiccups and make a spiffing game! All in all I give this 3 and a half cups of tea out of 5 for it's originality, story and the rather spiffing attempt at bringing us something a little different. Tally-Ho!

reviewText:
firstly i want to highlight that this game has some truly great writting. i mean bioware levels of good writting. the core story of this game is that you play detective Ronan O'Connor who is murdered investigating a serial killler in the twon of Salem. the story follows the detectives journey to discovere the identity and reason for his murder assissting others along the way .

first thing i want to say is that this game has a very heavy L.A Noire feel. if you didnt like L.A noire then you wont like this and vice versa if you like it then Murdered: Soul Suspect is the game for you. the core factors of this game are the story and the investigations. being a police officer the investigation skills were always going to play a big part in this game. the first investigation is very basic as to act as a tutorial to the player. the investigations are the primary form of gameplay with the player having to use their initiative to search the scene for clues and piece togethor what has happened. finding the clues themselves is not as simple as you'd think either with some of the investigations requiring a thourough search to find all the pieces of the pouzzle. for example in an investigation in the towns museum i found most of the clues fairly easily but the last clue proved to be a real pain in the ♥♥♥♥.. a painting hidden deep behind a shelf covered with boxes to obscure it, even worse the room was dark and the painting is black. i only managed to find the clue after about 30 minutes of searching and a lot of cursing haha. but even though the game can be a difficult at points it has a great sense of rewarding when you finish an investigation and unlock another piece of the puzzle.

another asoect that is important in this game is the mechanics, admittadly in a game where that focus's more on makingthe player think than the character being pushed to the limit the mechanics are as expected very solid, basics are obviously solid, running, looking, and interacting with objects are the core of the game but there is a few other core mechanics that are done quite well. as a ghost detective O'Connor has the abillity to interact with otherworldly objects in the town of Salem such as floors, walls, doors, staircases and ramps. this can be a diffficult mechanic to get right as the character is basically adding in game enviroment (i've developed a few games and tried to do this myself its not as easy as it sounds aha) but Square Enix have gotten it right here with a seamless addittion to the enviroment at the instruction of the player opening up new parts of the town. the other mechanic done well is the teleportation mechanic (not a spoiler as you see other ghosts doing this straight off the bat) the teleporting is only short range to avoid you jumping all the way over town in one go. it takes a few seconds to charge up but it comes in handy at points when looking for clues. the only mechanics i take issue with are the possession mechanics. now these work pretty well but its not as well rounded as the other mechanics, it can be a bit difficult to focus on the person you are trying to possess sometimes which made me slightly irritated to be honest.

the story writting for this game is as i said though VERY well done. what this game is, is essentially an interactive  detective thriller novel. the story plays out just as you'd expect but with some very well placed twists. i guarantee if you play this game you will guess wrong about the identity of the killer. the various games twists are very well placed but none more than the end .. no spoilers .. but it is very well placed and just about the last thing i expected playing this game.

finaly i shall examine the look of this game. the graphics for this game are very pretty but not overwhelmingly stunning. for the pc it isnt the best i quality i was expecting. it has a more console feel in terms of graphics which isnt really a bad thing. it doesn't do anything to damage the feel of the game as it still looks very good, the cinematics are nicely done keeping a similair graphical level to the game itself which i think works better for the way the game transitions from cut scene to actual gameplay. i would love to see this game with a more beautiful asthetic look to enhance aspects such as the moving through wiast high objects or to make Detective O'Connor himself maybe a bit easier on the eye.

in short i very much reccomend this game if you are looking for a good story and to make yourself think a bit more than the usual game. the story will engross you while the investigations and the twists will keep you guessing until the game is ready to reward you with answers. there is also a hint of sarcy dry humour that i liked from Ronan which i think makes him more likeable but you can make your own mind up about that. i reccomend this game as a solid 8/10 .. its very good but not flawless and i doubt you will regret giving it a play

reviewText:
Finished the game in about 7-8 hours and here is my review.

+Unique story
+Unique gameplay
+Very good voice acting
+Completionists and supernatural fans would enjoy this very much above the usual casual gamers
+Sheds light to the history of witches and Salem
+Characters are very interesting and have separate background stories

+/- Impossible to fail, not very challenging
+/-Has a very niche audience, not your average game

-Tends to have some weird issues (Couldn't put AA over high or else a green hue would overshadow everything, lost control of mouse and/or keyboard, which could only be resolved with restarting the game, crashed a few times)
-Very short, i completed in about 7-8 hours, while still getting over 200 collectibles and completing most sidequests.
-For the content you are getting kinda pricey
-Feels rushed in some parts, there are a lot of fillers collectibles" so that you wouldn't complete the game faster
-No replayability
date: some people (including myself) see this as a bit similar to L.A Noire
recommended:
however your options don't have any consequences and you can't go back to mend your mistakes or replay a story in a different way like you would in L.A Noire
-Extremely sandboxed/linear

Overall rating would be a solid 7 out of 10 spooks
However if you don't like detective games or anything to do with the supernatural i wouldn't recommend this
hoursPlayed:
although it wouldn't hurt you to try out a new genre for yourself.

reviewText:
Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of my favorite games of the year so far.
8.75/10

I thought this game would be good, but it surpassed everything I expected and was a blast to play the whole time.

+Environment Variety
+Approximately 11 hour campaign (If you get all collectibles)
+Well written story that keeps you invested (and has some good twists)
+Wealth of collectibles to find, all with back-stories
+Though basic, there a plenty of fun stealth/battle sequences
+Interesting Side Quests
+Though it helps you out, it genuinely makes you feel like a detective
+It's just a blast playing as a ghost and using all the abilities that comes with it.
+The cats (you'll see)

-No enemy variety
-No takedown variety with enemies
-Sometimes you are helped too much, you almost never have to worry about failure

Overall, the game is a blast to play and well worth your time. If you want a game that truly makes you feel like a detective or even if you've ever just wondered what it would be like to be a ghost, this game is for you.

reviewText: This isn't a game. It's more like a barely interactive movie. The gameplay is nearly non-existent, besides the 3000 quicktime and other single-button-press events. You get cool powers like Reveal" and "Remove" but are never given the opportunity to use them for anything other than the aforementioned single press events. I was waiting for the puzzle where you have to combine your powers in some clever way. But unfortunately
date:
that never happens. There is not a single puzzle in the entire game where you actually have to use your brain.

The only positive is that the story is actually pretty good. I was engaged enough that I really did want to find out who the killer was. And the history parts of it were pretty entertaining yet educational.

It's unfortunate that the rest of the "game" is so poor and lacking any sort of polish whatsoever. For example
recommended: when you walk near an NPC
hoursPlayed: they have one voice. Then you possess them and read their mind
voteText: they have a totally different voice. Very jarring. Not to mention the incredible amount of voiceover repetition amongst all NPCs. Another issue is trying to target objects and enemies is often a frustrating mess. Walking up to an enemy
helpfulPercent: seeing the prompt to "attack"
votesHelpful: and then having it suddenly disappear causing you to die is maddening beyond belief. It's made worse only by the fact that it happens so often. The targetting is really
votesTotal: really off in this game. These are small issues

reviewText: The reason for not reccomending this game is because it tries to be something its not. The game is heavily based off of finding clues, reading minds, and peacing together unsolved puzzles. What makes the game not what it should be is the combat system, it shouldnt be there. The only enemy you face the whole game is Demons. How to kill a demon is incredibley simple and very tedious, you walk up behind it and hold RT (if using an xbox controller) and then a quick time event pops up where you have to move the directional stick in a combination with a button. The demons only appear at certain points during the game and i always dreaded fighting them. They arent very scary but rely heavily on jump scares so you will accasionally get caught off gaurd and get spooked. The combat in this game feels like a very last minute thing" that the Devs were forced to implement. They are essentially cheap game lengtheners that take you away from the story
date: forcing you to spend 10 minutes on some idiotic sneak/quicktime minigame. The game would have been SO much better without the tedious demon encounters. Other than that
recommended: the game is very enjoyable and the story is above average and makes you feel sympathy toward certain characters. Playing this game kinda felt like watching an episode of scooby doo because once you think youve found out what is going on
hoursPlayed: it turns out to be completely different."

reviewText:
if you’re comfortable with death, and the afterlife as a subject matter then this is a gem of a game. the game runs well, it looks really nice. kind of a pain to get running but once you do, you’ll be in for a treat. you have the main story, but also little side quests, even the collectables once collected unlock a short horror story.
i really enjoyed my time with this, it’s rather short (10 hours) and would love for there to be some DLC but with how the story ends i am not sure how. *it’s more Michael J. Fox’s The Frighteners than anything scary. no jump scares, but you’re on edge at times due to the awesome soundtrack the game has.

caveat emptor (buyer beware): there’s a HUGE problem with this game, it won’t launch :(

1.
turn off, exit out of any recording software. i use DXtory. for me i normally use this to find out what my frame rate is more than any actual recording. i’ve found that with this game, while DXtory is running will crash on start up.
it’s a minor thing to over look, so if you’re having trouble and running any software which records, and/or shows your frame rate then try playing with out it to see if it is a conflict. even if it isn’t, you’ve eliminated one possibility of what might be wrong.

2.
create a shortcut for Murdered Soul Suspect .exe
however, don’t right-chick and ask Steam to make you one. for some odd reason my computer see’s the shortcut as a web url and won’t let me do what i will mention next.
so file location is Murdered Soul Suspect / Binaries/Win64/Murdered.exe
right-click > create shortcut > drag/drop shortcut on desktop > right-click it > properties > shortcut tab > find target:, and the end of the “text” press space, add, and type -dx9
this should get the game up and running. it runs perfectly fine, only you don’t get to use Steam overlay or get any notifications or achievements pop up. you still get them, along with the Steam trading cards for the game but you won’t see anything pop up on screen.

3..
lets fix this game shall we?
at the time of writing, this game seems to have a problem running with a certain DirectX file.
i went to the following locations on my computer, Windows/System32 & Windows/SysWOW64. my latest d3dx9_xx file (again, at the time of writing) is, or was d3dx9_43. i deleted this file from both the locations listed and downloaded, and updated/installed the latest dx from the web installer.
Steam was closed while doing this so i would suggest doing that, then a restart of your computer.

this has done it for me. now everyone has different setups so one solution won’t solve them all. don’t be fooled into downloading some third party programs like some are suggesting. the first solution i found i totally overlooked. perhaps you have too, or perhaps you haven’t.
some people don’t regularly update their graphics drivers, some people don’t even have the recommend hardware. i do, and yet i still ran into problems.

*also find the FateSystemSettings.ini find the following lines and change it to..
ChromaticUVNudge=0.000000"
"ChromaticBlendExp=0.000000"
"

reviewText: I finished it, got all the achievements and I can tell you that this game is not that bad like most reviewers say but it's not a masterpiece either. reviewText:
If you are interested in adventure games focused on the story, it is a decent game. The investigation bits aren't developed compared to other games like sherlock holmes, it simply adds to the story. It is not a very long game, even if you are into collecting all the pieces to unlock other non-playable short stories, which is kinda boring IMHO.

My biggest problem with this title is the unnecessary addition of quicktime events during gameplay. Quicktime is alright if they are few and far between, but in this game it is added in several mechanics, from fighting demons to escaping from demon pits. They should've done away with all of that if they didn't bother adding a different mechanism of fighting and evading danger.

The graphics are alright and the dialogue is okay - if your graphics card isn't at least a medium-end one I'd say skip it mostly because you might run into a few issues with fps, which will probably take away from the game as you have to walk all around places and kill demons to get to the objectives.

I can recommend this game only if you enjoy story focused games and even in this case, if its on a sale. I wouldn't recommend people paying over $15 on this one.

reviewText:
A very disappointing game. I expected a relaxing adventure game with nice graphics, a nice story, some easy puzzles and some exploration. Unfortunately only the graphics held up to my expectations. The story wasn't very original up to the point where I quit, but at least it was interesting enough to follow it. So it could have been a decent game - if it weren't for the abysmal gameplay.

The whole game is basically one of those crappy hidden object games. You walk around with your ghost character and search for clues (objects or people you can interact with) so you can walk up to them and press a button. Doh. Once you've found enough clues you can combine the most important ones  (which again means mindlessly pressing buttons, don't get your hopes up) to 'solve' the scene and move on with the story.

Oh, and apart from that sometimes you have to fight demons. Sounds exciting? It is not. You just have to walk up to them from behind and press a button combination. Just another very dull gameplay mechanic.

Murdered: Soul Suspect would have been a better game if it was one of those Walking Simulators like 'Dear Esther'. And that says something. The gameplay is simply too boring and annoying to enjoy the (not even outstanding) story of the game. Not recommended.

reviewText:
A very easy game, No real challenge at any point (Demons can be annoying at best) but still was enjoyable to play. A good solid story, It gets you hooked and you want to solve the murders.

*WARNING*

If you are going for the achievements (main one being collecting all artifacts)  make sure you have them all before the last chapter as there is no way back after, as I found out (Woe is very much me) I am now debating wether I can be  asked to play through again for the achievement I missed or just leave it (I probably will at some point, it'll just keep nagging me otherwise).

Summary:-

Easy, Enjoyable Crime solver worth buying in a sale.

reviewText:
Got this game via. a Humble Bundle and despite the recommendation, I'm glad I didn't pay full price.

This is not a bad game. However, it isn't a spectacular one either. I enjoyed playing it, and think it's worth the purchase, but only within the $5 - $10 range.

The game isn't particularly long--7 - 10 hours not including collectables--and due to the murder mystery-esque storyline, has little replay value.

Combat is non-existant, and instead the few enemies met in the game are dispatched using sneak up behind them and perform a button combination" tactics. The encounters are never difficult
date: and with the exception of perhaps one or two near the end
recommended: pretty straight forward.\n\nThe meat of the game involves crime-scene investigation
